text:
The process had begun to look more of a coronation than a contest. In mid-June, Canada's Progressive Conservative Party will hold a convention to pick the successor to Brian Mulroney as prime minister, and all signs pointed to Kim Campbell, the defence minister. Other cabinet heavyweights had bowed out. Discounting three Conservative backbenchers, Ms Campbell's only serious contender was the environment minister, Jean Charest, and he had obstacles to overcome. At 34 he is a bit too young and, like Mr Mulroney, he comes from Quebec. By tradition, it should be the turn of another province to take the prime ministership.
But in London on March 30th, Ms Campbell found herself complaining that the tiresome term "Campbellmania" sugested that her supporters were "faintly unbalanced. Couldn't we call it Campbellrationality?" Indeed, some rationality has begun to enter the selection process and, as a result, Ms Campbell may not have an entirely clear run to the prime ministership.
People have begun to look beyond their first beguilement with a witty woman of 46 from British Columbia who as justice minister showed off a fine pair of shoulders in a memorable photograph. Under scrutiny, liberals complain, her three years as justice minister reveal more skill at compromise than clear progressiveness on such issues as homosexual rights and gun control. As defence minister. she is under fire, even from members of her own party, for spending C$5.8 billion ($4.6 billion) on EH-101 helicopters at a time of recession and peace. She began her political life in the right-wing Social Credit Party and questions are being asked about both her economic policies and her world view. Opposition Liberals have been quick to argue that Ms Campbell offers no change, except a bright face, from the inner circle of older Mulroney ministers.
In contrast, Mr Charest has mangaed to seem fresh and open-minded. He is bilingual (Ms Campbell speaks passable French) and is respected for having put up a good performance at the Earth summit in Brazil, as well as for having chaired a useful committee on the constitution. Among those convention delegates who set a high store on family values, Mr Charest's happy home life will score against Ms Campbell's two divorces.
But Ms Campbell's strongest card is that Conservatives see her as the candidate most likely to carry them to victory at the general election that must take place by November. Though the Liberals have led by some 20 points in opinion polls for the past two years, a recent poll put the Tories under her leadership almost that far ahead of the Liberals under Jean Chretien. Mr Chretien, who this week marks 30 years (with one short break) in federal politics, has held every senior cabinet post except the prime ministership. Many doubt how well he would fit that missing part.

text:
In her two months as Canada's prime minister, Kim Campbell has brought her Progressive Conservative Party within striking distance of the Liberals, led by Jean Chretien. Most Canadian federal elections in the past quarter-century have been decided on the voters' assessment of party leaders. So her test will come within a few weeks, when she embarks on the 47-day campaign for the election that is almost certain to take place before the end of October.
Ms Campbell has been doing her best to suggest a range of differences with Brian Mulroney's government, without repudiating any of its policies--which she could hardly do since she was first his minister of justice, and then of defence. Her answer is a new image, particularly of herself.
Mr Mulroney, prime minister for nine years until he retired in June, was mistrusted and unpopular except in his native Quebec. His efforts to unify Canadians through constitutional reform and to bring jobs through free-trade agreements were judged a failure. As defence minister, Ms Campbell herself had to defend the purchase of 50 military helicopters costing C$5.8 billion ($4.5 billion).
With the open look of a healthy blonde, she has reflected the sunny mood of summertime Canada. She has avoided controversial issues, preferring to be interviewed by disc jockeys than by political pundits. She has kept photographers busy with her cheerful hats, and she pitched a baseball competently. Flitting across Canada--on national day, July 1st, she greeted the dawn in Newfoundland and watched the sunset in her own British Colombia--she has shed some of her elitist skin. Mr Mulroney used to travel in limousines, but she took the subway in Toronto and walked the streets of Regina when paying a call on two provincial premiers. While the Mulroneys were furnishing their new mansion in Montreal with whirlpools in every bathroom and trying to sell their prime-ministerial furniture to the government, she was telling radio-show audiences that she had not even bought linen for her official residence.
As a first move towards fulfilling her promise--made when she was fighting for the party leadership--to eliminate the present C$32.6 billion federal deficit within five years, she cut the cabinet by eight ministers, and the civil service by nine government departments. She also refused to sign election nomination papers for three Quebec parliamentarians who face charges of misusing public funds; a step designed to appeal to supporters of the Reform Party, which has sprung to influence in western Canada. For Canadian nationalists who maintained that Mr Mulroney was a branch-plant American, Ms Campbell and her external affairs minister, Perrin Beatty, have managed to distance themselves a little: lifting a ban on aid to Cuba, opposing an air strike in Bosnia and holding out against sanctions in Bill Clinton's NAFTA side-deals (see page 21).
The summer has been less kind to Mr Chretien and the New Democrat leader, Audrey McLaughlin. Mr Chretien has been embroiled in squabbles with a dozen constituency associations, accused of using his position to "parachute" high-powered names on to the list of Liberal candidates. He was one of Pierre Trudeau's most energetic ministers but now, it seems, his folksy style belongs to an older generation of politics. For her part, Ms McLaughlin stumbled when, on August 11th, she bought an hour of network time for a "television town-hall meeting". Her admission that the opening video was made in Washington brought derision on the leader of a party that has vowed to abrogate the free-trade treaty.

text:
They have enjoyed one of the sunniest summers they can remember. Now Canadians face a hard-to-forecast general election on October 25th, and a clouded future, whoever wins.
One cloud is political: there will probably be no outright winner. Canada has three major parties, but a first-past-the-post electoral system. So the Conservatives or the Liberals have usually managed to win an overall majority, leaving the New Democrats to play the national conscience, with occasional power in the provinces (as at present in Ontario, British Columbia and Saskatchewan). This year, though, two regional parties are doing well, the separatist Bloc Qubecois and the Alberta-based Reform Party. The best guess is that neither the Conservative prime minister, Kim Campbell, nor the Liberal leader, Jean Chretien, will win a clear majority of the 295 seats. Indeed neither may do better than 120.
This need not be worrying. Minority government is nothing new in Canada, nor need it mean stalemate. Lester Pearson headed two minority Liberal governments in the 1960s that brought in big welfare programmes. Pierre Trudeau had to govern for two years by the grace of the New Democrats, and paid for their support by creating the national oil corporation, Petro-Canada, which brought Canadians inside knowledge of a mainly foreign-owned industry.
Ms Campbell is trying for a third Conservative majority government, but takes pains to call it a first Campbell one, to distance herself from Brian Mulroney, who ended nine years as prime minister in deep unpopularity. In the short time she had before having to call an election, she worked hard on the barbecue circuit to make herself known and liked, but the 47 days of the election campaign will be the test of a relatively untried politician.
She was Mr Mulroney's minister of justice, and then of defence, for less than four years. Mr Chretien, in contrast, held almost all the important portfolios under Mr Trudeau. But few younger voters know or care. As one pollster put it this week, the choice is between a fresh leader with a tired party and a tired leader with a fresh party.
Ms Campbell is trying to get rid of one albatross, or rather seven, inherited from her own defence-ministry past. On September 2nd she announced she would cut from 50 to 43 the number of helicopters that Canada is to buy, still laden with equipment to spot Soviet submarines. Supposedly, this will save C$1 billion ($750m) of the original C$5.8 billion cost; but Ms Campbell's announcement has merely made the deal a live issue again. A nastier affair is still round her neck: a belated flow of revelations of murderous indiscipline in the Canadian Airborne Regiment in Somalia.
The real cloud is economic. With little sin of recovery, and the unemployment rate now at 11.6%, the main issue will be jobs and the recent cost-cutting by the federal government and all ten provincial ones. In the past fiscal year, their combined deficits totalled C$60 billion, nearly 9% of GDP. Ms Campbell, though talking of eliminating today's C$32.6 billion federal deficit within five years, has promised there will be no new or higher taxes. So thousands of civil servants fear for their jobs, other voters for social programmes, such as medicare and pensions.
Jobs will be the issue for the New Democrat leader, Audrey McLauhlin. She has a detailed plan to create 1-1/2m of them over five years, while reducing the deficit and holding taxes steady. This appealing snake-oil, based on investing in everything from modern transportation to a national child-care system, is her party's best hope of climbing from its present sorry 8% in opinion polls. Of its present 43 seats, mostly in western Canada, half are at risk.
The Liberals will publish their full platform only after a week of campaigning. If they are even to come close to a clear majority, they must take two-thirds of the 99 seats in Ontario and--more difficult--regain some 20 in Quebec that they lost to Mr Mulroney, a Quebecker. But the popular Lucien Bouchard and his Bloc Quebecois could win half of the 75 seats there, on the issue of the economy as much as Quebecois sovereignty.

text:
VOTERS are braced for a volcanic change in Canada's political landscape. For as long as most can remember, the federal government has been run by one of two parties, usually the Liberals but for the past nine years the Progressive Conservatives, with the New Democrats as a strong third party providing a social conscience. After the general election on October 25th, two regional parties, the Bloc Quebecois and the Reform Party, are expected to have knocked the traditional pattern aside.
Under Brian Mulroney, the Tories won two handsome victories, based on strong support both in Mr Mulroney's native Quebec and in oil-rich Alberta in western Canada. But these two Tory pillars grew wobbly when Kim Campbell took over the leadership in June; during the 47-day election campaign they have visibly crumbled. Ms Campbell, a lawyer from British Columbia who had difficulties in the French-language television debate, has seen Mr Mulroney's followers slide over to the Bloc Quebecois, which is expected to win most of Quebec's 75 seats. Meanwhile, Preston Manning, the son of a former premier of Alberta, has spread enthusiasm for the simple verities of his Reform Party--a balanced budget, smaller government, less immigration through western Canada and into Ontario.
The main pre-election question is whether the Liberals under Jean Chretien will win a narrow majority of the 295 seats, or have to struggle as a coalition or minority government. The Liberals have won support with their plausible plan for job-creation, a more attractive line--in a country with chronic unemployment now running above ll%--than Ms Campbell's insistence on reducing the budget deficit. But debts and deficits remain, and the new Reform MPS, plus whatever is left of the Tories, will undoubtedly chase the issue of economic management.
The Bloc Quebecois may well help Mr Chretien out on economic questions; its leader, Lucien Bouchard, places the party left of centre. But as a party fighting for Quebec sovereignty (a supposedly unfrightening form of separatism), it will otherwise be at logerheads with the Liberals. Somewhat in the tradition of Charles Stewart Parnell and Irish home rule in the British Parliament of the 1880s, its overriding object in coming to Ottawa is to fight for Quebec's interests and to prepare the way for Quebec's departure from the Canadian confederation within three years. Mr Bouchard's timetable is based on Quebec's provincial election next year, which his separatist ally (not contesting the federal election), the Parti Quebecois, may well win.
Mr Chretien's campaign has fared reasonably well in English Canada partly because people remember his long and respectable record in federal politics as Pierre Trudeau's lieutenant; by contrast Ms Campbell's way across the country has been littered with imprudent remarks. But Mr Chretien's links to Trudeau federalism, which offered no special treatment for Quebec, make him anathema to the nationalists around Mr Bouchard.
When battle is joined in the next constitutional round, it will be bruising. Mr Manning and his colleagues have shown no sympathy for Quebec's aspirations, and indeed their party has grown in reaction to Quebec's influence on Ottawa. The country, after October 25th, will be more divided than ever, though not yet fractured.

text:
O CALAMITY
Jean Chretien, leader of the Liberal Party, will be the prime minister of Canada. He replaces Kim Campbell, whose Conservative Party was drummed out of all but two of its 157 seats. The Bloc Quebecois,, which wants sovereignty for French Canada, will be the main opposition.
Bill Clinton gave a carefully upbeat assessment of the American economy, saying that "we are finally seeing sins of hope." He was supported by subsequent news that GDP rose by an annualised 2.8% in the third quarter.
The administration's healthcare legislation was at last produced. It included an increase in the tax on each packet of cigarettes from 24 to 75 cents; a cap on health insurance premiums paid by individuals to 3.9% of their pay; and a revision of the deficit-reduction estimate for the package from $91 billion to $58 billion in 1995-2000.
Sharon Pratt Kelly, the mayor of Washington, ac, asked for authority to call up the National Guard to deal with violent crime in the city. Mr Clinton said the decision rested with Congress, which he hoped would co-operate.
Hopes dimmed for the peaceful return of democracy to Haiti. A UN-brokered plan calling for the return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide from exile was in tatters as the county's military rulers refused to resin.
DEADLY REVENGE
Northern Ireland killed ten people, including a bomber, and injured more than 50. The British government banned Gerry Adams, the president of the IRA'S political wing, Sinn Fein, from the mainland. He later attended the funeral of the bomber. Loyalist terrorists responded to the bomb by shooting Catholics. The Irish government announced a peace plan, though there was little new in it.
European heads of government gathered for a summit meeting in Brussels to celebrate the ratification of the Maastricht treaty. The treaty comes into force on November 1st.
Boris Yeltsin signed a decree permitting farmland to be traded freely in Russia for the first time since 1917.
The Bosnian government cracked down on criminal gangs and warlords who had been terrorism Sarajevo, killing 18 people and arresting over 500.
Constantine Mitsotakis, defeated in last month's Greek general election, resigned as leader of the opposition New Democracy party.
Greece conducted another mass expulsion of illegal Albanian immigrants. This time it threw out 2,700.
Ruling out the prospect of East European members until "the distant future", NATO instead endorsed an American proposal to offer would-be applicants "partnerships for peace". These are bilateral deals allowing countries to participate in some NATO operations but without any security guarantees.
As part of his attempt to revive the French centre-left, Michel Rocard was overwhelmingly elected as secretary-general of the Socialist Party, which he has led provisionally since March.
COME TOGETHER
Talks bean in Indonesia between the Philippine government and Muslim separatists from the island of Mindanao. It was the first time the two sides had met formally since the insurrection bean two decades ago.
Reports in South Korea suggested that America might grant North Korea diplomatic recognition in return for permission for the IAEA to inspect the country's nuclear facilities.
The president of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev, refused to sin an agreement on dismantling nuclear weapons with Warren Christopher, the American secretary of state. He wanted a full-blown ceremony with Bill Clinton.
POINT OF DEPARTURE
A mass exodus of foreigners from Algeria could follow President Mitterrand's warning that he might evacuate the tens of thousands of French nationals living there. This follows a spate of fundamentalist attacks on expatriates, including the kidnapping of three French consular officials.
Israel released 617 Palestinian prisoners but dropped its plan to include some members of Hamas, the Muslim resistance movement.
Two Americans, a Frenchman and an Egyptian were murdered in a Cairo hotel. The authorities, anxious to protect Egypt's shattered tourist industry, said the assassin was not a Muslim militant, but was deranged.
The Angolan government and UNITA rebels met for secret UN-sponsored talks in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, to try to negotiate an end to the fighting.
A coup in Burundi, in which the president, Melchior Ndadaye, was murdered, crumbled. Army generals called on the prime minister, Sylvie Kinigi, to come out of hiding and take control of the country. Thousands died in inter-ethnic fighting.

text:
Is Canada worth preserving? Half of those who voted on October 25th in its querulous, mostly French-speaking province of Quebec supported a party that says No. How many truly share that view is not clear. To send the Bloc Quebecois to the federal parliament in Ottawa as the main opposition is one thing. To elect its provincial equivalent, the Parti Quebecois, to power in Quebec next year would be another; and to support the demand for Quebec's independence in a referendum to be held there in 1995 a still more fateful step. Yet all of this could happen in the aftershocks of an election that has reduced the governing party to rubble and remade Canada's political landscape (see page 43). The question is what, if anything, other Canadians should, or can, do to repair their fissile federation.
The sensible answer--though not, for many Canadians, the sentimental one--is not very much. Separation would do Canada no great harm. In an era of free trade and free movement, no vital part of its economy would be torn apart. Its geographically disconnected Atlantic provinces would no doubt feel isolated, but little more so, in practical terms, than they are now. That needs to be set against Quebec's grievances, which are founded in history and tribal consciousness--forces that can often be even stronger than those of economics.
Quebec's provincial government already controls its own education and nearly all its own linguistic policy, the foundations of national identity. It does not control its own economy, but then no non-communist government does. It is suffering painfully from unemployment, but so is all of Canada. It is as much (which is a lot) in control of its own taxation as any other province. It likes to see itself as the poor stepdaughter, ill-treated by a miserly mother in Ottawa. Yet federal money, not least for high technology, has flowed freely to the province. For the past five years, to go no further back, most Quebec MPS have been on the government side; the Conservative prime minister until a few months ago, Brian Mulroney, was himself from Quebec, as is Jean Chretien, the new Liberal one. Insofar as Quebec has a case against the centre, it is one shared by most other provinces. What more does it want?
The problematic answer has long been: quite a lot. Canada has made two recent attempts to meet Quebec's demands. The first was rejected by the other provinces. But a second deal, which included recognition of Quebec as a "distinct society" and lots of protection for its Frenchness, was accepted by all the provincial governments, Quebec's included, as well as the federal one--only to be thrown out in a referendum last year. The Quebecois, unlike their government, thought it gave them too little; many other Canadians thought it gave them too much.
When people feel like that, with both sides unready for the compromises that could keep them together, they should perhaps part. That would not be painless: history and tribal feeling are not the monopoly of Canada's French-speakers, and there are many Canadians who feel for Canada just as Quebecois do for Quebec. Nor would Anglo-Canadians, thoroughly fed up with Quebec, bend over backwards, financially or otherwise, to help it on its way. But in the end it takes only one to end a marriage. If one province does feel that way, while the others think the demands it makes for a still fragile reconciliation are unreasonably high, so be it.
BREAKING UP STILL HURTS
Yet even if the possibility of a sovereign Quebec need not alarm outsiders unduly, the breaking up of Canada would have other costs. First to feel them would be Quebec's English-speakers. Even now, linguistic zeal weighs on the 18% or so of Quebeckers who do not speak French. Never mind the language of shop-signs. The rules that prevent non-Canadian newcomers from sending their children to English-language schools pose a much harder problem. There are arguments for this based on social integration. But that is not the purpose; and there is a strong case of civil liberty against it. True, the Quebec government already warns might-be immigrants of its rules. But how quickly, in an independent Quebec, would an acceptable concern for national identity become linguistic chauvinism?
The portents are not encouraging. About a fifth of Canada's people do not, of choice, speak its main language. About a fifth of Quebec's cannot speak its. Canada has two official languages Quebec has only one. When Lucien Bouchard, the Bloc Quebecois leader, celebrated his triumph on Monday night before the television cameras, he spoke in French to his Quebecois supporters. He spoke briefly--and responsibly--in English to the rest of Canada. For English-speaking Quebeckers, fellow citizens of his may-be country, he had not a word.
For the outside world--a gleeful France excepted--a Canada-in-pieces, though no disaster, would be no asset either. An independent Quebec would be unlikely to want to denounce international accords accepted by today's Canada, whether of defence or trade. Quebec's nationalists are not, as one might imagine, wild protectionists: on the contrary, it is the Liberals, now in national power, who have talked--implausibly--of renegotiating the existing free-trade agreement with the United States and the still-to-happen NAFTA deal. Yet could NAFTA, already at risk in the United States, survive the shattering of Canada into squabbling pieces? The parting, however messy, would not threaten a new Bosnia. Still, a smaller Canada, its insistent voice for fair-mindedness and good citizenship muted in the world's councils, would be a loss.
Put it simply. If Canada breaks apart--and if is not yet when--the United Nations would gain a new member, the United States would have two northern neighbours instead of one, and that would be about it. Canada as we now know it would have one. That would be sad, but bearable.

text:
His wildest dream, or a nightmare? As the long election campaign progressed, Jean Chretien grew more confident of winning a modest majority of the 295 seats in Canada's Parliament for his Liberal Party. On October 25th he succeeded, but perhaps a little too well. The Liberals won 177 seats and in the process devastated the other two traditional, federalist parties. The Progressive Conservatives, who held 157 seats at the start of this campaign, have been reduced to an absurd two. The New Democrats have sunk from 44 to nine.
In the debris of these old parties stand two fresh, dangerous opponents. The new groupings show up Canada's fault lines. The Liberals won all but one of the 32 seats in the four provinces of Atlantic Canada, and all but one of the 99 seats in Ontario. But they won less than one-third of the 75 seats in Quebec, where the separatist Bloc Quebecois took 54 and now becomes the official opposition. They also won only one third of the 89 seats lying west of Ontario, where the right-wing Reform Party took 51 (plus a solitary Ontario seat).
On election night Lucien Bouchard, for the Bloc, spoke of the aims (economic growth and job creation) that he shared with the Liberals; Preston Manning for the Reformers talked of the need to develop "a new federalism". Behind these polite sentiments lies the unpleasant fact that the two parties are protest movements with overwhelming strength in their regions--and antipathetic to one another.
There are straws to clutch in this high wind. The most substantial is the size of the Liberal majority. Mr Chretien will be able to stimulate the economy without worrying overmuch about criticism from the cost-cutting Reformers. He has a pretty good crew. Among the small contingents of Liberal MPS from western Canada and from Quebec are excellent newcomers, and his cabinet may be the most talented for a generation.
His party boasts a record number of 53 women MPS, including Ethel Blondin-Andrew, an Inuit from the Western Arctic, and Jean Augustine, who emigrated from Jamaica under the domestic workers programme to become head of Toronto's housing authority. And he himself is a reassuring presence. His reputation is a comfort after the mistrust that Brian Mulroney, the former Conservative leader, provoked; his experience (the prime ministership is his tenth portfolio) shows up well in contrast to the amateurish performance of Kim Campbell, who ends her brief spell as Conservative prime minister.
But on the most vital issue of all--whether or not Quebec will stay within Canada--he is hobbled by his past. As Pierre Trudeau's loyal lieutenant, he is linked to the policy of treating Quebec constitutionally like any other province. This makes it difficult for him to switch to a more flexible approach. Recognising this handicap, he appealed in his victory speech to Canadians to "leave constitutional quarrels on the back burner". Mr Bouchard, who stormed out of the Mulroney cabinet to form the Bloc Quebecois when the Meech Lake constitutional amendments failed in 1990, is hardly likely to agree.
Mr Bouchard's first words to his nationalist supporters on election night were to remind them of the defiance of Rene Levesque, Quebec's late premier, when he lost the referendum on sovereignty in 1980: "We will see you next time". For Mr Bouchard, that time will come if the Parti Quebecois (the Bloc's provincial ally) wins the provincial election next year--and honours Levesque's memory by winning, through another referendum, the mandate to carry Quebec and its 7m people to political sovereignty.
Optimists say that Monday's election has got rid of under cover manoeuvres and ambiguity: the Quebec issue will now have to be settled in a straightforward manner. Some even suggest that the Bloc's MPS will be converted to federalism through the chemistry of companionship in Ottawa and the give-and-take of question time.
But the old way of placating Quebec nationalism was to slip lucrative contracts to the province and allow its government more administrative power than any other. This would be hard for Mr Chretien. He has committed himself to cancelling the Tories' controversial C$5.8 billion ($4.4 billion) contract for military helicopters, much of which would have flowed to Quebec. And if he offers Quebec other plums, he will risk loud shouts from the Reform Party.
LOST IN THE DEBRIS
Meanwhile, the Conservatives and the New Democrats have to burrow their way out of the rubble. The surviving Tory MPS are an ill-matched pair: Jean Charest, who ran a close second to Ms Campbell for the leadership in June, and Elsie Wayne, a former New Brunswick mayor. Kim Campbell herself, having carried the weight of Mr Mulroney's unpopularity across Canada in an exhausting campaign, made a graceful exit on losing her Vancouver seat.
She may continue as party leader for a year or more, while rebuilding begins. More than 2m Canadians voted Conservative--more than for the Bloc Quebecois--and her party could have held some 20 seats in Ontario if the intervention of Reform candidates had not handed them to Liberals. The Conservatives still have a power base in the Senate, which Mr Mulroney brazenly packed before his departure.
The New Democrats, too, were humbled. Their leader, Audrey McLaughlin, survived in the Yukon, as did six others in the Prairies, the party's most secure base. But they were eliminated in Ontario, where Bob Rae's provincial government is unpopular, and almost wiped out in British Columbia for a similar reason--Michael Harcourt's NDP government lost support both for its tough measures on the deficit and for a compromise on the logging of Clayoquot rainforest that enraged environmentalists.
The New Democrats picked an uninspiring campaign issue--anxiety about the trade agreements with the United States and Mexico--and yielded ground to Mr Chretien, who concentrated steadily on the hope of good times ahead. But the NDP probably retains its niche to the left of the Liberals as a party of social conscience (so long as that is still relevant). By contrast, the Conservatives, or what remains of them, are squeezed between the Liberals moving to the right and the Reform Party surging from the far-right. Kim Campbell's final affectionate words to her followers on election night--"Consider yourselves hugged"--may carry a more ominous meaning.

text:
So with NAFTA safely accepted by Congress in Washington, all is sweetness and free trade in North America, is it? It is not.
This week, in accordance with campaign promises, Canada's new Liberal government, headed by Jean Chretien, held talks with the United States, trying to reopen parts of the NAFTA package. The deal was ratified in the spring by the then Conservative-controlled Ottawa parliament, but was not proclaimed as law.
The two countries have had their own free-trade agreement since 1988. Most often, it works well enough. But the Canadians--not alone--dislike the way American industry, whenever competition gets tough, tries to force its government to pull up the drawbridges, with cries of "subsidy" or "dumping".
In recent examples, Canadian durum wheat--exports of which are controlled by a wheat-marketing board--is alleged to have been dumped. The "stumpage" fee paid by Canadian logging companies to provincial governments is so low, American rivals complain, as to amount to a subsidy. After years of wrangling, Norsk Hydro, which produces magnesium in Quebec using low-cost hydro-electricity, was hit six weeks ago with countervailing import duties on both charges. The Canadians want the rules on these issues tightened and clarified.
Mr Chretien's hands, though, are hardly clean. Even if his party had not opposed the 1988 agreement, which it did, there are plenty of protectionists in his own backyard. Ancient supply-management mechanisms protect Canada's daily, egg and poultry farmers from cheaper American imports. In Windsor, next door to Detroit, car-component workers believe a long-standing free-trade agreement in that industry has done them more harm than good. Road haulage and air transport are firmly protected (as they are in the United States).
In the name of Canadian culture, publishers too are protected: Canadian firms that advertise in American magazines cannot treat the cost as a tax-deductible expense, and the government even has power (albeit never yet used) to ban imports of "split-run" editions of American magazinesAmerican editorial tarted up maybe with a bit of Canadian news but surrounded by Canadian advertising. Broadcasters must use a certain proportion of Canadian material.
So far, so normal. Much less so is some bizarre intra-Canadian protection. Quebec has for some time had rules that prevent building workers from other provinces being employed there, unless they have an--almost unattainable--Quebec certificate of competence and several months' prior employment outside Quebec for the firm that wants to use them inside. The effects are seen at their craziest in Ottawa (Ontario) and its twin, Hull (Quebec), just across a well-bridged river. Economically, the two are a single city, and 4,000 Quebeckers work on Ottawa building sites. Yet the whole of Ontario--it claims--supplies only 350 builders to the entire province of Quebec.
Quebec's neighbours are now fed up. Tiny New Brunswick this year hit back, with laws specifically aimed at Quebec. Big Ontario now plans to do likewise. It has already, in September, brought in rules that bar Quebec contractors and even building materials from projects financed by the provincial government (as well as banning subsidies for purchases of Quebec-made buses). A new provincial bill tabled on November 25th would bar Quebec workers from any Ontario building site, public or private.
The aim is deterrence: a negotiated retreat by Quebec, not a tit-for-tat trade war. It may work: Quebec in recent weeks had already made some small concessions. But maybe Mr Chretien, before he remarks on the moats around Bill Clinton's markets, should try bolting together the fractured beams in his own.

text:
Can Canada stay in one piece? Two months ago all bets were on a land slide victory for the Parti Quebecois (PQ), under Jacques Parizeau, in the provincial election due in Quebec by September. Daniel Johnson, who took over as premier there in January, was seen as a caretaker leader of the Quebec Liberals, if not their undertaker.
Mr Parizeau had made a solid alliance with the (federal) Bloc Quebecois, which swept 54 of Quebec's 75 seats in last October's federal election, and the Bloc's leader, Lucien Bouchard, was making the most of his outpost in Ottawa as leader of Her Majesty's loyal opposition to argue the case for Quebec's sovereignty. Even their opponents believed that between them the two could build enough momentum at least to carry the PQ into power in Quebec and maybe to win a referendum there on separation.
Mr Bouchard, a former ambassador and then environment minister in Ottawa under Brian Mulroney--they split over constitutional issues, and in 1990 he set up the Bloc--has built up a solid public stature. His fledgling MPS have been swift to take wing in debates. They deliver well researched speeches, and keep close formation over such unfamiliar terrain as ex-Yugoslavia and Canada's 2,000-plus troops there. At the same time, they use phrases such as "Canada and Quebec" to imply that separation has practically occurred.
On a visit to New York and Washington this month, Mr Bouchard made plain that sovereignty meant real separation from Canada, though he assured the 11 congressmen he met that it would be amicably done.
He also developed the argument that separation was necessary for economic as much as cultural reasons, representing Canada's present set-up as an inefficient mess impeding the progress of Quebec.
Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, welcomed his frankness in using "the real word, separation," instead of the soft one, "sovereignty". If the Quebec election and any subsequent referendum are fought on the clear issue of separation and argued on economic grounds, it will be a bold departure from the 1980 referendum there, when a convoluted question about "sovereignty-association" was defeated, with a 20% main, by voters fearful of the economic consequences. Whether honesty and boldness will pay is less clear. The chairman of the New York Power Authority has said New York is "awash" with power, and has recommended cancelling a $5 billion contract with Hydro-Quebec. This could delay the second, hue stage of Quebec's James Bay hydro-power scheme.
On his side, Mr Johnson has shown frankness beyond the style of his predecessor, Robert Bourassa, in declaring himself a forthright federalist who does not want to extract more powers from Ottawa. His Liberals recently lost one by-election to the PQ in a seat they had held for 37 years; but they promptly won a PQ seat in return. Opinion polls now put them back level with the PQ
That still suggests a PQ victory in the provincial election, since so much of the Liberal vote is concentrated in the island of Montreal. But a third party, Action Democratique de Quebec, has just been launched. text:
Not every government--ask Britain's--likes to frame its foreign policy in public. But Canada's voters expect a new party in office to make a serious review of foreign relations. When the Liberals under Jean Chretien swept to power last October, Mr Chretien promised just that, and as public a review as possible. It is now under way.
The start came last month, when Mr Chretien assembled 120 experts from universities, companies and voluntary agencies--plus a few retired generals--in Ottawa's old railway station, now a conference centre. He in person started them off, without telling them which way to face. But he left a hint. When he flew off that afternoon to Mexico on a trade mission, he by-passed Washington. After six months as prime minister, he has not been there yet.
There is good reason, the Liberals say, for a thoroughgoing review. As the cold war ended, Canada began withdrawing its last troops and aircraft from Europe, only to send peacekeepers back to ex-Yugoslavia. The country faces a foreign debt of some C$200 billion ($145 billion), and is searching the world for new export markets to help finance it. Having produced a federal budget in February which, even with cuts, forecast a deficit of more than C$39 billion, the government is under pressure for more cuts in both defence and foreign aid. It also assures environmentalists that it takes very seriously the action plan--Agenda 21--from the Rio summit two years ago. It lines up with voluntary agencies in demanding a proper concern for human rights. All these aims and obligations are being thrown into the mix. Nothing is taboo, says the foreign minister, Andre Ouellet.
He is getting plenty of advice. At the Ottawa forum, some leading businessmen argued that Latin America's markets rather than East Asia's were Canada's best hope of escaping its dependence on the United States. Everyone agreed--well, said they did--that aid must be separate from trade. Little was said about the European Union, and most of those who spoke about Canada's remaining links to NATO suggested they might wither away rather than be cut formally. In the background lay a radical document from a group of notables called the Canada 21 Council, arguing against keeping large forces of fighter aircraft and anti-submarine frigates, and for training many more peacekeeping troops.
Two parliamentary committees began raking over these points this week. They may find it hard to make a coherent whole of them. Defence won a battle over foreign affairs in getting a separate committee for its concerns, and it is unclear whether the main committee will rasp the thorny issue of immigration policy; no small lacuna, of it is left out, given the government's target of 250,000 immigrants this year.
The main opposition party, the Bloc Quebecois, is firmly pro-American, while the Liberals are eager to take a more independent line after the Mulroney era. Mr Ouellet has already taken two steps independently of the United States, in announcing that Canada will ratify the Law of the Sea Convention this year and in urging his American counterpart, Warren Christopher, to forget old quarrels and integrate Cuba into the hemispheric family.
What real difference will it all make? In the end, for all the fine words in the old railway station and in committee rooms, foreign policy will probably still be made by the officials around the finance minister, Paul Martin. Which means staying close to the apron strings of the United States.

text:
NOT since Wolfe defeated Montcalm have the battle lines in Quebec been so clearly drawn as they have during the provincial campaign that culminates on September 12th.
The Parti Quebecois (PQ) leader, Jacques Parizeau, has forthrightly called himself "a sovereigntist [supporter of Quebec independence] before, during and after the election", unlike the first PQ leader, Rene Levesque, who held (and lost) a referendum in 1980 on a vague concept that he called "sovereignty-association". In the opposing trenches, the province's Liberal premier, Daniel Johnson, has declared himself "a Canadian first and foremost"; his wary Liberal predecessor, Robert Bourassa, used to refer to "profitable federalism", suggesting that, if ever Quebec's place in Canada were to turn unprofitable, he too might think it time to decamp.
Though pollsters put support for independence at only around the 1980 referendum level of 40%, Mr Parizeau is expected to triumph in Monday's battle. Seemingly beyond hope at the start, Mr Johnson has fought a spirited campaign, accusing the PQ of wanting to lead Quebec into a mist of uncertainty about the costs of independence, rather than tackle practical tasks like unemployment and debt. And for a time the Liberal counter-attack gained round. But a poll published on September 6th gave the PQ 49% of decided voters, the Liberals, surprisingly, only 38%, with the rest going mainly to a minor party led by breakaway Liberals with Quebec-nationalist leanings. If those figures prove correct, the PQ can hope for at least 85 of the 125 seats in what Quebec already calls its National Assembly.
If only 40% of Quebeckers want independence, why is the PQ doing so well? The answer is the Liberals' nine years of power, and the long recession that this included. The ruling party was visibly exhausted when the ailing Mr Bourassa retired last winter. Half the cabinet chose not to fight again. Mr Johnson had little time to reinvigorate his troops. And the provincial economy only really got moving again this summer.
In the sole television debate between the two leaders, Mr Parizeau made much of the economy: why, for instance, has Montreal 100,000 fewer jobs today than before the recession? This sort of question, and the length of hospital waiting lists, have ranked as election issues quite as high as Mr Johnson's warnings--fiercely disputed by Mr Parizeau, with equal barrages of figures--about the costs of separating from Canada.
Quebec's language laws, often a source of contention in the past 20 years, have barely figured in the campaign, though early on Mr Johnson raised the fear that a PQ victory would prompt an exodus of English-speaking Quebeckers. This in fact seems unlikely. In the 15 years after the PQ took power in 1976, some 250,000 of them did leave. Those who remain, about 9% of the province's 6.8m people, can mostly work comfortably in French. Still, Liberal support is concentrated notably in areas, like the western half of Montreal, lived in by these and other Quebeckers for whom French is not their mother-tongue.
The question is whether, having won the battle, Mr Parizeau could win the war. He says he will first put through the National Assembly a "solemn declaration" that Quebec's people desire independence. In 1995 he will call a referendum on the issue, whether or not Quebec, the federal government and the other nine provinces have negotiated a break-up agreement by then.
Would a referendum get through? Certainly things look easier for the PQ than in 1980. In the Bloc Quebecois it has a strong ally in the federal parliament; and the federal government is headed by a prime minister, Jean Chretien, whose standing in Quebec is shaky compared with the then towering figure of Pierre Trudeau.
Though its top three men-prime minister, foreign minister and finance minister--are Quebeckers, the federal government has taken virtually no part in the election. Mr Chertien decided to hold his fire until the campaign for sovereignty begins in earnest. It is not clear, though, what he will do then. A counter-referendum, for instance, or a series of federal/provincial meetings to show up Mr Parizeau as unco-operative--both would have their hazards. So would a blank refusal to contemplate any negotiations, while waiting hopefully for Mr Parizeau to make mistakes.
The provincial premiers too--like the general public outside Quebec--have kept quiet during the final weeks of the election campaign. The premiers were noticeably coy about promising any action to protect Indian rights in the event of a break-up, though vast areas of northern Quebec are peopled-so far as they are peopled at all--mostly by Cree Indians. The removal of some barriers that face building contractors trying to do business across provincial boundaries, and an agreement that the premiers will meet regularly on their own to discuss national issues, may weaken Mr Parizeau's case, but not his resolve.
He will still have to convince a majority of Quebeckers. Polls show that almost 60% of them want a referendum, while nearly half favour the "solemn declaration", and would want a PQ government to get on with drafting an independence constitution and seeking negotiations with Ottawa. These high figures may look good news for Mr Parizeau. More plausibly, they suggest that, while many Quebeckers want the sovereignty issue settled one way or another, the aim for quite a number is to get rid of it.

text:
On being normal in a down-the-rabbit-hole sort of world
IN A world full of turmoil, there ought to be some countries that are just plain normal. Indeed, more and more claim the title. Not Canada, though, a country famed for its ordinariness. Jean Chretien, the prime minister, bristles: "Canada is not a normal country...It is an extraordinary country. And nothing in the world would make me change it for a country that is only normal." Quite so. But if Canada is not the super-normal place people thought it was, who does set the standard?
Japan, which used to pride itself on conformity with the norm, no loner seems quite so sure. Ichiro Ozawa, the string puller behind Japan's opposition parties, puts up "The Normal Nation" as a slogan for the sort of Japan he would like to see. (Rivals include "A Country of Unpretentious Excellence" and the rather more opaque "Air, Sun, Water, Rice".) Yet many Japanese were outraged by the proposal that they should change their ways. "What nation does he think is normal?", growled Beat Takeshi, a political satirist. "Somalia? Iraq?"
In contrast, the countries of Eastern and Central Europe no longer talk of normality as an aspiration but rather an achievement. Last year Dusan Slobodnik, Slovakia's minister of culture, said: "We are not...totalitarians. We are a normal nation." Vaclav Klaus, the Czech prime minister, insisted cheerfully that "the Czech Republic is no loner a post-communist country in transition. Now we're a normal country." Back in 1991 Jan Krszystof Bielecki, Poland's prime minister, promised to make his "a normal country". His successor, Hanna Suchocka, said that she too wanted Poland to be "a normal country". The pair did good work: the New York Times wrote in July that "Poland is becoming a more normal nation."
West Europeans also want to stand in in a crowd. Spain's prime minister, Felipe Gonzalez, declared in 1992: "My heartfelt desire for many years of my life was that Spain should be considered a normal country." He should feel satisfied: the Financial Times wrote last year that, by and large, "Spain is the most normal of countries." Italians crave the same: "Three years ago," points out Beppe Sevelgnini, an Italian journalist, "Italians decided they had had enough. They wanted a normal country." As the song goes and Italians have discovered, you can't always get what you want.
A word begging to be retired
Some newcomers to normality have seemed unsettled by the experience. Some time after the end of the Soviet Union, The Economist wrote: "Russians have not yet come to terms with the idea of Russia as a normal nation-state." Similarly, Israel's deputy foreign minister, Yossi Beilin, said shortly after the Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement: "Suddenly, becoming a normal country is very, very strange for us."
Ordinariness is breaking out in some other extraordinary places. But that, it turns out, may be nothing to boast about after all. Nicholas Kristof, a New York Times reporter, has written that in China "corruption, religious zeal and public scepticism may be the hallmarks, not of a disintegrating country, but simply of a normal nation". That can hardly be good news for normal countries, wherever--and whatever--they may be.

text:
Two days before a joint Commons-Senate committee on November 14th put out its proposals for reshaping Canada's foreign policy, a group of Newfoundland fishermen came to Ottawa. Their "Folk of the Sea" choir took a larger catch with sea shanties from a sellout audience than they could have with their nets: a point not lost, maybe, on Senator Allan MacEachen, the powerful co-chairman of the committee, who has long argued that a country's image is better projected by its cultural exports--singers, writers, artists--than by politicians or even peacekeepers.
To the bewilderment of some, the senator--a former foreign minister under Pierre Trudeau--included in the report a full chapter on this topic, arguing that the projection of Canada's culture abroad should be a fundamental dimension of its foreign policy. Already, the report argued, this is the better-than-boring image by which Canada is best known abroad today--and rightly.
If some were bewildered, the Bloc Quebecois was roundly upset. In a dissenting report, these separatists--number two in the Commons--argued that projecting a unified image of Canada abroad amounts to rejecting Quebec culture, and constitutionally only the provinces can develop policies on education. All signs point to lively debates ahead.
Trade was another theme of the report--though not quite in the spirit of the present Liberal government, which in its year of office has placed great emphasis on it. (A recent, parallel review of defence policy, argued that Canada needed global security because it was a trading nation.) The prime minister, Jean Chretien, this month has led nine provincial premiers and hundreds of businessmen on a trade-seeking blitz of China and Indonesia.
Liberal Senator MacEachen's committee was ready to help, urging stronger efforts in growing markets such as Latin America, and arguing that Canada's cultural image, good in itself, could help sell Canadian products too. Artistic groups, it suggested, should accompany ministers on trade missions. But it blew cold on a more usual tool of trade promotion: links with foreign aid. Canadians across the country, it said, had told it that helping the world's poorest was Canada's primary task abroad. The aid programme, to a unique degree expressing Canadian values and ideals--"the bright side of our national character"--should be kept firmly apart from trade promotion. And, not at all by the way, it should rise toward the target 0.7% ratio of aid to GNP, which, under this government as its predecessor, Canada (like most rich countries) does not meet.

text:
LISTEN carefully. Do you hear a giant sucking sound of jobs and investment disappearing from the United States across the Rio Grande to Mexico, as predicted by Ross Perot in the great argument over the North American Free-Trade Agreement? A different noise is in the air: the hubbub of politicians singing the praises of trade liberalisation.
In Indonesia last month, America and other Asia-Pacific countries pledged to achieve free trade in the region over the next 25 years. Last week, Congress at last approved the GATT deal. At the Summit of the Americas in Miami on December 11th, Bill Clinton, together with Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, and Mexico's new president, Ernesto Zedillo, are expected to announce their intention to welcome Chile as the next member of the NAFTA club. And it seems a club worth joining: NAFTA, the politicians boast, is proving to be a triumph.
"Facts are proving NAFTA right," said Mr Zedillo during a recent visit to Washington. The agreement is turning out to be "a win-win situation", with extra jobs on all 3 sides, said Lloyd Bentsen, the departing treasury secretary, this week. Boosters for the agreement are already explaining how it demonstrates that rich countries need not fear free trade with poor neighbours (West Europeans wary of opening their markets to the ex-communist East, please note).
In fact, it is still early days for NAFTA, too early to draw confident conclusions from the experience to date. Its influence is hard to disentangle from that of other economic policies, and from the effects on trade of America's current boom (unemployment down to 5.8%, GDP growing at an annual rate of nearly 4%) and of Mexico's recovery this year (growth resumed in the second quarter, after a year-long recession). Larry Summers, the number-two at the Treasury Department, thinks that NAFTA's main impact this year has been to halt capital flight from Mexico and save the country from disaster. And some of the growth in trade is simply the result of diversion from regions, such as the Caribbean, with which bigger barriers remain. That said, the people who fought for the agreement have reason to be pleased with the first year's figures.
America's trade with Canada and Mexico has expanded at about twice the rate of trade with non-NAFTA countries in the first nine months of this year compared with the same period in 1993. American exports to Mexico grew by 22% and imports from Mexico rose by 23% (see chart); America's surplus on this trade edged up to $1.8 billion. Sales to Mexico and Canada account for some 60% of America's export growth this year.
Anti-NAFTA campaigners warned of doom for America's car industry. It turns out that Detroit is working flat out and that American car exports to Mexico have zoomed by nearly 500% in the first eight months of this year. Large rises in exports have also been seen for products ranging from semiconductors (up 98%) to apples (up 74%). The Commerce Department estimates that the surge in exports to Mexico this year has secured 130,000 American jobs.
Such estimates, based as they are on some rather big assumptions, ought not to be taken too seriously. But, contrary to the dire predictions of Mr Perot and others, American jobs and investment have clearly not been disappearing down a southern sink. Foreign investment in Mexico grew by 20% in the first eight months of this year, no faster than the 24% annual growth in 1990-93. As for NAFTA-related job losses, by early November just over 12,000 Americans had qualified for help under the special Transitional Adjustment Assistance programme run by the Department of Labour; some two-thirds of these related to trade with Mexico and one-third with Canada. That is a drop in the ocean. Over the same period, some 3.5m more American jobs were created than were lost.
So far, so good for NAFTA, it would seem. Yet its opponents have not fallen silent. They not only pass over the boon to consumers as imports bring down prices. They also tend to be oblivious to the fact that imports as well as exports help create jobs, by freeing resources at home. They note that imports from Mexico are expanding slightly faster than exports to Mexico, and conclude that this is costing America jobs.
A recent staff study by the Joint Economic Committee of the House of Representatives is a fine example of this muddled thinking. It assumes that "the overall effect of trade on employment is determined by the difference between exports (which create jobs) and imports (which eliminate jobs)." Based on their estimate of America's trade balance with Mexico, the economic committee staff reckon that trade with Mexico has cost America 10,000 jobs this year. "If that's the level of economic expertise floating around the Congress," says Jeffrey Schott of the staunchly Pro-NAFTA Institute for International Economics, "then no wonder we have a $4 trillion debt."
The bizarre depth to which discussion of the costs and benefits can sink is illustrated by another critical report on NAFTA's first year, published this week by the Institute for Policy Studies in Washington and the Centre for Urban Economic Development at the University of Illinois. "NAFTA has not led to the creation of the 100,000 jobs promised by the Clinton administration," it says. "We can find evidence of only 535." Senseless as such assertions maybe, they do reflect a problem inherent in the politics of NAFTA and other trade-liberalising efforts. The benefits are to be counted mainly at the broad, macroeconomic level (and, over time, the effect is on the quality of jobs, not their quantity). The costs, on the otherhand, are painfully visible in laid-off workers and factory closures.
NAFTA certainly does not come without such costs. As the IPS report points out, the 12,000-plus certified job losses are probably just the tip of an iceberg. Spot checks at unemployment offices by the trade-union federation, the AFL-CIO, suggest that many workers are unaware of the help available for NAFTA-related lay-offs. The companies hardest hit by NAFTA's tariff eliminations tend to be small manufacturers producing low-tech products. Workers from the clothing industry (where 70% of the workforce are women) account for nearly one-third of all recipients of special NAFTA assistance. Manufacturing plants in rural areas, where alternative jobs are hard to find, seem to have been disproportionately affected by the agreement.
Harsh as these job losses are, they are also evidence that NAFTA is working, as trade theory says it should, to create a more efficient division of labour between the countries involved. In an effort to assuage the fears of the anti-NAFTA coalition of trade-unionists, environmentalists and congressional protectionists, Mr Clinton tacked on side agreements on labour and the environment. Even after a relatively benign start for the agreement, the misgivings of the antis remain deep and the pressure to wrap labour and environmental guarantees into future trade-liberalising deals is strong.
But the pressure to do nothing of the sort is now even stronger, after the Republican takeover of Congress. Early next year Mr Clinton will ask Congress for renewed fast-track negotiating authority for trade, not least so that he can press ahead with his plans for Chile. On December 5th, Republican leaders in the House of Representatives--including Newt Gingrich, Dick Armey and Bill Archer--fired their opening shot in a letter to Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. They are in favour of fast-track authority, they say, as Mr Clinton moves to expand the agreement to other countries in the hemisphere. But they insist that labour and environmental issues should be kept strictly separate.
With the GATT and NAFTA deals done, and with serious intentions for trade liberalisation in the Asia-Pacific region and now in South America too, Mr Clinton has a trade-policy record to be proud of. More GATT-plus deals such as NAFTA (the only sort that make sense) are on the horizon. But to turn them into reality the president will have to swallow hard, burn some more Democratic brides and agree to deal on the Republicans' terms.

text:
LONG before he led his separatist Parti Quebecois to victory in the provincial elections in September, Jacques Parizeau was arguing that Quebec's road to independence could--indeed, would--be smooth, swift and painless. He set out to prove it on December 7th, when he tabled in what the province already calls its National Assembly a draft bill whose first article bluntly declares Quebec to be a sovereign state.
The bill sketches a trouble-free road ahead. Quebeckers will continue to use the Canadian dollar and can keep their Canadian passports. Quebec will abide by present Canadian treaties, so, in particular, slipping into membership of the North American Free-Trade Agreement without further negotiation.
It sounds like a joy-ride. Other Canadian politicians have been quick to point out the pot-holes. Even before Mr Parizeau revealed his bill, the separatist cause suffered a nasty blow when his ally in the federal parliament, the Bloc Quebecois leader, Lucien Bouchard, was struck down by the rare and horrible condition called necrotising myositis. Against the odds, Montreal doctors saved his life with four operations on December 1st, amputating his left leg at the thigh and digging into his chest to clear it of the flesh-eating bacteria.
Mr Bouchard, the most popular politician in Quebec, and widely respected elsewhere, was well prepared to back the provincial campaign for sovereignty by leading his 53 members of parliament, the official opposition in Ottawa, in a lively attack on the wastefulness of the federal system. He is now recovering, with none of his spirit lost, it seems. Between operations he managed to scribble a note "Que l'on continue!" ("Carry on!"), which may have been a message to his doctors but was seized on by supporters as a rallying cry for sovereignty. His doctors suggest he could be back to active politics within four months. By then his ordeal--which, to the surprise of many, brought him a wave of sympathy nationwide--may be a political asset. Meanwhile his Bloc Quebecois is left without a substitute leader of any stature.
Back in Quebec, Mr Parizeau revealed how he plans to go ahead with his draft bill. He will consult Quebeckers throuh 15 regional commissions before revising it, and then put the result to them in a referendum. He even gave the precise words of the question: "Are you in favour of the act passed by the National Assembly declaring the sovereignty of Quebec, yes or no?"
It looks straightforward, certainly more so than the complicated question on sovereignty-plus-economic-association that the first PQ government posed in 1980 (and lost). But in fact the bill--of dubious legality--that voters will be asked to judge is essentially a wish-list of the links a sovereign Quebec might have with its neighbours. Sheila Copps, Canada's deputy prime minister, called it a fraud. New Brunswick's premier, Frank McKenna, accused Mr Parizeau of trying to take Quebec out of Canada by trickery.
Still, as his opponents acknowledge, Mr Parizeau's tactics are clever. After the failure in 1990 of the Meech Lake constitutional accord, the Belanger-Campeau commission toured Quebec and produced a report calling for major concessions from the rest of Canada if Quebec were not to secede. Mr Parizeau, in contrast, will set up 15 local commissions, so minimising the effect of federalist opinion, which is heavily concentrated in Montreal (that is why, though PQ and Liberals ran neck-and-neck in the popular vote in September, the PQ took 87 provincial seats to the Liberals' 47). He will also invite all Quebec's MPS and National Assembly members to sit on these commissions--and lo, about 140 of the 200 of them are sovereigntists.
To make trebly sure, the commissions will explain the draft bill and invite amendments; in effect--like the car salesman jumping to "Do you want it red or blue, Sir?"--asking voters how to make sovereignty work, instead of debating the broader merits of separating from Canada at all.
The Quebec Liberal leader, Daniel Johnson, calls these consultations a propaganda ploy, and says his parliamentarians will take no part. So Mr Parizeau may have the field clear until mid-March, when the commissions are due to report.
How should the federal government react? Ms Copps has talked of a parallel commission to consult other parts of Canada. So far, the federal strategy has been to avoid any direct clash with Quebec separatists, even buying off incipient quarrels over the closing of a military college and the costs of the 1992 referendum (in which Canada as a whole turned down a special deal for Quebec), while it gets on with the business of cutting the federal deficit and the numbers of jobless; in otherwords, of making the Canadian federation a working success. The prime minister, Jean Chretien, who is not popular in his native Quebec, has kept busy leading provincial premiers--all but Mr Parizeau--on a trade mission to China, and addressing the French Senate; both mandeuvres offering a political pay-off at home. But at some point he will have to confront Mr Parizeau.
Mr Parizeau has set no date for his referendum, except to confirm that it will come next year. The timetable for his commissions makes June possible (which would upset Mr Chretien as he prepares for the next G7 summit in Halifax, Nova Scotia); or it might be delayed until September.
One reason for Mr Parizeau's vagueness is to keep the federalists guessing as long as possible. Another is that Mr Bouchard and he disagree on tactics. Mr Bouchard believes the referendum should wait until events and opinion polls look most favourable. Just before he went into hospital, he spoke of this being "the last fight". For separatists of his era--he is 55--because another defeat would end the idea for a generation. In contrast, Mr Parizeau has suggested a series of referendums until separatism wins. The 1980 provincial referendum was lost by a margin of 40 to 60. A recent opinion poll put support for sovereignty in Quebec at 46%. Mr Parizeau, now alone in charge, may decide to make a dash for it.

text:
WHEN newly elected, American and Canadian leaders usually hasten to congratulate each other on sharing the world's longest undefended border. But President Bill Clinton let two years pass without visiting Ottawa, and Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, has gone almost everywhere except Washington. Spin-doctors have been keen to point out that the two men have met six times at various summits, and that Canada's competent ambassador in Washington is the prime minister's nephew. Anyway, if there is ice, Mr Clinton is breaking it with a visit to the Canadian capital on February 23rd and 24th.
Such coolness as there is derives from fish and country music. Canada's west-coast fishermen are suffering from the mysterious non-appearance last year of 3m sockeye salmon that were due to spawn in the Fraser river system, and are sharply watching American vessels that have fished out stocks off Washington and Oregon. The country-music videos are part of an intricate free-trade argument, stirred up (Canadians suspect) by Mickey Kantor, America's trade representative.
It began when Canada's broadcasting regulators removed a station owned by Westinghouse, an American firm, from the list of authorised cable services, licensing a new Canadian network in its place. The Americans have long resented the exclusion of "cultural products", their second-largest export, from their free-trade agreement with Canada. In retaliation, Canadian videos are being dropped from a station in Nashville that boasts some 40m viewers..
On sovereignty for Quebec, Mr Clinton will need to pick his words carefully. Lucien Bouchard, chief of the separatist Bloc Quebecois, will meet the president in his capacity as leader of the opposition in the federal parliament. Mr Bouchard has just lost a leg to a rare infection, and has everybody's sympathy. Back at work, he hopes to get Mr Clinton's assurance of gentle treatment for an independent Quebec in renegotiating treaties, including the one on free trade.
The Bloc Quebecois has been careful not to annoy the Americans. It has unswervingly opposed any resolutions in the House of Commons that might upset them, including one to ban the testing of cruise missiles over Canada, and another to restore full trade and aid with Cuba. The Bloc began to grumble only when Mr Clinton's treasury proposed raising some $400m a year by charging people crossing the undefended border. Trade would be free, but movement expensive; that's unfriendly.

text:
OTTAWA
THE Quebec separatist movement has fallen into disarray, and the threat that the province might this year vote itself out of the Canadian federation is on the wane. It is a testing moment for the leader of the Parti Quebecois (PQ), Jacques Parizeau--and one of the testers is his own ally in the federal Parliament, Lucien Bouchard.
Mr Parizeau was elected premier of Quebec last September. He mapped out a short, swift route to independence for the province, starting with a provincial referendum before Quebec's "national" day on June 24th this year. But on April 5th Mr Parizeau glumly announced that the referendum was to be postponed until the autumn; Quebec's people were not ready for independence. Two days later, Mr Bouchard, whose Bloc Quebecois (BQ) members are the largest opposition group in the federal Parliament, suggested at his party's convention that the referendum might be put off until as late as 1999--the final year of the PQ's provincial mandate--if that would ensure its success. Mr Bouchard went on to speak of a bold new vision, of Canada and Quebec being associated like countries in the European Union. Mr Parizeau at once retorted that he would insist on the referendum being held this year. Further questioning of Mr Bouchard left reporters in doubt whether, in those circumstances, he would lead his BQ troops into wholehearted support of his provincial ally's campaign.
Mr Bouchard has always been leery of a rushed referendum; Mr Parizeau remembers how the PQ left a previous referendum until the fourth year of its then mandate, 1980, and lost. The longer it waits, the less popular a government becomes, he fears.
His trouble is that his energetic efforts to stoke up enthusiasm for independence have not set Quebec afire. The 15 commissions that toured every corner of the province in February to do this job under the guise of hearing the people's views had to report that they heard little interest in independence but plenty of comment on local problems. Even Quebec's actors and singers, once so active in the cause of sovereignty, had lost their passion.
Opinion polls have given Mr Parizeau no comfort either. Backing for sovereignty has not risen above 45% among Quebeckers, despite the return to active politics of the popular Mr Bouchard, after losing a leg to bacterial infection. To make things worse, Bernard Landry, the province's deputy premier, who has a military background, has told Mr Parizeau he has no wish to be "second-in-command of the Light Brigade".
The federal Liberal government under Jean Chretien has so far played a waiting game, successfully. It won a useful by-election against the BQ in February, and has brought an influential Quebecker, Lucienne Robillard, into a cabinet already dominated by men from that province. Mr Chretien (he is one of them) has left it to independent researchers to publish tracts exposing the fallacies in the PQ's draft legislation. Among the PQ's promises are an assurance that an independent Quebec would have no problem keeping a common currency with the rest of Canada, and another pledging dual nationality for its citizens.
Mr Chretien's tactics are to goad Mr Parizeau into keeping his promise of an early referendum on a straightforward question, while keeping his own fingers crossed that meanwhile no bigot stamps on Quebec's fleur-de-lys flag or otherwise inflames opinion there. But he has given no hint of any new deal for Quebec as a reward for rejecting sovereignty; and, as Mr Parizeau argued, he is unlikely to be excited by the European Union model. Some time this year, Mr Chretien will have to offer some alternative to the present version of federalism. Meanwhile, he can enjoy watching Mr Parizeau dancing on hot coals.

He mapped out a short , swift route to independence for the province , starting with a provincial referendum before Quebec 's " national " day on June 24th this year . But on April 5th Mr Parizeau glumly announced that the referendum was to be postponed until the autumn ; Quebec 's people were not ready for independence . Two days later , Mr Bouchard , whose Bloc Quebecois ( BQ ) members are the largest opposition group in the federal Parliament , suggested at his party 's convention that the referendum might be put off until as late as 1999 - -the final year of the PQ 's provincial mandate -- if that would ensure its success . Mr Bouchard went on to speak of a bold new vision , of Canada and Quebec being associated like countries in the European Union . Mr Parizeau at once retorted that he would insist on the referendum being held this year . Further questioning of Mr Bouchard left reporters in doubt whether , in those circumstances , he would lead his BQ troops into wholehearted support of his provincial ally 's campaign . 
 Mr Bouchard has always been leery of a rushed referendum ; Mr Parizeau remembers how the PQ left a previous referendum until the fourth year of its then mandate , 1980 , and lost . The longer it waits , the less popular a government becomes , he fears .

The 15 commissions that toured every corner of the province in February to do this job under the guise of hearing the people 's views had to report that they heard little interest in independence but plenty of comment on local problems . Jean Chretien won a useful by - election against the BQ in February , and has brought an influential Quebecker , Lucienne Robillard , into a cabinet already dominated by men from that province . Mr Chretien ( he is one of them ) has left it to independent researchers to publish tracts exposing the fallacies in the PQ 's draft legislation . Among the PQ 's promises are an assurance that an independent Quebec would have no problem keeping a common currency with the rest of Canada , and another pledging dual nationality for its citizens .

text:
OTTAWA
AT LAST Quebec's 5m voters know when they will be invited to vote on "sovereignty". Jacques Parizeau, leader of the province's separatist Parti Quebecois (PQ) government, this week confirmed the "probable" date, October 30th, of his planned referendum. But what question, exactly, will the voters be asked? That will be made public by mid-September--and a trifle less than exact it looks likely to be.
The last PQ referendum--lost, in 1980, by 60% to 40%--talked off negotiating "sovereignty-association" with the rest of Canada, The new one will propose a declaration of sovereignty plus an offer promptly to negotiate, you guessed, association, political and economic. It was on this basis that Mr Parizeau and his alley in the federal parliament, Lucien Bouchard, in June won the backing of Mario Dumont, a former Liberal, whose new Action Democratique du Quebec took 6-1/2% of the vote in last year's provincial election. With his votes, the separatists reckon, they would win, and opinion polls suggest they are right.
There's a problem, though. After a divorce, would the rest of Canada agree to shack up again? Mr Parizeau used the annual meeting of the ten provincial premiers on August 24th to advance his argument that negotiating such a deal would not be difficult. He turned up proclaiming free trade, stayed for a session on removing interprovincial barriers to it, told journalists there had been "an evolution" in the premiers' thinking about economic links with an independent Quebec, and went home.
The evolution, in fact, was a decision not to say explicitly in their communique that the inter-provincial trade agreement would not apply to an independent Quebec. So irritated were the others by Mr Parizeau's version that, after he left, they toughened the wording to specify that the deal applied only to Canadian provinces and territories. Even so, he did well. He can tell his voters that only sovereignty will persuade anglophone hardliners to come to terms.
The federalists' tactic has been to argue that Canada is a splendid country to live in, which no sensible Quebecker would want to leave. But now they are shifting a little in response to separatist rhetoric about voting for change. Daniel Johnson, who as Liberal leader in Quebec heads the No campaign, has said that, if he again became premier, he would call for recognition of Quebec as "a distinct society", with a veto over Canadian constitutional change; terms revived from the Meech Lake accord aborted in 1990. The federal Prime minister, Jean Chretien, who has shown his distaste for any return to the quagmire of constitutional talks, nonetheless closed ranks with him, allowing that in 1997 the premiers would review the (1982) constitution. Since a review after 15 years was built into it, this was hardly new; but some still saw it as a concession.
When the campaign proper begins, the federalist line is likely to toughen, with reminders of Mr Parizeau's remark in July to a couple of European ambassadors that, once a majority of Quebeckers vote Yes, they will be "like lobsters in a trap"--that is, that if negotiations for association were to fail, he would take the province to independence without further consultation.
Meanwhile, Mr Parizeau faces a reminder that there are others in his province who can claim that theirs is a distinct society: the Cree Indians and the Inuit of northern Quebec, numbering about 18,000. Their traditional territory, by area one-third of the province, was attached to Quebec only in 1912. They intend to hold their own votes on self-determination and on remaining part of Canada just before Mr Parizeau's referendum. In a similar vote in 1980, the Inuit voted 87% against separation from Canada. They hope a repetition of that vote will aid Mr Parizeau's opponents.
