text:
THERE are anxious faces in Ottawa as the final stage of the referendum campaign on Quebec sovereignty starts. For the separatist Jacques Parizeau, it has been a nonstop campaign since his Pari Quebecois (PQ) won the provincial election a year ago. By the time he tabled the referendum question and the sovereignty bill, complete with a lengthy and (above) splendidly florid preamble, in Quebec's legislature on September 7th, the separatists had picked up enough momentum to have a slight lead in opinion polls. Not many Canadians really believe Quebeckers will vote, on October 30th, to separate. But suppose they do?
Canada's Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien, refuses to answer hypothetical questions, merely warning Quebec's 4.9m voters that a Yes vote would be "a one-way ticket to separation".. Does that mean the federal government would spurn the detailed offer of political and economic "parnership" even now beings prepared by Quebec officials for negotiation in the (probably) 12 months before a declaration of sovereignty would take effet? The offer, promised in the refrendum question, is the carrot with which Mr Parizeau hopes to win over the "soft nationalists" who last autumn voted for Mario Dumont's newly minted party, Action Democratique du Quebec, and who could swing the day.
The answer is that Mr Chretien has decided the best tactic is to keep the choice as stark and simple as possible. A large minority of those who tell pollsters they expect to vote Yes believe Quebec will still be part of Canada, with a common citizenship and currency but with political clout equal to the other nine provinces combined. The federalists aim to sweep away this confused wishfulness without being so native as to reinforce the PQ argument that it and its allies are the party of change, while Ottawa stands merely for the status quo.
So the federalists will focus on the beneficial changes in Quebec since an earlier "sovereignty-association" vote was taken (and defeated) in 1980: economic power moving solidly into the hands of francophone firms, business administration graduates flooding the province, an increased sense of security over the French language, control over immigration and many other administrative powers shifting from Ottawa. The trouble is that this quiet evolution, while more meaningful, is less headline-catching than struggles over constitutional change. If Mr Chretien were to promise Quebeckers a new deal as a reward for voting No--as Pierre Trudeau did in 1980--he would not be believed; two constitutional accords have already, in the end, come to nothing. So he has ignored the call for minor constitutional changes from Daniel Johnson, leader of Quebec's Liberals, who in theory heads the No campaign.
Federalists find comfort in the fact, proven several times in Canada, that most of the don't knows or won't says in opinion polls, in the end vote--if they vote at all--for what is familiar. This seems especially true of women, who make up the majority of the 15% of Quebec voters still in this category. Both sides have placed women ministers in the forefront of their battle-line, to rally these important waverers; Mr Chretien went to the length of handing a plum ambassadorial post to an obscure Montreal member of Parliament in order to open a seat for his champion, Lucienne Robillard.
Mr Parizeau has a key supporter in the 25-year-old, ex-Liberal Mr Dumont, a man right in the middle of the age-group that hardly realises the changes benefiting Quebec since 1980 and likeliest to favour radical change, however ill-defined. Meanwhile, Lucien Bouchard, leader of the Bloc Quebecois in the federal parliament, is warning federalists that the separatists will never give up, even if they lose this time. He must be calculating that older folk, weary of this debate, will shift to his camp alongside eager youth. A rough battle lies ahead.

text:
VANCOUVER--WITH three weeks to go before Quebec votes on whether or not to split the country apart, western Canada has shown little interest. Do its people--nearly all of them English-speakers--imply not care?
They do, in fact, care deeply. But most of them reckon that the outcome on October 30th will be about the same as in 1980, when Quebeckers rejected a complex notion called "sovereignty-association" by 60% to 40%. Opinion polls in Quebec, the west knows, are closer than that today, but still give the federalists a lead: the latest poll found 55% saying No to separation against 45% saying Yes.
For more than 30 years Quebec nationalists have brandished the threat of secession, and westerners are weary of it. Rafe Mair, a Vancouver radio talk-show host, sums up their response: "We want Quebeckers to make up their goddamn minds once and for all: in or out." The separatists' new version--sovereignty plus a commitment to negotiate what they now call "partnership"--cuts no ice in the west.
So if Quebec does decide to separate, westerners say let it go. They believe that more than enough has been done to placate Quebec nationalism: from official bilingualism to immigration. A separate Quebec would suffer a harsh drop in living standards, say various economic studies, but, after a brief setback, the rest of Canada would get by nicely.
Their calm screens the deep discontent that the western provinces--Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia--feel about the federal government's favouritism towards Quebec. "Western Canada sees Quebec as the spoilt child of confederation," says Angus Reid, a national opinion pollster. There have been regular flare-ups at the way Quebec is given more than its share of defence contracts, public works, federal programmes and institutions; and unequal administrative and financial arrangements. Westerners want no more attempts to buy off separatism.
Witness a confrontation in Parliament on September 19th. The prime minister, Jean Chretien, expected a clash with the separatist Bloc Quebecois. What he got was one with the hard western "either in or out" line of the federalist Reform Party, all but one of whose 52 seats are from the west. How would the government interpret Quebec's vote? Mr Chretien had earlier said a Yes vote would be "a one-way ticket to separation." Later he hedged, saying there is "no mechanism in the constitution for separation." So what did he mean, asked Reform's leader, Preston Manning, bluntly: let him "state unequivocally" that a majority, be it of just one vote, in the referendum would mean that Quebec was on its way out.
Mr Chretien's reply, that he would not necessarily be bound by a narrow Yes victory, dismayed westerners. Those--which means most--who want Quebec to stay, fear this sort of dithering may encourage Quebec's "soft nationalists" to believe that even a Yes majority would not real mean separation, merely serve as a bigger lever to prise still more concessions from the federal government. And that, a new move in the old game, is almost as unacceptable to the west as sovereignty-partnership.
A Canada-Quebec partnership may be an appealing idea to many Quebeckers, especially the soft nationalists. But 67% of English-speaking Canadians oppose, it, according to one poll. All four western provincial premiers have flatly rejected the idea that a sovereign Quebec should continue to enjoy the full benefits of inter-provincial free trade.
Ironically, western hardliners may yet prove Quebec's allies--and vice versa. They want more power decentralised to the provinces. Quebec may vote firmly to stay inside, but its nationalism will not go away. Centre and provinces alike will have to take a fresh look at the overall balance of power.
But there is a problem. To most French-speakers today's Canada consists of two societies, which should be treated as equal (though they are not); hence Quebec, as the voice of the French-speaking society, has a right of veto. To most English-speakers, that is nonsense: Canada consists of ten provinces, not of equal weight but of equal status, each entitled to the same rights and powers as others, not less--but not more. These rival views have bedevilled past constitutional negotiations. Reconciling them will be no easier this time.

text:
Limbo land
Lamberto Dini, Italy's prime minister, offered to resin by the end of the year to avoid defeat in a no-confidence vote brought by his predecessor, Silvio Berlusconi.
Russia's Boris Yeltsin said he would sack his foreign minister, Andrei Kozyrev -- and then said he would unsack him and appoint a new deputy instead. Mr Yeltsin himself was back in hospital with heart problems.
State elections in Berlin were a disaster for the opposition Social Democrats. They polled 23% of the vote, their worst result for 50 years in a city that was once a stronghold. The Greens and the former communist PDS did well.
Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin said they agreed that Russian troops would serve as part of a peacekeeping force in Bosnia; their defence ministers discussed who should command them. Germany approved a plan to send troops to join the peacekeeping contingent.
Russia's upper house voted to lift sanctions on Serbia.
NATO began searching for a new secretary-general after Willy Claes resigned in the wake of a bribery scandal. He claimed innocence.
The Spanish parliament rejected the government's austerity budget for 1996, bringing an election nearer, and pushing into the distance Spain's faint hope of joining EMU by 1999.
Forty-three parties registered for Russia's forthcoming parliamentary election. Eighty-seven candidates are either under criminal investigation or have been convicted.
Jacques Chirac said he would cut the number of French nuclear tests from eight to "probably" six. The European Commission declared there were no grounds for legal action over the tests.
What a laugh
World leaders duly celebrated the UN's 50th birthday, promising that the next century would see an organisation properly "equipped, financed and structured". They also had meetings with each other, except for President Chirac of France and President Zeroual of Algeria, who cancelled theirs. Boris Yeltsin gave President Clinton the giggles by being rude to journalists at a news conference.
Syria took in some of the Palestinians stranded after being thrown out of Libya. Colonel Qaddafi told a news conference he would not expel any more for the moment.
President Henri Konan Bedie of Cote d'Ivoire received at least 96% of votes in an election boycotted by the main opposition parties.
Tanzania's ruling party was declared the winner of the disputed election in Zanzibar. Both the ruling party and the opposition Civic United Forum, which wants more autonomy for the island, challenged the electoral count.
Moments of truth
Senate and House began to thrash out their differences on welfare reform in Washington, and the two chambers' Republicans were due to see if they could agree on tax cuts and balancing the budget. Bill Clinton said taxes were raised too much in 1993.
Colin Powell beat all others on offer, in an opinion poll, as the presidential favourite of Republicans in bellwether New Hampshire.
Murders within families, a third of all murders in 1965, were only a tenth in 1992. The growth of random violence in the United States is shown by Justice Department figures which suggest that half of all murders may now be committed by strangers.
Both houses of Congress said that the American embassy in Israel should be moved to Jerusalem by 1999.
With polls on the October 30th referendum showing a swing to the Quebec separatists, and markets reacting accordingly, Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, swung into the fray with a new offer: constitutional change is possible, and Quebec would have a right of veto on matters affecting it.
Power play
President Jiang Zemin attacked "certain big powers" that criticised China under the cover of "democracy" and "human rights". His uncompromising remarks at the UN cast a shadow over his meeting with Bill Clinton, which had been expected to ease Chinese-American relations.
Sri Lankan government forces were within 8km (five miles) of Jaffna town, headquarters of the island's Tier separatists. The government aims to end the 12-year civil war in which more than 50,000 people have died. Separatist guerrillas went on the rampage, killing many villagers.
The trial of Shoko Asaharu, the Japanese cult leader accused of planning gas attacks on the Tokyo subway, was postponed when Mr Asahara fired his lawyer just before the trial's opening session.
A major military exercise by South Korean and American forces was held up when 5,000 soldiers were deployed to hunt down "North Korean spies". One was caught, but others were said to have "infiltrated".

text:
Quebec's separatists will succeed next time
THE noes had it this week, so Canada escapes dismemberment. But for how long? Defeated by little more than 1% of the vote this time, the separatists who want to make Quebec an independent French-speaking country will be trying again before long. It is hard to see how they can be bought off. This week's referendum was far from being an affirmation of Canadian unity, and resolves nothing (see page 45).
The separatists are already looking forward to a fresh attempt. Federalists wearily accept that the only way to avoid that is change. But what change, achieved how? Further loosening of the federal government's already loose control, say some of the nine other provinces. But each has its own idea of what that means. During the campaign, Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, offered Quebec formal recognition as a "distinct society", but this no loner satisfies the separatists: Quebeckers are "a people", they say. He also offered Quebec a veto over constitutional change affecting it. That Quebec would like, but the rest of Canada probably would not.
The central difficulty is that most French-speaking Quebeckers feel more affection for Quebec than they do for Canada and, if many of them still vote to stay in Canada, they do so more out of a fear of the unknown than of loyalty to any concept of Canadianism. Moreover, it is hard to see how greater loyalty to such a concept could be fostered, least of all by weakening the federal arrangements of what is already the loosest federation in the world.
The attempt has, after all, been made before. Much of the past ten years has been devoted to drawing up a constitution that both Quebec and the rest of Canada could live with. At one time, in 1987, it looked as though agreement had been reached. But in the event two provinces failed to ratify the deal, and Quebec, which had voted 60-40% to stay in Canada in a referendum in 1980, started to consider separation with renewed interest. Another effort at constitution-making foundered in 1992, after Canada-wide voting showed that Quebec thought it had been offered too little while many in the rest of Canada thought it had been offered too much.
Few are willing to go down this tortuous path again. The western-based Reform Party has a sweeping project whereby, mostly through changes of laws, not the constitution, the federal government would move out of many fields entirely, not least language. But that would not meet separatist demands: laws can always be changed back again. Still less would mere administrative change. The Parliament in Ottawa might agree, say, to hand over to the provinces manpower training, another issue that excites Quebeckers--until it changed its mind again.
The bosom still heaves
All the evidence suggests that Quebec's unhappiness derives not from bad or even remote government but from the desire of a French-speaking people to run their own country. When the Earl of Durham was sent from England in 1838 to investigate grievances in Canada, he "expected to find a contest between a government and a people"; instead, he found "two nations warring in the bosom of a single state". They are still warring, and for the same reason: the French-speakers want to run their own show. Jacques Parizeau, Quebec's separatist premier, admitted as much this week when he put part of the blame for the vote's defeat upon "the ethnic vote". Like many a gaffe--he announced his resignation soon after--it was true: 60% of French-speakers want to secede, but that desire is shared by only a handful of Quebec's (varied) minorities.
Though everyone heroically denies it, it is not Quebec that is distinct, but its French-speakers, and they are growing more so. Nationalism in Quebec is rising, especially among the young. In a few years' time, the separatists will probably win, especially if the non-French-speaking minority votes with its feet in the meantime. Unless hearts change all across the country on a hue scale, Canada has been spared break-up on this occasion only to prepare for it on the next.

text:
THE blue-and-white banners waved, the chanteurs sang their throats out against les federastes, the balloons soared, the placards bounced like demented bedsprings. Then everything, slowly, went flat. The 8,000, mostly young, French-speakers packed to the roof of Quebec city's ice-hockey arena shifted from thunderous triumph to unease, alarm, quiet gloom, at last defiant despair. As a nail-bitten evening ended on October 30th, Quebec, by one percentage point in a hue 94% turnout, had voted to stay with Canada and--as these separatists saw it--against itself.
Or rather, some not-quite Quebeckers had. A bitter premier, Jacques Parizeau, explained his defeat: "money 
big business, fairly solidly against him
 and the ethnic vote". By this he meant the province's 10% of immigrants, who mostly prefer English to French as their adopted tongue (even Montreal's many Haitians and Lebanese do not vote separatist). Plus, though Mr Parizeau did not quite say it, the slightly fewer native English-speakers who--they thought--are an accepted part of Quebec society.
Next day, as the defeated Mr Parizeau announced that at the end of the legislative session he would step down from the leadership of his Parti Quebecois (PQ) the province's premiership and its "national" assembly, he apologised for this much jumped-on gaffe. But he insisted that, albeit ill-expressed, it was true. So it is. And this continuing, indeed widening, gap between Quebec's four-fifths majority of French-speakers and the rest--which also means the rest of Canada--explains what has hit that country since the referendum campaign began. It also explains the conundrum that the federal government and the nine other provinces now face: in brief, what is now to be done?
The separatists will be back, and soon; they made that repeatedly plain this week. They have a litany of economic complaints. But their real ones are linguistic: they want total control of Quebec's language law, especially as applied to schools, and of immigration (cosmopolitan Montreal island is less than two-thirds French-speaking). But even if they are given all that, they have the unanswerable demand of un peuple: we want un pays, a country.
Separation has been on the way for decades. To go no further back, it is seven years since Mr Parizeau came to the top of the PQ. Since then, two attempts to satisfy Quebec's constitutional demands (made by Quebec's Liberals, not the PQ) have failed--in essence, because too many of Canada's English-speakers would not wear them. In 1990, Lucien Bouchard, having left the federal cabinet, formed the Bloc Quebecois to fight elections at federal level and in October 1993 led it to a remarkable success, second only to the federal Liberals. Eleven months later it was Mr Parizeau's turn, as he swept the local Liberals out of power in Quebec.
Economics played its part in both elections. But at the root was resurgent French-speaking nationalism, helped in Mr Parizeau's case by a split among Quebec's Liberals, when some walked out to form the soft-nationalist Action Dmocratique party, now led by a 25-year-old, Mario Dumont. "English" Canada understood with its head, maybe, what was going on, but not with its heart. It still does not. The referendum campaign has been full of Anglo astonishment that anyone could want to part from a country that is, cliche of the season, "the envy of the world". When Messrs Parizeau, Bouchard and Dumont got together in June to agree on a "soft" referendum question--not a straight split from Canada, but one that would follow an attempt to negotiate a future partnership--federalist alarm bells should have been ringing. They were not.
Until early last month, this complacency seemed justified. The economic risks of separation looked large, even in the separatists' calculations, let alone the federalists' (the federal finance minister at one point dreamed up a million job losses for Quebec). Canada's Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien, basically decided to let the separatists cut their own throats.
Monday's cliff-hanger showed how wrong he had been. Three weeks earlier Mr Parizeau had stepped aside to let the separatist campaign be led by the far more popular Mr Bouchard, whose charisma is such that little old Quebecoises have been seen eager just to touch the man who last winter escaped--minus a leg--from flesh-eating bacteria. From that moment the campaign, and the opinion polls, changed. Why? Because Mr Bouchard put his side's economic calculus into the cupboard and took out of it the big French drum.
He is good at lofty emotion, brilliant at rancour, Mr Bouchard. By ill chance for Canada, Mr Chretien is a French-speaker from Quebec but hated by many there for his alleged part in ancient, and some more recent, political wrong. Last week, when he belatedly addressed a television appeal to Quebeckershis privilege as prime minister--and rashly gave Mr Bouchard equal time immediately after him, the separatist tore into, not his arguments, but his treachery towards his own province and towards Rene Levesque, the separatists' great myth-figure, nearly 15 years ago. Time stops for nationalist history.
This week, having declared before the vote that he did not want any of those "moral victories that are really defeats", Mr Bouchard was defiant when he got just that: the fight would go on. Haling, compromise? Forget it. Even Mr Parizeau's announcement of his retirement was not that of a beaten man. I am passing on the torch, he said, in effect, to a new generation. We lost, just as Levesque lost an earlier referendum in 1980, but look how much round we've made: from 40% to almost 50%. And we won a large majority (about 60% in fact) of Quebec's French-speakers. A la prochaine (to the next time), as Levesque famously said after that earlier defeat.
Mr Parizeau lamented that the separatist cause had made no inroads among English- and other speakers. But his successor--probably Mr Bouchard--does not need to win over those who will not be won. All he needs (maybe in a fresh referendum, quite soon) is to swing another 5% of his own kind behind him. And it will be French drum and horn, and defiance of Ottawa and of le Canada anglais, that do it, not dusty economics or even jobs.
This is why some premiers of English-speaking provinces were running around this week with unusual phrases on their lips. "We have heard you, we will work with you," Alberta's Ralph Klein told Quebec. It is not that these men suddenly love Quebec, they don't. Even the huge Montreal love-in on October 27th, to which non-Quebeckers poured in, some from the Pacific coast even, was not the true voice of Anglo Canada: much of it is fed to the back teeth with Quebec. But what the campaign, and the vote, have shown is that most Canadians do in fact feel for Canada, and have suddenly understood that it really could fall apart.
The provincial premiers reflect that feeling. Not perhaps as sincerely as their voters, since love of Canada is almost equalled by their desire to get Ottawa out of their provincial hair. Hence the cry on all sides for change, to keep Quebec in--for Canada's sake, not its own--and Ottawa out. But it has to be added that no one is volunteering for a third constitutional marathon, and that cries for change rang loudly after the previous Quebec referendum; producing, in the end, damn all. asdklgj;

text:
FEDERALISTS and separatists were both still licking their wounds this week, after the knife-edge result of the Quebec referendum on October 30th. And neither side knows where to go from here.
For the moment, it is the separatists-defeated only by one percentage point, but still defeated-who are in more obvious disarray. Having lost, Jacques Parizeau, the province's Parti Quebecois premier, brought the roof down on himself on referendum night: appalling many even of his own supporters, he blurted out on television that it was "the ethnic vote" that had cost them victory. Next day, doubly battered, he announced he would retire before the end of December-only for his deputy, Bernard Landry, to cast similar anti-minority aspersions, publicly, in a hotel foyer, on a Mexican-born woman with 20 years of residence in Quebec. Mr Landry, who was also minister for immigration and the "cultural communities" (those troublesome ethnics) promptly lost that portfolio and maybe any chance he had of the premiership with it.
In contrast, Mr Parizeau promoted another credible contender, Pauline Marois, who as head of Quebec's Treasury Board has negotiated nimbly with the trade unions. She got the finance ministry; and Mr Parizeau went further in suggesting that the next premier might well be a woman.
And what about Lucien Bouchard, the separatist hero of the campaign, who injected belated passion into what seemed a lost cause and brought it to the brink of victory? Leader of the Bloc Quebecois in the federal parliament, he is most separatists' favoured successor to Mr Parizeau. Mr Landry, for one, had said he would not dream of standing in Mr Bouchard's way. But the hero, having said he needed some days to mull over his future, retired to his tent-a family holiday of three weeks.
One consideration for him is that, were he to leave the federal parliament, he would bring his party's numbers there down-for a time-to 52, level with the right-wing Reform Party, and so might endanger the privileges it now enjoys as the main opposition party. A larger thought for Mr Bouchard may be his family. His Californian wife is not famously addicted to the separatist cause, and she may worry about his health. Their two small sons, says Mr Bouchard, by now spit at the very word "referendum".
Possibly a strategy is being negotiated, in which Mrs Marois will command the fort for a year or two, until Mr Bouchard returns from an effective guerrilla campaign in Ottawa to lead the Parti Quebecois to victory in a fresh provincial election on a platform of separation. A victory, be it said, that is by no means guaranteed: whoever runs Quebec for the coming years will have to take a sharp knife to public spending.
As for the federalists, on the face of things they should be happy. After all, with a last-minute show of passion for Canada, they staved off its disintegration. But only just, and what follows? Quebec's Frenchspeakers-four-fifths of its electorate-voted 60-40 for independence last week. How are they to be won over? Can they really be satisfied with some changes to the Canadian constitution and a few more powers devolved to Quebec's provincial assembly?
The federal prime minister, Jean Chretien, has told a gathering of his Liberal faithful that he is fed up with destabilising talk of further referendums, hinting that he might use federal powers to disallow any Quebec legislation arranging for one. But has he any positive strategy? If so, he is showing little sign of it. Ministers have been busy in Parliament fighting off the Reform Party, which-though it has its own plan for drastic decentralisation-demands that they promise to make no special deal with Quebec (an odd demand, given that Canadian federalism has evolved through just such deals with various provinces). Meanwhile, that old warrior Pierre Trudeau--the former prime minister whose 1982 "patriation" (from Britain) of the Canadian constitution, over Quebec's head, has fired much subsequent separatist ardour-on November 6th emerged from his silence during the referendum campaign. He attacked Mr Bouchard for falsifying the history of those days, and warned his countrymen that further decentralisation would destroy what remains of a united Canada. Which, true or false, does not answer the questions facing Mr Chretien. Nor yet--probably the reverse-will the proposed constitutional pow-wow of all provincial premiers (but not the federal one) which those of the four western provinces this week agreed to push ahead with.
In the absence of imaginative (or even conciliatory) political leadership, ordinary Canadians are preparing to fill the vacuum. Having mobilised for the great patriotic rally in Montreal on October 27th that may just have swung the balance to the federalist side, they want now to launch a thoroughgoing national debate to overhaul Canada.
Some argue for an old-fashioned constituent assembly. The head of a small research institute, Andrew Cardozo, is building support for a more open and less confrontational dialogue on the Internet. Can people power and new technology rescue Canada, as old politicians seemingly cannot? Perhaps it was symbolic that when a 34-yearold French-speaker from Montreal broke into the prime minister's Ottawa home last Saturday night, it was Aline Chretien who slammed a door on the knife-wielding intruder, while her husband lay fast asleep.

Perhaps it was symbolic that when a 34 - yearold French - speaker from Montreal broke into Jean Chretien's Ottawa home last Saturday night , it was Jean Chretien who slammed a door on the knife - wielding intruder , while Jean Chretien's husband lay fast asleep .

text:
CANADA may have less than two years to pick itself up from the scare it got on October 30th, when Quebec's voters all but gave their provincial government approval to declare independence. Can those who value the country as it now is pull themselves together enough in that time to defeat a renewed separatist challenge?
That is the question now posed to them by Lucien Bouchard, whose honeyed tongue lifted the separatist campaign to within a whisker of victory in Quebec's referendum last month. Now leader of the federal-level Bloc Quebecoi, he announced this week that he would resign his seat in the federal parliament and offer himself as leader of the provincial Parti Quebecois (PQ) and thus as premier of Quebec.
The two posts will soon be left vacant by Jacques Parizeau, who announced his decision to that effect on the morrow of the separatists' defeat in the referendum. Though it took Mr Bouchard a three-week holiday to make up his mind--his wife is clearly less than thrilled--the job is his for the asking. No one of substance in the PQ is expected to stand against him. He will either win by acclaim of the party's national council on January l2th, or, if, some dark horse should trot in sight, be elected leader on February 25th. The militants in the PQ cabinet see him as the one person who can keep up the momentum toward sovereignty (Quebec-speak for "independence"; the still more alarming word "separation" is spoken only behind closed doors).
Mr Bouchard's first words as their soonto-be leader will have pleased his future followers. Asked if there was any possible deal Ottawa might offer that would keep Quebec in Canada, he replied, "Not possibly. I am a sovereigntist."
His plan, he said, was to govern Quebec so as to create jobs and improve the economy, at the same time improving the province's finances (through spending cuts, he said, rather than tax increases). Meanwhile he would wait and see what Ottawa and the rest of Canada would try to do about the constitution. Brought in in 1982, it is due, mandatorily, for review by April 1997. Mr Bouchard does not expect the review to produce "anything significant"; nor, he said, would he take part in preliminary talks.
In sum, he looks for nothing and will ask for nothing. And in time, he said, though he would not be drawn on exactly when, he will put a fresh referendum to Quebec's 5m voters "at the right time--a winning one".
Some federalists argue that that time will never come. Separatism, they say, has peaked. Mr Bouchard's halo will be tarnished by the unpopular measures that he will have to take to reduce Quebec's hefty budget deficit. The Bloc's MPS in Ottawa will be far less effective without his leadership, and may even be supplanted as the leading opposition party by the right-wing, western-based Reform Party. Though the Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien, soon after Mr Bouchard's announcement said that constitutional change was not his first priority, his government will show it has shed its near-fatal complacency and produce plans to revamp the federal structure. And Canadians generally have been so stirred by their near escape from fragmentation that they will accept the radical changes Mr Chretien has hinted at. So, at least, say Canada's optimists.
From Quebec, Jean Charest, a Conservative member of the federal parliament who tumed out to be the separatists' most effective adversary during the referendum, foresees a different future. He views Mr Bouchard as an opportunist and a demagogue, without sense of responsibility. He expects Quebec's new premier to blame all the province's ills on Ottawa-especially after another tough federal budget next spring-and call an early provincial election to establish his own mandate. It would then be just a short step to sovereignty.

text:
Implementing peace
 The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, said he supports the peace agreement worked out in Dayton. NATO'S military committee agreed on an operational plan for its peaceenforcing soldiers in Bosnia. Germany said it would send 4,000 men. President Clinton began trying to persuade a reluctant Congress to send troops.
Serbia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, sidelined three long-serving lieutenants, including Mihailo Markovic and Borislav Jovic, who were co-founders of the ruling Socialist Party.
After months of no progress, John Major, the British prime minister, and John Bruton, his Irish counterpart, declared a target date of February for all-party talks on the future of Northern Ireland. The two held a finely timed summit only hours before President Clinton arrived for a visit to Britain and Ireland.
Finance ministers of the European Union failed to agree on a cut-off date for choosing which countries had qualified for economic and monetary union. They agreed to discuss a German proposal to fine countries which ran excessive budget deficits after EMU. The EU'S transport commissioner, Neil Kinnock, said he thought EMU could not be implemented by 1999 as planned.
The Greek prime minister, Andreas Papandreou, remained critically ill in hospital.
Opinion polls in Russia found that the popularity of the Communist Party is falling, for the first time in 18 months.
As Belarus went to the polls to fill parliamentary seats left vacant in the general election last May, the country's president, Alexander Lukashenka, told a German newspaper that "not everything that was connected to a certain Adolf Hitler was bad."
By the narrowest of margins, Irish voters agreed in a referendum to a lifting of the constitutional ban on divorce. The anti-divorce lobby is to challenge the result.
France endured a series of public protests and strikes, especially in the railways.
The Czech Republic joined the OECD.
The Slovak president signed a controversial language law making Slovak the only official language and restricting the use of others in public.
Taking aim
 President Mandela said South Africa might take action against Shell because the oil company failed to apply pressure to the Nigerian government over the recent executions of nine activists. Nigeria retorted that Mr Mandela was a tool of western countries.
A leading member of F.W. de Klerk's National Party called President Mandela a "con artist", and attacked the govemment for prosecuting former senior members of the armed forces for war crimes.
Kenyan police arrested several Rwandans, including two bishops, after the Rwandan government accused Kenya of protecting exiles responsible for last year's genocide.
In a more peaceful election than the presidential one in October, Cote d'Ivoire's ruling Democratic Party, led by Henri Konan-Bedie, won 147 of 175 seats in an election for the National Assembly.
More than 4,000 candidates competed for the 444 seats in Egypt's parliament. The government party was assured of victory even before it had arrested several candidates and supporters of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood.
Hizbullah's guerrillas launched a rocket attack on northern Israel in response, it said, to Israeli aggression.
Korea's can of worms
 South Korea's constitutional court opened the way for the prosecution of two former presidents, Roh Tae Woo and Chun Doo Hwan, for their part in a coup in 1979 and a subsequent massacre of civilians.
Malaysia's ruling United Malay National Organisation said there would be no contest for the leadership of the party, and hence of the country, at UMNO'S next national convention. The prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, said foreign journalists had tried to destabilise the country by stirring up rumours.
Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the democratic opposition in Myanmar, pulled her party out of a constitutional convention controlled by the ruling military junta.
China named a six-year-old boy as the new Panchen Lama, the second most holy figure in Tibetan Buddhism. The Chinese decision was a direct challenge to the Dalai Lama, the exiled leader of the Tibetan Buddhists, who earlier this year blessed another six-year-old as Panchen Lama.
Pacifying Quebec
 Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, announced plans to head off separatism in Quebec: parliamentary recognition of it as a "distinct society" and of its rightoffered to Ontario, the west and the Atlantic provincesto a veto on constitutional change. Far too little, said the separatists; too much said most others.
Newt Gingrich, the speaker of America's House of Representatives, said he would not run for the Republican nomination for president.
In Rio de Janeiro, around 100,000 people marched against violent crime. Greater Rio recorded 24 murders that day, much as usual.

text:
An offer from Ottawa that may well fail, but is worth making
CAN Canada be saved? In the month since Quebec voted grudgingly not to stomp out just now, the rest of the country has been left to wonder what, if anything, can be done to stop it from leaving next time. Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, has now given his answer-and Canadians, in Quebec or elsewhere, have offered him little thanks in return. That might not matter if they had any better ideas, but, since they do not, maybe they should listen after all.
Mr Chretien's plan has three points, directed towards the Quebec separatists' three main demands: a parliamentary motion to recognise Quebec as a distinct, French-speaking society; a bill that would give Quebec a veto on constitutional change; and a promise that the federal government will get out of manpower training, a topic on which Quebeckers feel strongly. The answer from Quebec has been framboise.
Mr Chretien cannot have expected anything else. The separatists had already made clear their contempt for mere parliamentary motions: at the least, they want their province's special position enshrined in the constitution. But Mr Chretien has more than Quebec to deal with. Much of "Anglo" Canada is fed up with Quebec, and most provincial politicians are fed up with the federal government as well. They want more power from it. So Mr Chretien has had to offer them something too. He is offering a veto not only to Quebec but also to the other weighty province, Ontario, and, as regions, to the four (small) Atlantic provinces and the four (sizeable) western ones. His readiness to get Ottawa out of manpower training, he says, is just the start of wider decentralisation. So is Anglo Canada happy? It is not.
Yet what more can Mr Chretien offer? A right of constitutional veto, however solid, would not really satisfy Quebec's separatists. They and most of the nearly 50% of Quebeckers who voted for "sovereignty" want just that: not rights over any Canadian constitution but a separate one of their own. Even those who do not really want a split would like more than a veto on change; they want change itself. Quebec's language law goes far to ensure the dominance of French there. But it has still had to be toned down from what French-speaking enthusiasts wanted, and even now it is Canada's highest court, not Quebec's, that would in the last resort rule on any challenge to it. More widely, federal legislation in Canada is still made-and will be under any constitution-by a parliament in Ottawa dominated by English-speakers from other provinces.
And why not, those others say: that is what distinguishes a country from a customs union or a club. Little as they love Ottawa, they do not believe Canada can be run on the basis that you just opt out of whatever you don't like, or veto what others do. Especially, some would add under their breath, when you are a bunch of French-speakers with no huge wish to belong to the country at all. That is less than fair to French-speakers: even in Quebec, two-fifths of them have just voted to say they do want to belong. But Anglo exasperation with Quebec is a force that cannot be ignored. And it tightly limits the concessions that federalists can offer. Big constitutional changes require ratification by all ten provinces. Canada spent much of the 1980s trying for unanimity and failing; Mr Chretien is not the only person who sees little hope in another round.
Yet there is room for haggling. Quebec's present government has not flatly said no; it has said not enough is on the table. Its future leader, Lucien Bouchard, announcing his availability for that post, did say he would refuse to talk, but not for ever: he would talk at the constitutionally due date of 1997, he said, albeit with total scepticism. On the Anglo side, the Reform Party, about as far as one can get in geography or spirit from Quebec, does not reject recognition of Quebec's distinctness outright, or its claim to a veto (the party's first response was to ask for a veto for British Columbia too).
Soldier on, or lie down now
So those who believe in Canadian unity must soldier on. The conditions will be far from ideal. Mr Chretien is not their best imaginable leader. And among Quebeckers there would be many with no wish to see any talks succeed-a bad basis to start from, as any diplomat knows. Yet Mr Chretien's true hope is not a deal, not even talks at all: it is that his offers (which he can push through Parliament, unlike constitutional changes) will cut away enough "soft" separatist support to defeat the next referendum. He may be wrong. But federalists have little choice: if they will not risk defeat, they guarantee it. Quebec separatism is not about to go away.

text:
WHO can solve Canada's crisis of national unity? Not Jean Chretien, say western Canadians.
 To win over Quebec, the prime minister-a French-speaking Quebecker by origin--has just rushed through the federal Parliament, where his Liberal Party has a solid majority, a quasi-constitutional revision of Quebec's status that has done more to divide the country than unite it. Quebec separatists are unimpressed. Western Canada has been angered and alienated.
The west's confidence was first shaken late in the Quebec referendum campaign this autumn, when Mr Chretien, who till then had sidestepped delicate constitutional issues, dangled before Quebec offers of recognition as a "distinct society" and a veto on constitutional change. That may have helped to defeat the separatists in the vote on October 30th, but the margin was so small that something more had to be done if Quebec was to stay in Canada.
That something, in Mr Chretien's eyes; was to introduce in Parliament, without consulting the provinces, a motion on the distinct-society issue and a bill in effect lending the federal veto on constitutional change to four "regions"-the provinces of Quebec and Ontario, and the east and west (four provinces apiece, whose veto could be exercised if at least two, holding jointly 50%plus of the region's population, so chose). He saw this as a compromise. To the west it was as though he had flung a lighted match into dry prairie grass. "A slap in the face" and "sowing the seeds of western separatism" were among the cries voiced by politicians and ordinary citizens alike.
To westerners, Mr Chretien was trampling on their bedrock belief that all provinces are entitled to equal rights and powers (a bedrock somewhat fissured by simultaneous indignation that Atlantic Canada, with 8% of the country's people, was being put on par with the west, which has almost 30%). British Columbians were especially incensed at being lumped in with the three prairie provinces, contrary to both geography and history. "Canada is not composed of Ontario, Quebec, and two regions," declared the province's premier, Mike Harcourt. "This is an offensive view held to be true only in central Canada."
Mr Chretien timing did not help. British Columbia and Alberta have been riled for some time by his refusal to alter the formula for sharing welfare costs whereby Ottawa pays a third in well-off British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario, but half in other provinces. British Columbia's bill, particularly, has shot out of control as the jobless have flooded in, boosting welfare rolls by 100,000 in four years. To make tempers worse, when the province recently imposed a threemonth residency requirement on claimants, Ottawa hit back by withholding C$47m ($34m) due in tax transfers.
The veto protests paid off, in a way: a late amendment designated British Columbia as a region with a veto of its own-only to be dismissed there as a "token", indeed a step back. The west wants reform of the federal Senate, with senators elected, not appointed, and more of them for the less-populous provinces, fewer for the two heavyweights. Today's constitutional rules make this hard: together, the big two, Ontario and Quebec, can block change. The new veto system would make it almost impossible, since either could do so single-handed.
Underlying western anger is bewilderment that Mr Chretien, a veteran of constitutional wars, would blunder ahead as he has. On television, he said he felt confident, because his veto concept had been supported by all provinces in 1971 (in a deal that collapsed when Quebec changed its mind). "Deja vu," said Alberta's premier, Ralph Klein, summing up western dismay at Ottawa's obsession with Quebec.
Until recently, Mr Chretien's national popularity-opinion polls have given him over 60% approval-had seemed solid. Even the west, mostly represented in Ottawa by members of the Reform Party, was behind him, pleased with his efforts to encourage growth and cut the budget deficit. But his lack of early action in the Quebec referendum has been widely blamed for the nearloss of that battle, and now he is similarly assailed for misreading the west.
Mr Chretien plainly does not understand how disaffected westerners have become. They flatly reject recognition of a special status for Quebec, or one-sided concessions to win hearts in a province that. seems to be halfway out of the door already. And their anger is increasingly tinged with despair, as Canada slips back into a familiar slough of constitutional warfare. The man whose task it is to unite the country has botched the job, say many westerners; it is time he went-and, the times being what they are, they want an English-speaking, non-Quebecker in his place.

British Columbia 's bill , particularly , has shot out of control as the jobless have flooded in , boosting welfare rolls by 100,000 in four years . To make tempers worse , when the province recently imposed a threemonth residency requirement on claimants , Ottawa hit back by withholding C$ 47 m ( $ 34 m ) due in tax transfers . 
 The veto protests paid off , in a way : a late amendment designated British Columbia as a region with a veto of its own - only to be dismissed there as a " token " , indeed a step back . The west wants reform of the federal Senate , with senators elected , not appointed , and more of them for the less - populous provinces , fewer for the two heavyweights . Today 's constitutional rules make this hard : together , the big two , Ontario and Quebec , can block change . The new veto system would make it almost impossible , since either could do so single - handed . 
 Underlying western anger is bewilderment that Mr Chretien , a veteran of constitutional wars , would blunder ahead as Jean Chretien has . On television , Jean Chretien said Jean Chretien felt confident , because Jean Chretien's veto concept had been supported by all provinces in 1971 ( in a deal that collapsed when Quebec changed its mind ) . " Deja vu , " said Alberta 's premier , Ralph Klein , summing up western dismay at Ottawa 's obsession with Quebec . 
 Until recently , Jean Chretien's national popularity - opinion polls have given Jean Chretien over 60 % approval - had seemed solid . Even the west , mostly represented in Ottawa by members of the Reform Party , was behind Jean Chretien , pleased with Jean Chretien's efforts to encourage growth and cut the budget deficit . But Jean Chretien's lack of early action in the Quebec referendum has been widely blamed for the nearloss of that battle , and now Jean Chretien is similarly assailed for misreading the west . 
 Jean Chretien plainly does not understand how disaffected westerners have become . They flatly reject recognition of a special status for Quebec , or one - sided concessions to win hearts in a province that . seems to be halfway out of the door already . And their anger is increasingly tinged with despair , as Canada slips back into a familiar slough of constitutional warfare . The man whose task it is to unite the country has botched the job , say many westerners ; it is time he went - and , the times being what they are , they want an English - speaking , non - Quebecker in his place .

text:
FOR at least two years, Lucien Bouchard has been the most popular politician in Quebec. On January 29th he takes over as premier of the province, at the head of the separatist Parti Quebecois (PQ) that rules it.
Mr Bouchard has played diverse roles in the ten years since he left his law firm at the beckoning of the Conservative prime minister of the day, Brian Mulroney. He has been ambassador in Paris, then a federal member of Parliament and environment minister for Mr Mulroney. Then, after a quarrel with his old college friend, he went into backbench exile and formed a separatist party at federal level, the Bloc Quebtcois.
When the Bloc swept 54 federal seats in Quebec in the 1993 election, he found himself leader of the opposition, facing another Quebecker, the new, Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien. The skirmishing over Quebec and its dreams of sovereignty took place across the House of Commons as much as in the Quebec legislature, and Mr Bouchard was outshining the province's PQ premier, Jacques Parizeau, in forceful oratory long before he took the reins of the separatists' flagging referendum campaign last October and brought it within an inch of victory.
His new role will be the most demanding of all. By provincial law, he cannot call a new referendum on separation during the present legislature, whose full term runs to 1999. He could call a very early election this year to confirm his leadership and be ready for whatever Mr Chretien may do when, obligatorily, he holds a review of the 1982 federal constitution next year. Mr Bouchard has not tipped his hand on this yet.
Instead, he says, his first priority is to cut his province's budget deficit, at C$3.9 billion ($2.8 billion) relatively the largest in Canada. He has made his task harder by saying he will cancel a planned increase in sales tax that would have brought in C$500m. Federalists hope his first months behind a desk where the buck really stops, and the unpopular spending cuts he will have to make, will tarnish the halo he has worn for a year since he recovered, almost miraculously, from a bacterial attack that cost him a leg. Leading the PQ, with its tradition of mature and open debate, will also be harder than commanding a party founded and recruited by himself.
But Mr Bouchard is already showing his skill. He has rejected the mansion in Quebec city that businessmen furnished for his predecessor. And, having recognised that to keep a federal pension was political folly, albeit wholly legitimate, he is donating the C$30,000 a year to his new party.
In the face of this new force at the head of the separatists, the federalists are yet to close ranks. Andre Ouellet, who until he quit office this week was both foreign minister and senior minister for Quebec, has twice attacked the provincial Liberal leader, Daniel Johnson, for his feebleness during the referendum. Mr Chre'tien, on a trade mission to Asia with seven provincial premiers, forged little more agreement among them than that any referendum affecting the constitution must be subject to proper ground rules-not least, that the question be clear.
Meanwhile, the right-wing Reform Party, strong in the western provinces and in Ontario, has pressed for a tough line on Quebec separatism: it wants "exit conditions" laid down if Quebec voters next time choose sovereignty. In parallel, talk is growing in some English-speaking enclaves of Quebec of strategies to remain part of Canada, whatever happens. The 20 mayors of Pontiac county, along the Ottawa river, meet on this issue in February. Federalists in the western half of the island of Montreal dream of a separate city-state.
 The most sensible voice has been that of Keith Spicer, once a languages commissioner and now head of Canada's broadcasting regulators. Quebec nationalism, he argues, will never go away; the federal government and the other provinces are in total disarray with no coherent plan; and Mr Bouchard might call a spring election and summer referendum. So he appeals urgently for a twin strategy: one "option group" to propose bold constitutional changes that include Quebec, the other a blueprint for a Canada without it. By midJune, he suggests, after a "citizens' assembly" has added its say, the whole country should make its choice in a referendum. His paper has been well received in Quebec and beyond-and at least it has put something into the present policy vacuum.

text:
IT IS a fond boast of Canadians that their country invented peacekeeping when Lester Pearson, its foreign minister of the time, proposed a force for Sinai that allowed British and French troops to withdraw after "Suez", those countries' joint attack, with Israel, on Egypt in 1956. In the 40 years since, there has scarcely been a United Nations observer mission or peacekeeping operation-from Cyprus and the Golan Heights to Namibia and Cambodia-in which Canadian troops have not been engaged.
Canadians, with justice, are proud of this record. But enthusiasm for their highminded calling cooled around the time that a monument depicting three peacekeepers was erected in 1992 on the ceremonial route in Ottawa. The Airborne Regiment was disgraced (and soon afterwards disbanded) when some of its men, supposedly keeping the peace, killed several Somalis, including a teenager whom they had tortured. Disillusion deepened when a small if brave Canadian contingent in Rwanda proved ineffective during that country's vast massacre in 1994.
In the first two years after it was elected in late 1993, the present Liberal government of Jean Chretien showed every sign of wanting to give up Canada's commitments in several hell-holes, notably Bosnia. In the end, though, it contributed 1,000 troops afresh to the NATO operation in ex-Yugoslavia, to ensure that the United States too would send a contingent. Now it has taken an extraordinary step to maintain a peacekeeping force in Haiti.
The Haiti operation has become a political football in the UN Security Council. The American troops, the dominant element in the UN force there, are due to withdraw this month, and President Rene Preval, the newly elected successor to JeanBertrand Aristide, is still far from secure in office. China, no friend of the Aristide regime, which maintained close relations with Taiwan, said it would accept continued UN peacekeeping only if the force were limited to 1,200, and kept in place for no longer than four months.
Enter the Canadians. Their new foreign minister, Lloyd Axworthy, a strong supporter of the UN, helped to produce a compromise. The Americans will duly go home, reducing the UN'S blue-bereted force to two battalions of troops, from Bangladesh and Pakistan, along with an Argentine field hospital. But Canada will provide 700 other troops wearing their own green berets, together with Brigadier;General Pierre Daigle, who will command the whole group, taking over from an American. Canada will also itself pay the full $24m cost of its troops' four-month stay as well as continue to field its 0 Mounties training a new police force.
Why? Here is Canada ready to spend more money for Haiti, and send more men, a French-speaking regiment which will, moreover, be in daily contact with a volatile population, unlike the earlier detachment of engineers, who worked in the background. There seem to be two reasons for this rush of generosity. The Chretien government has sought foreign policies that show Canada to be independent of the United States, without challenging its big neighbour (although-as long since it disagrees firmly about Fidel Castro's Cuba). The takeover of responsibility in Haiti was a gift for Mr Chretien in this respect: a move positively helpful to the Americans, but independent of them.
The second reason has to do with the politics of Quebec, where many Haitians now live, and where Mr Aristide was once a theology student. When Mr Chretien shuffled his cabinet last month, the previous foreign minister, Andre Ouellet, gave up that post, and with it his seat in the federal parliament, where he had represented Papineau-St Michel, in Montreal, the province's biggest city. Mr Chretien brought in an outsider, Pierre Pettigrew, as minister for international co-operation and one of two new faces to strengthen the government's image in Quebec He is to fight a by-election on March 25th in Mr Ouellet's old constituency, where one person in seven is Haitian.
This will be no pushover for Mr Pettigrew and the Liberals. The separatist Bloc Quebecois has a strong candidate. And, though Canada's Haitians, albeit Frenchspeaking, have little sympathy for Quebec separatism, the New Democratic (leftish) candidate is Haitian. So is the husband of the Conservative candidate. Both Mr Pettigrew and his Tory rival flew to Haiti for President Preval's inauguration. But the Liberals now hope to find they have played an ace with their offer of 700 troops.

text:
THE Canadian army had to mark the anniversary of its greatest battle honour-the storming of Vimy Ridge, near Ypres, in Flanders, in April 19i7-in a most curious way this year. All 100,000 armedforces personnel and their civilian colleagues were told to drop everything they might otherwise be doing on April 9th and spend the day searching for documents to do with some ugly incidents in Somalia three years earlier.
The man who ordered what immediately became known as the Great Easter Egg Hunt was the country's top soldier, General Jean Boyle. Before he became chief of defence staff in January, General Boyle was in charge of policy and communications in the defence department. This month a former subordinate, Colonel Geoff Haswell, claimed that the general had approved, in that post, a move to change the category of certain documents, which meant they could be destroyed and thus escape the eyes of a civilian inquiry that has laboured for months on the Somali affair.
The armed forces' response was to charge Colonel Haswell under military law, while the besieged general first denied that he had ever taken part in any effort to thwart the inquiry's work, and then added an appeal-on video-to all his troops to hunt everywhere for logs, computer disks and whatever else might be relevant to the affair. Although everyone from fighter pilots to office clerks searched diligently, and did indeed turn up some missing documents on the now disbanded Airborne Regiment, the inquiry's commissioners were far from satisfied. They adjourned their hearings this week, giving the general until April i8th to turn in all relevant papers and promising some tough questions when he appears as a witness next week.
Whyall this fuss about some papers? Because the "Somali affair" was a very nasty one indeed, besmirching not just the army but the country's reputation for its role in peacekeeping, of which Canadians have been justifiably proud. The Airborne Regiment drew its men from other units, and toughness-as in any such regiment in any country-was one qualification. As part of the peacekeeping force in Somalia, the regiment did good work clearing a way for relief convoys. But then in March 1993 a group of corporals caught a Somali teenager inside their compound-and tortured and beat him to death.
The story took weeks to reach Ottawa, to the embarrassment of the defence minister, Kim Campbell (who became prime minister for the Conservatives that June, only to be buried by Jean Chretien and his Liberals in an autumn general election). Rumours of other killings surfaced. Later, photographs of the boy being tortured emerged. So did video films of crude rituals and racist remarks among members of the Airborne Regiment in Somalia. The new, Li eral defence minister, David Collenette, responded firmly: he disbanded the regiment. One private was later courtmartialled and sentenced to five years in prison; a corporal attempted suicide, achieved only a coma but is still unfit for trial; some senior officers responsible for giving any "orders of engagement", including the colonel, were acquitted.
Throughout last year dissatisfaction rose over the way the army had punished only a junior scapegoat, while questions multiplied about the extent of a cover-up. How far up the chain of command did it go? The commission of inquiry, under a federal judge, Gilles Letourneau, completed a first stage in January, plainly incredulous of military explanations for the way logs and disks could not be found (computer errors in Canada and "destroyed by water" in drought-prone Somalia, where every drop was guarded
Then this month Colonel Haswell, who had been director of public affairs, broke silence. In a long press interview, he explained how some documents had been recategorised to avoid access-to-information requests. More explosive still, he claimed that General Boyle had given his approval, as had-he said-the general's predecessor as chief of defence staff, now retired, and a senior public servant who is now Canada's ambassador to the United Nations All three men deny it.
Opposition members of Parliament, returning from their Easter break, have been demanding this week that both General Boyle and Mr Collenette, who was enthusiastic in his appointment of the general to Canada's top defence job, should resign. The betting is that the minister, who is one of Mr Chretien's favourites, will survive, whereas the general may not.

text:
THREE years ago, the young, neo-conservative Reform Party looked like a future contender for power, as its rocket-like rise drove Canada's politics sharply to the right. Today it seems a spent force. Critics, inside and outside the party, say it is going nowhere fast, because extremist members have given it an image of racism and intolerance. The national convention that starts in Vancouver on June 6th, they say, faces a critical challenge: Reform must reform itself, or it will fizzle away. 
Reform has been the dominant voice of the right since the 1993 federal election. From 2% of the 1988 vote and one seat won in a by-election later, it shot up then to i8% and 52 seats, all but one, admittedly, in western Canada. While helping Jean Chretien's Liberals to win power, this devastated both the Progressive Conservatives, then in government, who were cut to two seats, and the leftish New Democrats, down to nine. Canada's politics seemed on the way to being entirely remade. 
That was always the idea. Reform was created in 1987 largely by its present leader, Preston Manning, son of a former premier of Alberta, as a populist movement to make politics more accountable to ordinary people. It aimed to speak for unhappy middleclass conservatives who want less government, with lower taxes and spending, more support for family values, tougher welfare rules, a crackdown on crime, fewer immigrants, and so on, plus some specifically Canadian demands such as an end to official bilingualism and no special status for French-speaking Quebec. 
Ironically, the plain-spoken populism that made Reform popular has now got the party into deep trouble. An internal feud broke into the open in March, when some moderate Reform members of Parliament blamed the party's defeats in five by-elections on its extremist image, and said they might not stand again.Jan Brown, a prominent Mr from Calgary, pointing to some colleagues' wild comments on gun control and caning criminals, said Reform had become "downright scary" to many voters. 
The row was redoubled in May by two Reform MPS opposing a Liberal bill to expand rights for homosexuals. One, from British Columbia, said that if he owned a business he would move black or gay employees "to the back of the shop" or even sack them, if their presence annoyed bigoted customers. An Albertan MP chimed in. 
Such matters are one reason why Reform is down to 70,ooo members (from a high of 137,ooo) and only 13% in the latest opinion poll. A related provincial party got nowhere in this week's British Columbian elections. Reform's performance in Parliament has been unimpressive. Only on the Liberals' fiscal policy, their confused response to Quebec separatism, and some immigration scandals has it mounted effective attacks. The better organised Bloc Quebecois outshines it. And Mr Chretien, noting the shift in popular mood, has moved smartly to the right, stealing many of Reform's clothes, attacking the budget deficit, cutting social spending and beginning to decentralise and to slim government. The Liberals had 53% support in the latest poll. 
Mr Manning himself has been under fire from some of his MPS for leaving them "twisting in the wind", as one put it, before belatedly acting to curb the row. He did eventually clamp down, issuing guidelines for Reformers to exercise free speech responsibly. Meaning? Well, he imposed the same penalty, a short suspension from the parliamentary caucus, on Ms Brown as on the two right-wingers. Ms Brown quit Reform, to sit as an independent. 
Might Reform yet move closer to the mainstream? Not to judge from the populist resolutions at its convention. Nor is it clear how far Mr Manning wants to move, or could, in that direction. His activists are not troubled, analysts say, by flaps over extremist remarks, because they do not find them all that outlandish and they expect their MPs to speak for the grassroots. 
In the long run, there can be only one effective party of the right. But neither Reform nor the Conservatives are keen to merge. Which will overcome? For Reform, the test will be the next federal election, which may come early. The party must break out of its western bastion. The big battle will in be Ontario. In 1993, Reform came second in over half the 99 constituencies there. But in much of Ontario the Tory tradition is strong.

 Such matters are one reason why Reform is down to 70,ooo members ( from a high of 137,ooo ) and only 13 % in the latest opinion poll . A related provincial party got nowhere in this week 's British Columbian elections . Reform 's performance in Parliament has been unimpressive . Only on Jean Chretien's fiscal policy , Jean Chretien's confused response to Quebec separatism , and some immigration scandals has it mounted effective attacks . The better organised Bloc Quebecois outshines it . And Mr Chretien , noting the shift in popular mood , has moved smartly to the right , stealing many of Reform 's clothes , attacking the budget deficit , cutting social spending and beginning to decentralise and to slim government . Jean Chretien had 53 % support in the latest poll . 
 Mr Manning himself has been under fire from some of his MPS for leaving them " twisting in the wind " , as one put it , before belatedly acting to curb the row . He did eventually clamp down , issuing guidelines for Reformers to exercise free speech responsibly . Meaning ? Well , he imposed the same penalty , a short suspension from the parliamentary caucus , on Ms Brown as on the two right - wingers . Ms Brown quit Reform , to sit as an independent . 
 Might Reform yet move closer to the mainstream ? Not to judge from the populist resolutions at its convention . Nor is it clear how far Mr Manning wants to move , or could , in that direction . His activists are not troubled , analysts say , by flaps over extremist remarks , because they do not find them all that outlandish and they expect their MPs to speak for the grassroots . 
 In the long run , there can be only one effective party of the right . But neither Reform nor the Conservatives are keen to merge . Which will overcome ? For Reform , the test will be the next federal election , which may come early . The party must break out of its western bastion . The big battle will in be Ontario . In 1993 , Reform came second in over half the 99 constituencies there . But in much of Ontario the Tory tradition is strong .

text:
THERE is an odd conspiracy of silence among Canada's political leaders about the one topic that leaves every citizen in a state of uncertainty and unease: the future shape and structure of the country. 
The federal prime minister, Jean Chretien, and the ten provincial premiers will meet on June 20th and 21st. Yet when he met Quebec's secessionist premier, Lucien Bouchard, privately on June 7th, the two agreed that constitutional change would not figure on that meeting's agenda. In fact, it will have to, if only for a few minutes: the ministers must decide how to handle a provision in Canada's 1982 constitution requiring a review of its amending formulae by next April. Saskatchewan's New Democratic premier, Roy Romanow, has argued that this review has already happened, during the talks on the Charlottetown Accord, a deal meant to placate Quebec that was rejected in a 1992 referendum. Mr Chretien has seized on this way out, though he is yet to win all-round approval of it. 
Yet many Canadians have toiled to produce schemes to save their country and persuade Quebec not to vote for secession next time round, as it nearly did last October. A group of notables, including former premiers and a famous hockey goalie turned lawyer, last month produced a scheme that would enshrine Quebec's "unique character" in the constitution, and devolve several federal powers to the provinces. At its recent convention in Vancouver, the Reform Party called for the devolution of most such powers. Thousands of ordinary citizens held a unity rally in Ottawa on June 9th, cheering a declaration signed by most of the mayors from a nearby county in Quebec saying they wanted to stay in Canada if the rest of Quebec voted to secede. 
Alain Juppe, the French prime minister, was in Canada this week. He at least pointed to the issue, telling Quebeckers they could count on France whatever choice they made. No one could blame him for scrupulously giving no advice on what that choice should be (and many non-Quebeckers would have gone for his throat if he had). But why are Canadian leaders silent? 
Mr Bouchard's reasons are straightforward. Formerly leader of the Bloc Quebecois in the federal Parliament, he took power in Quebec in January. Preoccupied with the referendum, the Parti Quebecois government there, under Jacques Parizeau, had for a year neglected bread-and-butter issues. The budget deficit was soaring. So was unemployment Montreal, once a queen among cities, was down-at-heel. Mr Bouchard's strategy has been to raise taxes discreetly, go hunting for investors, and say as little about secession as his radical supporters will allow. His hope is that the federalists will help Quebec's economic recovery, while alienating its voters enough politically to give him a referendum victory after a provincial election in 1999. 
So far, his plan is working nicely. When they met on June 7th, Mr Chretien offered federal help in a dozen industrial projects, and agreed to look again at an $18 billion French-designed high-speed train scheme to link the main centres from Quebec city to Windsor, Ontario. Mr Chretien, a Quebecker, hopes to hold his province in Canada with a show of "profitable federalism" and by pragmatically devolving some of Ottawa's powers (over job-training, mining and forestry) to all provinces. 
Mr Chretien's trouble is that his poll ratings keep slipping-to 24% in Quebec, says Gallup, half his national standing-while occasional tough federalist talk of what dire things might happen if Quebeckers were to choose independence at the next referendum has simply allowed Mr Bouchard to shine in nationalist colours. 
Meanwhile, Quebec's disconsolate English-speakers, now shrunk to around 6oo,ooo of its 7m people, continue to trek west By 1999, enough may have left, even without a high-speed train to help them, to assure a secessionist victory.

text:
UNTIL recently, Canada's Quebecois separatists had a virtual monopoly of the word "sovereignty" as a political slogan. Now the chiefs of the country's "first nations"--some 660 Indian bands--have taken it over, in a campaign to assert their rights to self-government. 
So is Canada about to break into hundreds of fragments? Chief Ovide Mercredi, leader of the Assembly of First Nations, says that, unlike Quebec's Frenchspeaking separatists, his people do not want to leave Canada (which would be impracticable anyway: the largest group of Indians in any one area does not number more than 12,000). To him sovereignty means self-determination, self-reliance "and not waiting for the white governments to tell us what we can do." 
He has come to this stance after five years of trying to get the first nations' rights fully recognised in the constitution. He decided in the end that the present-- Liberal--federal government, elected in 1993 under the leadership of Jean Chr& tien, was planning to abandon its role as the native peoples' trustee and to turn the main problems over to the ten provincial governments. 
Mr Mercredi on July 8th presented to his organisation's annual assembly a broadly worded declaration of "sovereign relationships". Noting that the first nations had never been brought to relinquish their collective rights "through conquest, surrender or other means", it affirms that "each community must assert its jurisdiction and authority step by step, consistent with its own needs, priorities and aspirations". 
He also added a Gandhian touch-- and worried many white Canadians, mindful of the far-from-Gandhian armed stand-off at Oka, near Montreal, in 1991by saying that Indian youths should be trained in passive resistance. After debating for three days, the chiefs decided to spend a year mulling over this declaration, and how to implement it. More forcefully, they rejected the piecemeal way in which the minister for Indian affairs, Ron Irwin, is setting out to amend the framework law, the Indian Act, under which they are governed. 
These moves reflect the frustration of some native leaders at their treatment by the Chretien government, which they see as reverting to the old tactic of divideand-rule. Mr Irwin a year ago set out his terms for negotiating local self-government with various groups. Some, like the Nisga'a Indians in British Columbia, would get considerable powers over land title, taxation, social services and policing in their own areas. Mr Irwin has also designated Manitoba--Chief Mercredi's home province--for a pilot scheme whereby the federal Indian-affairs department will bow out and 63 bands, individually, will share powers with the provincial government concerned. 
That may sound acceptable, but Chief Mercredi sees it as a denial of the first nations' right to self-government, because it is top-down decision-making from Ottawa. He long ago suggested that a cabinet committee should work with chiefs on a Canada-wide implementation of native rights. It has not happened. Mr Mercredi had hoped to be invited to sit down with the provincial premiers for a time during their latest regular meeting, in June. No luck; they were preoccupied with Quebec. The federal government also seems to favour a rival body, the Native Council of Canada, whose strength is among the 6oo,ooo Indians-about half the totalwho live outside reserves. 
To Mr Mercredi, the assertion of selfgovernment can take many forms. It may mean young men building a hunting cabin in defiance of conservation officers in the Yukon; or selling fish from Lake Winnipeg directly to Saudi Arabia--Mr Mercredi is going there himself shortly-- without asking the say-so of the federal Ministry for International Trade. He wants to see young men getting paid work-and fitted to get it. These days, many of them, demoralised by welfare hand-outs, take to the bottle and (increasingly) to suicide. Some join the "warrior societies" that have been seen at Oka and later confrontations. Mr Mercredi tells of one youth at Cat Lake, in Ontario, who brandished his gun, declaring himself ready to die for the cause and only waiting for the word to go ahead. 
That is not Mr Mercredi's line. But when he recounts how the federal manpower minister, Doug Young, could not find time to talk with him about job training, he sounds close to despair.
