text:
IN A little over three years, Canada has had three defence ministers and three chiefs of defence staff, and disbanded its crack Airborne Regiment On October 4th David Collenette, the defence minister, resigned. Four days later General Jean Boyle, the military chief whom he had appointed ten months earlier and defended through sustained public attacks, followed suit. 
The name engraved on both men's hearts is Somalia. The fine reputation that Canada's soldiers have earned in dozens of peacekeeping operations, and at first embellished in Somalia, protecting faminerelief convoys, was besmirched in March 1993 by two incidents when Somali youths suspected of stealing were killed, one of the two being brutally tortured first. Despite army efforts to hush the affair up-not least because the Tory government of the day had soon to face a general election-the facts dribbled out. These included gleeful photographs of one of the victims, besides videos of Airborne soldiers in disgusting hazing sessions. Mr Collenette acted firmly, breaking up the regiment and appointing a civilian commission of inquiry. 
Alas for Mr Collenette, the young general whom he picked last December to clean house had in 1993 been the soldier ultimately responsible for public relations. As journalists and the commission probed, one big question was how far up the chain of command it had been decided to reclassify some documents, to prevent publication. A colonel who faces court martial on charges of destroying documents has said the atmosphere to limit public information was established right at the top by General Boyle's direct civilian boss, the then deputy defence minister, Robert Fowler. 
Mr Fowler later became, and remains, Canada's ambassador at the United Nations. General Boyle spent an awkward week in August telling the commission he himself accepted responsibility, but then blamed underlings for "lack of moral fibre". Several retired generals joined opposition politicians and the media through September in attacking him for lack of leadership. Then, suddenly, Mr Collenette, who had defended his chosen general to the end, resigned, ostensibly over an unrelated and fairly minor matter. The prime minister, Jean Chretien, within an hour of his close friend's resignation, appointed instead Doug Young, a minister already known for his toughness. General Boyle's days were numbered. 
Mr Young faces some daunting tasks, from drawing a line under the Somalia affair to decisions on new equipment. His biggest task will be to revive the credibility and morale of a once proud army and fit it for further peacekeeping.

text:
FOR more than a week, Canadians have been looking hard at their prime minister, Jean Chretien, and debating an ugly political question: is a lie worse than a broken promise? And what about both together? 
Mr Chretien is clearly thinking of calling an election in 1997, his fourth year of office, rather than holding on until near the end of his five-year term in 1998. His Liberal Party won an overwhelming victory in October 1993. The governing Conservatives' long-time leader (and prime minister), Brian Mulroney, had lost public trust, and his short-lived replacement, Kim Campbell, was unimpressive. The Tories were swept away, retaining just two seats, while the traditional third party, the leftish New Democrats, slid to nine. 
Two regional parties-the right-wing Reform Party, based in western Canada, and the separatist Bloc Quebecois-became the main opposition, with just over so members of Parliament apiece. Neither, however, has proved effective. The Bloc lost its fire when its leader, Lucien Bouchard, left last winter to lead the Quebec provincial government, and his successor, Michel Gauthier, could not heal splits in the party caucus, and resigned. The Reform leader, Preston Manning, is also in difficulties: some of his brighter and more moderate MPS are not going to seek re-election. 
The Liberals meanwhile have got on with their job. They fought off, if only just, the separatists' challenge in the Quebec referendum a year ago. The finance minister, Paul Martin, has slimmed the budget deficit With some complacency, Mr Chretien told a recent party conference that his government had already fulfilled over threequarters of its election promises. At 47% in the opinion polls, far ahead of any other party, the Liberals should be sitting pretty. 
Alas for Mr Chretien, in his calculations he forgot a promise. One reason for his triumph in 1993 was a pledge to replace the hated goods and services tax (GST), brought in by the Mulroney government. He hasn't done it. Controversy about the tax last summer compelled the deputy prime minister, Sheila Copps, to resign her seat and fight it again-successfully-in a by-election. On December loth, Mr Chretien himself was called to account, not by some parliamentarian but by a Montreal waitress. 
At a televised "town-hall meeting", Johanne Savoie said she had voted Liberal in 1993 because of this promise to junk the GST, and it had not happened. Mr Chretien denied he had ever made such a promise; he had committed his party only to replacing the GST with an equal but fairer tax, and that, he claimed, it had done by some harmonising with provincial sales taxes. Ms Savoie stood her ground: Mr Chretien had promised to "kill" the tax, she insistedand the broadcasters obligingly showed election-time clips that backed her up. 
For a week, the prime minister maintained his denial, angrily rejecting editorials that accused him of lying. At last, on December 16th, over in Newfoundland, he apologised for the "honest mistake" the Liberals had made in thinking they could quickly bring in an entirely different tax. Fair enough, but that was not the mistake he had made at the town-hall meeting. Mr Chretien-who had floundered further at the meeting by telling a jobless woman with three academic degrees that the government does not create jobs, and some people are lucky, others not-has come across as a man who does not care. 
He still looks well placed to win re-election. Yet unemployment remains at io%, and even that conceals the replacement of full-time jobs by part-time ones. Two recent polls gave the Bloc a clear lead over the Liberals in Quebec, and overall their rating, though still high, has fallen by ten points in six months, with the Conservatives-now led by Jean Charest, an MP from Quebecup to i8% and the New Democrats to ii%. The election is shaping up as a series of regional battles, with the Liberals facing a different main opposition in each region.

text:
AS CANADIANS settled into winter last week, they had the promise of three months of political and courtroom theatre to warm them: the trial of a C$50m ($37m) libel suit brought by Brian Mulroney, their long-time Conservative prime minister, against the present Liberal government. 
It was not to be. The evening before hearings were to begin, Mr Mulroney, now a high-flying Montreal lawyer and company director, agreed to settle, in return for an unequivocal apology and a promise that the government would pay his legal costs, put at C$im. Both sides duly claimed victory, but it was his voice that rang truer. The deal may not enrich him, but it goes a distance to restoring his sullied reputation. In contrast, Jean Chretien's government and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) have emerged looking both vindictive and sloppy. The justice minister, Allan Rock, often touted as a possible successor to Mr Chretien, is having to fend off demands that he should step down. 
The suit revolved around enduring rumours that Mr Mulroney had received millions as a kickback after Air Canada-then government-owned-spent C$1.8 billion in 88 to buy new airliners from Airbus Industrie. The RCMP had investigated the sale and come up empty-handed before Mr Mulroney left politics in 1993. But after the Liberals took office later that year, the case was quietly reopened. 
Mr Mulroney went on the offensive in November 1995, when a Justice Department letter to the Swiss authorities was leaked. Asking for help in tracing a bank account that might hold money of his, the letter spoke of "criminal activity on the part of a former prime minister." He sued. 
Many Canadians took the letter as confirming what they had long suspected, that during the nine scandal-ridden years of Conservative power the rot went all the way to the top. There was no shortage of Schadenfreude. But the RCMP had a problem. Its case seems to have been fuelled less by facts than by the intense rancour still felt towards a man often accused of having sold out the country to corporate interests while gutting its most sacred institutions. 
The crux of the libel trial was to have been: who leaked the letter? Mr Mulroney, sensing politics in every twist and turn, thought it was someone in the new government or in the RCMP. The Justice Department suspected the affair was a ploy by the Mulroney camp. The case was all set to go to trial. But then-only on January 2nd-federal officials learned that a senior RCMP officer, who had previously denied doing so, had, after all, confided to a reporter (albeit not the one who broke the story) that Mr Mulroney was named in the letter. 
The RCMP this week was maintaining that settlement of the civil case will have no bearing on the criminal investigation. It is still under way, the Mounties say. But just what they think (or hope or dream) they may find, no one now is even hinting.

Both sides duly claimed victory , but it was his voice that rang truer . The deal may not enrich him , but it goes a distance to restoring his sullied reputation . In contrast , Jean Chretien's government and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police ( RCMP ) have emerged looking both vindictive and sloppy . The justice minister , Allan Rock , often touted as a possible successor to Jean Chretien , is having to fend off demands that he should step down . 
 The suit revolved around enduring rumours that Mr Mulroney had received millions as a kickback after Air Canada - then government - owned - spent C$ 1.8 billion in 88 to buy new airliners from Airbus Industrie . The RCMP had investigated the sale and come up empty - handed before Mr Mulroney left politics in 1993 . But after the Liberals took office later that year , the case was quietly reopened . 
 Mr Mulroney went on the offensive in November 1995 , when a Justice Department letter to the Swiss authorities was leaked . Asking for help in tracing a bank account that might hold money of his , the letter spoke of " criminal activity on the part of a former prime minister . " He sued . 
 Many Canadians took the letter as confirming what they had long suspected , that during the nine scandal - ridden years of Conservative power the rot went all the way to the top . There was no shortage of Schadenfreude . But the RCMP had a problem . Its case seems to have been fuelled less by facts than by the intense rancour still felt towards a man often accused of having sold out the country to corporate interests while gutting its most sacred institutions . 
 The crux of the libel trial was to have been : who leaked the letter ? Mr Mulroney , sensing politics in every twist and turn , thought it was someone in the new government or in the RCMP . The Justice Department suspected the affair was a ploy by the Mulroney camp . The case was all set to go to trial . But then - only on January 2nd - federal officials learned that a senior RCMP officer , who had previously denied doing so , had , after all , confided to a reporter ( albeit not the one who broke the story ) that Mr Mulroney was named in the letter . 
 The RCMP this week was maintaining that settlement of the civil case will have no bearing on the criminal investigation . It is still under way , the Mounties say . But just what they think ( or hope or dream ) they may find , no one now is even hinting .

text:
OTTAWA 
ABOUT the time he presented his fourth budget on February 18th, word went out that the finance minister no longer wanted to be known as Paul Martin Jr. It was a sign that Mr Martin was his own man, not just the son ofa famous veteran of Canadian politics. It may also indicate that he will succeed Jean Chretien as prime minister soon after the Liberals achieve their widely expected victory in the next general election, which is likely to be called for early June. 
In his 40 years of public life, Paul Martin Sr was variously health minister (introducing the federal system of medicare) foreign minister and, ultimately, high commissioner in London; he twice contested the Liberal leadership. His son's career has been more varied. He is proud of having been a youthful deckhand on an Arctic salvage boat and a roustabout in the Alberta oilfields. He spent the early 198os making a fortune as head of Canada Steamship Lines. Not until he was 5o did he enter federal politics, winnning a Montreal suburban seat in 1988. When the Liberals won power in September 1993, he was given the job of finance minister, considered a graveyard in recent Canadian politics. 
Instead, he has been the star of a still popular government and a recovering economy. Under his firm hand, the deficit has been reduced from 6% to 2% of GDP, with the prospect of a balanced budget in 1999. The economy is projected to grow by more than 3% this year, and inflation and interest rates are lower than in the United States. Mr Martin's latest budget won praise for continuing to cut the deficit while offering modest help to poor families: shamefully, one Canadian child in five lives in poverty. The best bilingual debater on the government benches, Mr Martin has managed to portray a 7o% increase in employee contributions to the government pension plan as investment in retirement rather than a disguised tax. 
Is all this enough to sweep him swiftly to the prime ministership?Certainly, much will depend on performances during the election campaign, on which most Liberals are eager to embark while the Reform Party is in disarray and the Bloc Quebecois is arguing over a new leader. Mr Chretien could decide to stay on afterwards, but he has started to sound uncaring about Canada's 9.7% unemployment rate and to look inept in coping with the Quebec separatists. He could even lose his own Quebec seat. Win or lose, Mr Chretien is nearly five years older than 58-year-old Mr Martin and might decide on a dignified withdrawal to the golf course. The leadership would then be Mr Martin's to lose.

text:
OTTAWA THE five federal-level political parties have started campaigning for a general election in Canada on June 2nd, not waiting for the Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien, to call it, as he is expected to do, on April 27th. At first sight, Mr Chretien's future looks safe enough. Just possibly it may not be. 
If he has indeed opted for an early election-Parliament's five-year term is not up until October 1998-the timing is tight for Mr Chretien. He has had to wait for a new electoral law to come into force this month, but he can also expect to see some gloomy unemployment figures coming out in June. And though the latest opinion polls put the Liberals at least 20 points ahead of any rival party, they also show that this support is soft. Many voters believe the government has done too little to deal with unemployment (still officially about 9%, and in reality probably higher), and over its 1993 campaign promises to maintain health services and to protect public broadcasting from the heavy cuts that the finance minister, Paul Martin, has since imposed in his crusade against the budget deficit. More than ever, the coming election will be a series of four regional contests, the Liberals having to spread their strength to match other parties prominent in each region. The two essentially regional parties that filled the opposition benches as newcomers after the 1993 vote-the French-speaking Bloc Quebecois separatists with 54 seats, and the rightwing Reform Party based in Alberta, with sa-remain powerful in their eastern and western bastions. The big question is how far the Liberal's two traditional rivals in national politics have recovered from the beating they took in 1993. 
The Conservatives, af ter nine years in power, nearly all under Brian Mulroney, collapsed in that election, under his short-lived successor, to just two seats. The leftish New Democrats (NDP) took only nine. Since then, though, both parties have given themselves attractive new leaders. On the right,Jean Charest, from Quebec, one of the two survivors, has pulled the Conservatives ahead of the Reform Party in opinion polls. For the NDP, Alexa McDonough, after a year in the shadows without a parliamentary seat, at last made her mark as party leader at an enthusiastic policy convention in mid-April in Regina, Saskatchewan, where the Regina manifesto of 1933 launched social democracy in Canada. 
The two have chosen different ways to challenge the Liberals, whose own strategy to win the middle ground is "to campaign from the left and govern from the right". Mr Charest, who was environment minister in the Mulroney government and is still only 38, has shifted Conservative policies further to the right, promising tax cuts and opposing gun-control legislation. His target is Ontario, home to 4o% of the nation's voters. In 1993 they gave the Liberals an almost clean sweep of the 99 Ontario seats, thanks, not least, to the split of the right-wing vote between Conservatives and Reform. If the Conservatives' new stars, such as MajorGeneral Lewis Mackenzie, of Bosnia fame, can roll back Reform support, the party could make precious gains. 
But there are risks in Mr Charest's tactic. Ontario's provincial Conservatives, who won power from the NDP there in 1995, have already put it into practice, slashing social services to deliver hefty tax cuts-and many voters dislike the result. 
In his native Quebec, Mr Charest could be the spoiler, taking anti-separatist votes from the Liberals (and some from the softer nationalists) with conciliatory talk about Quebec's special status in Canada. The Bloc Quebecois will have a powerful ally: Lucien Bouchard, its creator, now running the province at the head of the local Parti Quebecois, plans to campaign actively for his old, federal-level party. The Bloc may well hold on to two-thirds of Quebec's seats. 
The NDP'S main strength lies in western Canada, where its provincial versions run the governments of British Columbia and Saskatchewan. There the Liberals have to find a wide enough band of support between it and the Reform Party. The NDP has also picked up support in the four Atlantic provinces during recent provincial elections. Ms McDonough is well liked after years in Nova Scotia politics. During the Regina convention she staked out a policy of creating jobs and restoring social-welfare programmes after the harsh years of deficit-cutting. Her argument that parliament needs a strong opposition party of social conscience-"We have never made government, but we have always made a difference", she says-may win back votes from the Liberals. 
A Liberal government still looks the likeliest outcome. But even so there may be a shock in store for Mr Chretien: his own seat-like his background-is in Quebec, and he will have a hard fight to hold it against a strong Bloc Quebecois candidate.

text:
Blair's Britain 
Tony Blair's Labour Party won Britain's general election by a landslide, in one of the biggest poll victories in Britain this century. 
The first round of elections for about a fifth of Italy's local councils resulted in the loss of Milan for the separatist Northern League. The unreformed Refounded Communists showed they still have enough support to hamper reforms. 
Necmettin Erbakan, Turkey's Islamist prime minister, was again told by secular-minded generals to curb Islamic influence in the civil service and schools. 
European Union governments agreed to suspend "critical dialogue" and ministerial ties with Iran, but took no steps on trade and agreed that ambassadors-withdrawn in April because of state-sponsored murder by Iranians in Germany in 1992-could go back, if their government wanted them to. Iran, amid a flurry of abuse, said Germany's and Denmark's were not welcome. 
As France's general-election campaign got under way, the ruling centre-right coalition promised to cut taxes and government spending. The opposition Socialists and Communists made a joint declaration, promising to create 700,000 jobs and reduce the working week. 
Violence returned to the breakaway Russian republic of Chechnya, with fighting on the border between Russian police and Chechens. A bomb in a southern Russian railway station killed two people and injured 20. 
Refugees out 
Zaire's rebels, previously obstructive of UN efforts to protect Rwandan Hutu refugees, changed tack: repatriate the lot within 60 days, they said. The UN made a start. Talks between the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, and President Mobutu were arranged. 
Burundi's mainly Tutsi army said it had killed at least 300 Hutu militiamen last month after they invaded from Tanzania. The army claimed the militiamen had killed 34 schoolchildren and seven teachers. 
In Yemen, election results were brilliant for the main ruling party. They were rigged, said its minority partner, threatening to go to court. 
In a joint appearance with King Hussein of Jordan on CNN television, Israel's prime minister said he had begun to ease the ban on Palestinian workers, and would look into the way East Jerusalem Arabs had been deprived of residency rights. He offered no concession on the Har Homa Jewish settlement, but said building for Arabs would also begin. 
Taking stock 
The latest strategic review of America's defence capabilities suggested that as many as 50,000 active-duty troops might be cut, especially in the army, to help pay for weap ons such as computerised artillery systems and biologicalweapons detectors. 
The Chemical Weapons Convention, the world's most ambitious arms-control treaty, came into force. The United States ratified it just before the deadline. So did China. Russia, however, did not. 
A federal district judge in North Carolina, a big tobacco-growing state, upheld the power of the Food and Drug Administration to regulate tobacco as a drug. At the same time, however, the judge ruled out controls on cigarette advertising. 
Thirteen members of the self styled Republic of Texas, which wants Texas to secede from the United States, held police at bay from a compound in Fort Davis. 
Alexis Herman, a black woman, was confirmed as America's secretary of labour. 
As Bill Clinton prepared for an official visit to Mexico and Central America, Latin Americans at a high-level meeting in Atlanta accused the United States of footdragging over pan-American free trade. Officials reaffirmed America's commitment. Newt Gingrich went along, but joined in Latin criticism of the United States' "certification" process in the drugs war. 
With his party miles ahead in opinion polls, Canada's LiS eral prime minister, Jean Chretien, called an early general election for June 2nd, and then announced an easing of federal cuts in healthcare spending. 
Argentina's former economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, a loud and frequent campaigner against corruption, was indicted for misuse of his powers while a minister. 
Reassurance 
Hong Kong's future leader, Tung Chee-hwa, said in a television interview that a crackdown on democracy demonstrators, as happened in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, "will not happen" after the British colony reverts to China in two months. "Demonstration is part of our culture," he said. 
President Imomali Rakhmonov of Tajikistan was seriously injured when a grenade was thrown at him in Khudjand. Two people were killed. The former Soviet republic is recovering from a civil war. 
Budiman Sudjatmiko, the chairman of Indonesia's People's Democratic Party, was sentenced to 13 years in jail for "subversion". The party has been banned from taking part in the country's general election on May 29th. 
A quarrel in India's coalition government was settled, bringing back Palaniappan Chidambaram, a reformist free-marketeer, as finance minister.

text:
A chance to even up old scores 
IT LOOKS a safe bet. Canada's Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien, has called an early general election for June 2nd. Polls before the announcement put his party far ahead of any rival. Unless the land starts to slide dramatically beneath his feet or-even less probably-the earth moves for some other party, he is home and dry. True, the polls also showed huge numbers of voters-over 50% of Liberals, 60% of Conservatives-claiming they were still ready to change their minds. But there is no evident reason why they should, at least not to Mr Chretien's disadvantage. 
So this will be another dull Canadian election, will it? No, and not only because the one of 1993 was not dull at all.Aided by the first-past-the-post electoral system-as used in Britain and the United States-the voters four years ago produced the biggest turnaround in parliamentary history. The Liberals, with 41.5% of the vote, won 177 of the then 295 seats, while the sorry 16% of the ruling, once mighty Conservatives brought them a still sorrier haul of seats: just two. And suddenly the opposition benches were swamped by two parties previously little heard of: the right-wing Reform Party, with 18% and 52 seats, nearly all from western Canada, and, odder still, the French-speaking separatists of the Bloc Quebecois, with 14% and 54 seats. Add the leftish New Democrats (NDP), with 6.5% and 9 seats, and Canada had got the government it wanted but certainly not the parliament (where indeed the official "leader of the opposition" was the Bloc's Lucien Bouchard, a party and a man who would sooner not be Canadian at all). 
The coming election may partly redress these absurd figures. One poll published this week, though taken well before, gave the Liberals 44%, Tories 2o%, Reform 15%, NDP ii% and the Bloc 8%. Reproduced on election day, this would leave the Liberals very comfortably in command, unless one of the two right-wing parties can drive the other into the ground; that is unlikely, given the geographical spread of their rival supporters, but well worth watching. 
Worth attention too is the issue symbolised by the rise in support for the NDP. Mr Chretien's finance minister has been a zealous deficit-cutter; as have provincial governments across the country. But the feeling has grown, in the face of persistent unemployment and tight health-care spending, that zeal has gone too far. Mr Chretien, no deaf politician he, duly did a u-turn the day after announcing the election. Lo, some ofthe proposed cuts in central transfers to the provinces for (mainly) health care were no longer needed: a figure due to shrink to C$ii billion ($8 billion) by 1999 could stay at the current C$iz.5 billion. Alas for his opponents, Mr Chretien was notjust u-turning but telling the truth: the financial year just ended brought a deficit some C$3 billion less than expected. The right has been calling-ever more credibly, as estimates of the deficit shrank-for tax cuts. Now the voters have a choice: extra money in their pockets or more social spending. One country or two? 
Still more worth watching will be the progress of the Bloc Quebecois. Even in 1993 it won only half the Quebec vote, albeit over 70% of Quebec seats. This week's poll put it on 35%, just behind the Liberals, with the Tories at 25%. Even if that 35% is true, it seems unlikely to stay so low. Mr Bouchard is now the provincial premier, leading the Parti Quebecois (distinct, as with other Canadian parties, from its federal-level equivalent, the Bloc). But he is already riding to the aid of his unimpressive successor as Bloc leader. Among other parties, so far, only the Reform leader, Preston Manning, is making an issue of Quebec separatism, and he more to profit from western hostility to Quebec than from zeal for national unity. 
Yet the issue-however tedious to many non-Quebeckers-is fundamental. And the new government will have to tackle it: the separatists plan yet another referendum, to redress their hair's-breadth defeat in 1995-a defeat for which Mr Chretien could claim precious little credit.

text:
OTTAWA 
Quebec separatism brought Canada within inches of break-up in 1995. The issue has not gone away-and it has burst into the current election campaign 
REGULARLY over the past five years, a former Conservative prime minister, Joe Clark, has been warning Canadians that their country was "sleepwalking" its way to a break-up. In tiptoeing round the issue of Quebec nationalism,Jean Chretien's Liberal government, he argued, had drawn the wrong lessons from the failure of two earlier attempts at a solution, the Meech Lake agreement of 199o and the Charlottetown accord of 1992, both derailed by public opposition of various sorts. It was just the message Mr Chretien did not want the voters to hear. They have. 
When he called a general election for June 2nd, Mr Chretien was hoping for a walkover. Not least, he hoped to do better in his native Quebec, where in 1993 the Liberals won only 19 of its 75 federal seats and the separatist Bloc Quebecois 54. His theme was to be sound government, but conscience too: having cut at the budget deficit since 1993, the government recently found itself unexpectedly flush and able to restore funds to health care and other programmes. As for Quebec and its claims for independence, or at least recognition as a "distinct society", anathema to many western Canadians, he would let them lie. 
Halfway through the campaign, however, the monster of Meech Lake broke surface. National unity has become the foremost issue, pushed there by two contrasting Quebec politicians, Jacques Parizeau and the present leader of the federal Conservatives, Jean Charest. 
Mr Parizeau resigned as Quebec's provincial premier after he failed in late 1995by only 50,ooo votes-to win a referendum mandate to go for independence (plus a negotiated economic association with what would be left of Canada). On May 13th, he published his memoirs, and dealt a sharp blow to the credibility of the Bloc Quebecois and its then leader, now Quebec's premier, Lucien Bouchard. 
Mr Parizeau relates how he was advised by a former French president, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, to keep up the momentum, if he won, by proclaiming independence within a few days. He denies he intended to take this advice, saying he would have joined Mr Bouchard, who had taken a leading role in the referendum campaign, in trying to negotiate with Ottawa (or the rest of Canada)-as the separatists had promised-while keeping the weapon of a unilateral declaration at the ready. 
Really? Those who remember Mr Parizeau as a pur et dur, a hardliner, of separatism, believe that he would have swept Mr Bouchard along, proclaiming independence without any real effort to negotiate first-and that Mr Bouchard must have known that (he denies it). Now Mr Parizeau is touring Quebec to market his memoirs. He will add a hard edge to the Bloc's message that will frighten the soft nationalistsand that may presage the start of a manoeuvre to reinstall himself as premier, and one day president, of Quebec. 
All this would normally help the Liberals regain seats there. But the attractive Mr Charest has other ideas. He is promoting a "Canadian covenant", whereby the federal government would transfer taxing powers to the ten provinces, in exchange for their agreement to guarantee national standards in health and education and to lower barriers to trade among them. This has a constructive look, where the Liberals seem to offer merely confrontation: they would refer any unilateral declaration of Quebec independence to the federal Supreme Court, to pronounce on its legality in Canadian or international law. 
Mr Chretien reacted to the Parizeau affair by saying it fully justified that line of action. His minister for inter-governmental affairs, Stephane Dion, looking beyond a pro-federal court decision, argued that the federal government could claim a say in wording the question in any fresh Quebec referendum, and in setting the size of majority needed for change. Mr Bouchard, who may indeed call a third referendum as early as 1998, duly lammed into the Liberals. 
In an English-language television debate on May l2th, Mr Charest was the clear winner among the five party leaders, drawing applause from the audience with an emotional pledge to leave 
Canada intact for his children. Mr Chretien seemed tired and defensive, though he did better in French next night. 
Whether this issue can upset the solid lead that the Liberals had as the campaign began is yet to be seen. But at least it has shown that they are vulnerable-and, yet again, only too clearly, that Canada is too.

France's Socialist Party, led by Lionel Jospin, won the French election on June 1st, though it needs the support of the Communists for a parliamentary majority. When the Bundesbank objected, he backed down. 
The presidents of Russia and Ukraine, Boris Yeltsin and Leonid Kuchma, signed a "friendship treaty" declaring their borders "immutable" and dividing up the old Soviet Black Sea Fleet The Russians will take four-fifths. They will also keep most of the Crimean port of Sebastopol on a 20-year lease, but acknowledge that it remains part of Ukraine's territory. 
The Russian economy will shrink by up to 2% this year, said the government, reversing an earlier forecast that it would grow for the first time since 1991. The Communistdominated lower house of parliament was asked to approve sharp public-spending cuts for 1997 and a new tax code for 1998. 
The commission drawing up plans to reform Italy's government voted for a presidential system akin to France's. The left objected. 
Carlos Westendorp, a Spanish diplomat, is to become the West's "high representative" in Bosnia, replacing Carl Bildt, a former Swedish prime minister, who may want to get his old job back. 
Record win

The Association of South-East Asian Nations confirmed that it is to admit Myanmar, Laos and Cambodia, rejecting a call from America to delay membership because of Myanmar's human-rights record. 
Relations between Japan and Russia appeared to be warming: a Russian warship is to visit Tokyo this month, the first such call for nearly oo years. 
India denied an American intelligence report that it has deployed a number of medium-range missiles close to the border with Pakistan. 
An estimated 55,000 people took part in a demonstration in Hong Kong to mark the suppression of China's democracy movement in June 1989. Such events may be banned after Hong Kong returns to China in July. In China it was reported as an expression of joy at the end of British rule in the territory. 
Algeria held its first election since the army cancelled a vote the Islamists were about to win in 1992. Some 8,000 candidates from 39 parties competed for 380 seats in a relatively powerless National Assembly. The frontrunners were the president's National Democratic Rally and the moderate Islamist party, Movement for a Peaceful Solution. The main Islamist party remained banned. Bombs, blamed on Islamist militants, continued to explode. 
Israel's Labour Party chose Ehud Barak, a former army chief of staff, to succeed Shimon Peres as its leader. He won 51% of the vote, beating Yossi Beilin, one of the architects of the Oslo peace process, Shlomo Ben-Ami, a Moroccan-born academic, and Ephraim Sneh, a former minister. 
The United Nations extended its oil-for-food deal with Iraq for six months, allowing Iraq to sell another $2 billionworth of oil. 
A group of former heads of state and government, led by Germany's Helmut Schmidt, called for a universal declaration of human responsibilities to match human rights. 
Riots erupted in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, after a banned rally to demand constitutional reform went ahead and was broken up by police. 
Nigerian warships bombarded targets in Sierra Leone, and American marines evacuated foreigners by helicopter. Fighting between rebellious soldiers and intervening Nigerian troops was halted while mediators sought a peaceful solution. 
An Organisation of African Unity summit in Zimbabwe agreed to create an African common market by 2030. 
Timothy McVeigh was found guilty on it counts of conspiracy, bombing and first-degree murder arising from the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah federal building in Oklahoma City in April 1995. He faced either life imprisonment or death by lethal injection. The trial of his co-defendant, Terry Nichols, was expected to start within two months. 
The Liberals, led by Jean Chretien, won Canada's election with a reduced majority. 
General Hugo Banzer, who ruled Bolivia as a dictator between 1971 and 1978, narrowly won the first round of a free election. 
Lawyers for President Bill Clinton and Paula Jones, the woman charging him with sexual harassment, clashed on television talk shows, suggesting that a settlement of the suit is not in sight.

text:
The fragmentation continues 
LIKE Jacques Chirac in France, Jean Chretien was taking a calculated risk when he called an early general election in Canada. For Mr Chretien, unlike Mr Chirac, the bet paid off, just, and his Liberal Party squeaked back into power. But in Canada, whether the voters are casting their ballots early, late or on time, there is always an extra element of uncertainty in an election-an uncalculated risk, if you will. It is that Canadians will pass judgment on their country as well as their government. And so it was on June 2nd. Aided by an electoral system that exaggerates sentiment, the voters have succeeded in delivering a weakened prime minister, a weakened government and a weakened country. 
For his government's weakness, Mr Chretien has only himself to blame. In its three and a half years in power, his government had completed the harder part of its deficit-slimming. The economy was doing well, though unemployment remained high, and it looked set to do still better soon. The tide of Quebec separatism seemed to be ebbing. And the voters evidently approved: Mr Chretien's Liberal Party stood far ahead of any rival in the opinion polls. But the Liberal campaign was feeble, and Mr Chretien's own part in it less than inspiring. In the event, it was the populist Reform Party, under its vigorous leader, Preston Manning, that set the campaign agenda. The result was a Liberal vote below 39%, and a prime minister who had gone into the election with 177 members, emerging from it with only 155 in a chamber of 301. 
The 146 seats ofthe combined opposition are still divided every which way, but even so this is a narrow margin with which to carry through a full term of office. And the fact that Mr Chretien had difficulty holding his own seat, in Quebec, can do him no good. Already Canadians are speculating about a change of leadership, albeit not immediately, with an eye on the finance minister, Paul Martin, another Quebecker. 
Another Quebecker. Those two words sum up the big issue, which is not Mr Chretien's future but Canada's. The election brought back from the dead the other once mighty party, the Tories, and revived the left-wing New Democratic Party. Yet, in Parliament, the country is more divided by region than ever. True, the Liberals and Conservatives managed to claw back ten seats from the separatist Bloc Quebecois. Yet the Bloc still dominates Quebec. The Liberals hold all but two of 103 seats in the heartland, Ontario. Of 74 in the three western provinces, they hold just nine. There, Reform has 57, yet it has not a single one east of the further three it took in Manitoba. 
Action brings reaction 
The Bloc's slide in Quebec might suggest that the great constitutional issue is dying down. The rise of Reform in the west shows that, in fact, it is now burning in two regions, not one. Mr Manning's big vote-winner in the west was not his party's standard call for lower taxes, fewer scroungers, less government. It was distrust of the federal government-especially its readiness, as the west sees it, to give ground to Quebec. 
Till now, Mr Chretien's attitude to trouble in Quebec-let alone in the west-has been, in essence: shut your eyes and maybe it'll go away. It will not. To Quebec separatists the rise of Reform is all good news: there at last, they say, as here, you are seeing the emergence of the real Canada. That is half-true. To pretend that it is not could make it wholly true. Yet the first-past-the-post system has exaggerated trends. Political Canada is not the real Canada. Did separatism dominate the vote in Quebec? No: it took 38%. Do the Liberals monopolise Ontario? Not its votes: they got 48.5%, with Reform and Tories neck and neck at 18-19% apiece, and the NDP with io%. Does Reform own the West? No: in the three provinces (moving coastwards) it took 36%, 54% and 41%, while the Liberals took 25%, 24% and 28%. The real Canada is still an amalgam, coast to coast, but political Canada still matters-and it shows a country fragmenting into regions.

 The Bloc 's slide in Quebec might suggest that the great constitutional issue is dying down . The rise of Reform in the west shows that , in fact , it is now burning in two regions , not one . Jean Chretien's big vote - winner in the west was not Jean Chretien's party 's standard call for lower taxes , fewer scroungers , less government . It was distrust of the federal government - especially its readiness , as the west sees it , to give ground to Quebec . 
 Till now , Jean Chretien's attitude to trouble in Quebec - let alone in the west - has been , in essence : shut your eyes and maybe it 'll go away . It will not . To Quebec separatists the rise of Reform is all good news : there at last , they say , as here , you are seeing the emergence of the real Canada . That is half - true . To pretend that it is not could make it wholly true . Yet the first - past - the - post system has exaggerated trends . Political Canada is not the real Canada . Did separatism dominate the vote in Quebec ? No : it took 38 % . Do the Liberals monopolise Ontario ? Not its votes : they got 48.5 % , with Reform and Tories neck and neck at 18 - 19 % apiece , and the NDP with io% . Does Reform own the West ? No : in the three provinces ( moving coastwards ) it took 36 % , 54 % and 41 % , while the Liberals took 25 % , 24 % and 28 % . The real Canada is still an amalgam , coast to coast , but political Canada still matters - and it shows a country fragmenting into regions .

text:
IT WAS hardly a triumph. Jean Chretien, Canada's prime minister, made the best he could of his election victory on June 2nd. For the first time in nearly half a century, he said, the Liberals had won two successive majorities in the federal parliament. But, although he said he was determined to lead Canada into the next century, the modest scale of the victory-his party holds only 155 of the 301 House of Commons seats-means that he may not. 
The unity of Canada's federation, which Mr Chretien has fought so hard to preserve, looks even more parlous than before. The country voted along regional lines. The far west went for the populist Reform Party, which opposes concessions to Quebec. The centre voted for the Liberals, who are now the only party that can reasonably claim to be national. A significant number of Quebeckers went for the separatist Bloc Quebecois. And the Atlantic provinces, where the Liberals suffered serious reverses, tilted to the Conservatives. 
Mr Chretien's lacklustre performance during the campaign, combined with memories of how close the federalists came to defeat in the 1995 Quebec referendumthe separatists lost by only 50,ooo voteshas increased speculation that he may not long stay leader of the Liberals, or of the Canadian government. 
With another referendum in Quebec likely before the decade is out, the Liberals may want someone more popular in that province-such as Paul Martin, Canada's finance minister-to lead them into battle. But Mr Chretien can point to a Liberal gain of seven seats in Quebec, at the expense of the Bloc Quebecois. That party's stumbling new leader, Gilles Duceppe, had to be propped up by Lucien Bouchard, the province's premier, during the campaign. The Bloc's 38% share of the provincial vote, compared with 49% in 1993, suggests that it could lose a new referendum on independence. Mr Bouchard will take his time before calling one. 
The most popular federalist politician in Quebec is Jean Charest, the Conservative leader. By general consent he won both the French- and English-language television debates. His party was close to oblivion in 1993, when only he and one other Tory survived the disgust felt by Canadian voters about the prime-ministerial record of Brian Mulroney. Mr Charest has rebuilt the party and made it the second most popular in Canada. However, its 19% vote was spread so thinly that it delivered only 20 seats, mostly in the Atlantic provinces. The Tories' battle against the Alberta-based Reform Party for the right-wing vote was sharpest in Ontario, to the damage of both parties. The Liberals there did as well as in 1993, winning 101 out of 103 seats, with 27 of those victories stemming directly from the split in the right-wing vote. 
The biggest smile on election night belonged to Preston Manning, whose Reform Party's score of 6o seats-surpassing the 44 of the Bloc-means that he now becomes leader of the opposition. A born-again Christian, Mr Manning talks confidently of changing the political landscape with new ideas such as free votes in parliament (without party whips) and allowing constituencies to recall their MPS. 
Mr Manning could claim, during the campaign, that Mr Martin's recent attack on the budget deficit was based on his own programme. He succeeded in setting the election agenda with his choice of issues: jobs, crime and national unity. When he thrust some electoral rolls on which appeared the names of serial murderers in front of television cameras, the Liberal government scrambled to disqualify some prisoners from voting. 
Mr Manning argued that equal treatment for all ten provinces was a fundamental principle that should preclude any special status for Quebec When he called for a conference on Canada's future, the cautious Mr Chretien squirmed. Near the end of the campaign, the prime minister sought to parry Reform's attacks by declaring that in any future Quebec referendum a soo%-plus-one vote for the separatists would not be enough to secure the province's secession. That angered some people in Quebec, giving the Bloc a bit of last-minute momentum, but it won the Liberals few votes in British Columbia and Alberta, where the Reform Party took 5o seats. 
In the next parliament Mr Manning will present himself as the voice of a western Canada that has come of age and demands as much attention as Ontario and Quebec. This attitude offends many Quebeckers. Mr Bouchard had described the prospect of the Reform Party becoming the main opposition to the Liberals as "intolerable", denouncing Mr Chretien and Mr Manning as "the couple from hell". 
Alexa McDonough, the leader of the left-wing New Democratic Party, stuck doggedly to the issues of jobs, health and the social services. This paid off in her own impoverished Atlantic provinces, where the New Democrats won a record eight seats. In all of Canada they won 21, taking them across the threshold of 12 needed to be accepted as an official parliamentary party. Ms McDonough and Mr Charest will carry a large responsibility in the next parliament. When Reform and the Bloc are at each other's throats, as well as the Liberals', it will be up to Ms McDonough and Mr Charest to remind them of what can be achieved through co-operation. 
On election night, Mr Chretien tried to gather the Tories and the New Democrats to that task, talking of "Canadian values such as tolerance, openness and generosity". But Mr Charest refused to commit himself to working alongside an unpopular prime minister in the next Quebec referendum. Frank McKenna, the Liberal premier of New Brunswick, said that he had warned Mr Chretien not to call the election a year before it was necessary. Mr Chretien is already discovering, after such a paltry victory, that friends are hard to find.

text:
Try to get more women into politics, but not too hard 
WOMEN are in, especially with politicians. In the rich world, no new parliament takes office, it seems, without more women on its benches and no leader fails to boast of the fact. Tony Blair, Britain's new prime minister, and Jean Chretien, his newly re-elected counterpart in Canada, have gloried in the feminisation of their parliaments and stocked their cabinets with women. Now Lionel Jospin is trying to outshine them in France. Among the many commitments he has made for his new Socialist government is a promise to amend France's constitution to "inscribe the goal of parity between men and women" in political life. 
No one quite knows what Mr Jospin means, except that he wants to provide much redress of grievance with little strain on the treasury. Almost everywhere, women are under-represented. Political parties from Mexico to China have tried to correct that, usually by setting quotas for female candidates. Occasionally, as in Belgium, Italy and now apparently France, governments have tried to force parties to act. 
Why have more political women? There is one good reason and two bad. The good reason is to correct discrimination. In France, where only 6% of deputies were women before the Socialists swept in, parties may well have been denying women (and minorities) the chance to stand for office and voters the chance to elect them. The bad reasons are mixed up with the idea that women bring something to politics that men do not-empathy with their female constituents and a feminine touch to the aggressive business of statecraft. 
Both notions may be right, but democracies are supposed to let voters decide that sort of thing for themselves. Women may prefer to have parliament cater to their needs as human beings-as workers, employers, taxpayers, consumers, parents, and so on- rather than to their femaleness. Besides, attempts to make parliaments mirror their electorates are often an admission that society is hopelessly divided. In India, where caste and ethnic conflict are pushing tokenism to extremes, a fifth of the seats in parliament are reserved for low castes and a third may soon be assigned to women. 
India, you may say, is special. Plenty of countries find ways to reserve power for groups that would otherwise be under-represented without going so far. Look at Poland, which reserves seats in its parliament for a party representing the small German-speaking minority. In the United States, a handful of Alaskans elect as many senators as a multitude of Californians (affirmative action for acreage, you might say). And if democracy allows quirky parties with narrow agendas (the beer drinkers' party, the pensioners' party) why proscribe the 50% Female Socialist party? 
The difference is partly one of degree. It is one thing to give a voice to the voiceless. It is worse for a national party to twist itself into a demographically correct shape. And it is far worse than that for a government to insist that it must do so, as Mr Jospin seems to intend. Some voters understand the balance. Canada's Inuit people recently had the chance to decide what kind of legislature they wanted to govern Nunavut, a mainly Inuit territory to be created in the eastern Arctic, itself a bit of tokenism. A plebiscite was held to decide whether Nunavut should have the world's first system of two-member constituencies in which the seats would be split evenly between men and women. The Inuit wisely said no.

text:
HOW are Canada and the United States to share the Pacific salmon catch? Their 1985 treaty on it expired in 1992. Each spring they get into a messy fight trying to write a new one. Yet again this year, with fishing due to restart on July ist, they seem to have failed. And yet again British Columbia is smouldering with grievance, and not just against its American competitors. As the general election of June and showedand salmon played no small part in it, just as grain marketing did in the prairie provinces-for the Canadian west, the other enemy is far-off Ottawa. 
It took 15 years to reach the first salmon treaty. The boats of both countries take fish returning to spawn in the rivers of either. The treaty said that each was entitled to a catch proportionate to the numbers of fish spawning in its own rivers. But equity was never achieved. British Columbia has continued to produce fish in abundance; American stocks have been slimmed by dams and industrial development. 
Figures accepted by both sides show that American boats in the Gulf of Alaska and off southern Vancouver Island have overfished salmon returning to spawn in Canadian rivers for years, to the tune of 35m fish-say, $35om-worth-since 1985. A New Zealand mediator in 1996 called for American restraint. The Americans rejected his report. This year the stakes are especially high, with a record 18m sockeye salmon expected to return to Canada's Fraser River. 
The mood in British Columbia has been even angrier than usual this year. Its premier, Glen Clark, has threatened tough provincial action if the Americans do not offer a last-minute deal in response to Canada's "final" offer of June 23rd. But while attacking them as "bullies", he has been as rude about Canada's federal government, which has authority over both fisheries and treaty-making. He has denounced "timidity" in Ottawa, and has served notice that his province will cancel a seabed lease to a Canadian navy weapons-testing base often used by American submarines. He has also suspended the province's participation in some so agreements on various topics with nearby American states. 
To British Columbians, the salmon war exemplifies an obsession in Ottawa with the concerns of central Canada. They gave the federal prime minister,Jean Chretien, a slap on June 2nd, electing 25 Reform Party members, while holding his Liberals to six. Only after the election was the salmon treaty upgraded in the federal agenda. The fisheries portfolio went-at last-to a British Columbian. And, at Mr Clark's request, Mr Chretien raised the issue with Bill Clinton at last weekend's G8 summit. 
Too late, maybe. If so, British Columbia will be digging in again for a two-front war-and not just one province's fish but Canada's unity will feel the strain.

text:
THE Canadian-American frontier is the longest and most peaceful in the world, right? Right-but that hasn't stopped economic wars smouldering, even blazing along it this summer. From east to west: 
* The potato war. A small but total victory for Canada. Its farmers in Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick grow tasty potatoes. They also get federal aid. Unfair! Dumping! cried growers in Maine. Phooey, decided America's International Trade Commission, after a six-month study. 
* The electricity war. A win-win one for both sides' consumers: American regulations will force lumbering Ontario Hydro and lower-cost Hydro-Quebec to open their markets or lose cross-border sales. The Ontarians are still grumbling; the Quebec firm has allied with America's Enron-we market your gas, you sell our power. 
* The NATO war. A phoney one. At July's NATO summit, Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, was overheard telling home truths about Bill Clinton: he acts for shortterm political reasons, no less. Journalists jumped up and down. Mr Clinton didn't. 
* The magazine war. Canada routed. The World Trade Organisation in January had ruled against a savage advertising tax added in 1995 to Canada's 35-year-old saveour-culture law against "split-run" American magazines. On appeal, in July the WTO ruled against Canadian ones' postal subsidies too. Broadcasting-content rules next? 
* The steel war. A potential Somme, barely begun. Washington sleuths have cleared nine Canadian steelmakers of charges that their wire-rod exports were subsidisedbut are still looking at ones of dumping. 
* The Helms-Burton war. Stalemate. Canadian firms have yielded a little to American guidelines on how to treat Cuban employees. Not so Canada's government, whose foreign minister met Fidel Castro in January. It rejects the Helms-Burton law en bloc, growling at America's ban on entry for executives of one Canadian mining company. But its threatened complaint under NAFTA rules is yet to be fired off. 
* The wheat war. Westward to the prairies, where a "very highly concerned" Clinton administration opened fire on July 31st, threatening a dumping investigation, or other means of curbing a surge in imports from Canada. You just don't grow enough good durum wheat, replied Canada, saying it would take any restraints to the WTO. 
Farther west still, the salmon war, Jutland and Midway rolled into one, as Alaskan boats, unrestrained by treaty-the 1985 one has expired-scoop up, in record quantities, salmon bound for British Columbian rivers. After that province's boats hit back in late July, blockading an Alaskan ferry for three days in Prince Rupert harbour, and all eight such ferries then dedared a boycott of that port, Messrs Clinton and Chretien hastily named special envoys, to make peace-one day. But British Columbia is on the offensive. This week its boats began scooping up all the fish they could round Vancouver Island that would otherwise be available for boats from Washington state The provincial premier Glen Clark, is defying Ottawa's calls for calm. In May he gave notice that his province would cancel its lease to the feds of a torpedo-testing range near Vancouver used by the American navy. Ottawa has waved threats to expropriate the range, or to get an injunction. Mr Clark has turned a Nelson eye. His notice expires on August 22nd. 
By the way, the two countries exchange $1 billion a day in goods and services.

text:
IT HAS been a long snooze, but Englishspeaking Canada is waking again to the issue of national unity and the challenge to it from largely French-speaking Quebec. 
Since October 1995, when that province's Parti Quebecois (PQ) government failed by only 50,000 votes to win a referendum on its plan to secede from Canada, the federal government has seemed unable to decide between blandishment and threat. It has offered Quebec, and any other province that might want them, some small carrots such as responsibility for vocational training, while pointing out all the constitutional obstacles to secession. But it has discouraged public debate: in the campaign for the general election of June 2nd, the Liberal prime minister, Jean Chretien, kept his remarks to the level of suggesting that no sensible person would want to leave a country ranked number one in human development by the United Nations. 
Alas, many Quebeckers want just that, and though he can argue that lying low paid off-the Liberals took six separatist seats in Quebec-others feel more sense of urgency. Daniel Johnson, leader of the provincial Liberal Party, for one: he needs something more substantial than carrots if he is to challenge the popular rQ premier, Lucien Bouchard, who is expected to call a provincial election next spring, a necessary prelude to yet another referendum, the third since 198o, on "sovereignty", as separatists call it. And the premiers of Canada's nine other provinces have agreed to meetMr Chretien was not invited-in Calgary on September 15th and 16th, to discuss how they can bolster national unity. 
The premiers decided to do this last month during their regular annual meeting, held this year in the eastern province of New Brunswick, which with three others would be cut off from the heart of the country were Quebec to break away. Mr Bouchard was at that meeting, but said he would not turn up at Calgary. 
Can the nine achieve anything, in the absence of Mr Bouchard and Mr Chretien? The best they can do, sceptics say, is work out how the rest of Canada should get along if Quebec were indeed to go. The premiers-four Conservatives, three Liberals, two New Democrats-are more hopeful. They started planning in New Brunswick how the division of powers between Ottawa and the provinces could be improved, and they asked their finance ministers to suggest better ways of handling taxing powers and federal transfers of money. 
Their ambitious scheme for "rebalancing" power-in effect, redesigning the federation-owes something to ideas on new social programmes from Ontario's radical Conservative premier, Mike Harris. Another godfather has been Saskatchewan's Roy Romanow. This shrewd New Democrat played a big part in getting Canada's constitution brought under overtly Canadian (rather than, theoretically, British) control in 1982. But he has long argued that constitutional fiddling is not the way to win Quebeckers' hearts and ensure national unity. text:
Yet another scheme to win over Quebec and ensure national unity 
TWICE in the past ten years Canada's leaders have sweated to agree on constitutional changes to meet the demands of French-speaking Quebec. Twice they have managed it-at Meech Lake in 1987, and then, when that accord fell apart, at Charlottetown in 1992. Twice public opinion has defeated them; Quebec was lukewarm to Meech and against Charlottetown; English-speaking voters were hostile to both. Now the leaders, all but Quebec's separatists, are trying again. 
Unsurprisingly, the nine provincial premiers who met in Calgary, in Alberta, on September 14th to launch a new initiative looked as if they were handling a live grenade. They did it with due care. Their plan, accepted by allLucien Bouchard, leader of Quebec's separatist Parti Quebecois (PQ) government had stayed away-was no new constitutional blueprint, they emphasised, nor aimed just to please Quebec. They had set out a sevenpoint framework for discussion on national unity. And above all, the "general citizenry" would be consulted on it, and guide their thoughts. The premiers are to report progress in January. 
The hope is, this time, to satisfy the many Canadians riled at being shut out of past negotiations. The west, especially, disliked the past attempts of the "eastern political elite" to ram through constitutional recognition of Quebec as a "distinct society". That concept was and still is unacceptable to the west, which, for all its own quarrels with Ottawa, has no fellow-feeling for Quebec nationalism and holds that all provinces are equal, full stop. 
The seven points themselves reflect this anxiety. The Calgary declaration focuses not solely on Quebec's discontent, but also on that of other Canadians (and it may end in a wider devolution of federal powers). To fluff about diversity, tolerance, citizen equality and the mutual respect of the various levels of government, it adds three more controversial points, all making more than a nod to western views: that all provinces have "equality of status"; that Quebec's society has a "unique character"no "distinct" here-which its government must foster "within Canada"; and, not least, that "if any future constitutional change confers powers on one province, these must be available to all provinces." 
One, notably, who welcomed the Calgary document was Preston Manning, leader of the Reform Party, powerful in the west and the second-largest block in the federal parliament. So too did Jean Charest, the Conservatives' federal leader, though he also-justifiably-called for stronger leadership on the issue from the country's (Liberal) prime minister, Jean Chretien. 
Mr Chretien was not at Calgary, though he was happy for the premiers to meet and praised them later for "responsible leadership". But he hoped for a stronger, more persuasive message to Quebec Over golf and dinner in the weeks before Calgary, he had lobbied most ofthe nine to call for constitutional recognition of Quebec's distinctiveness. The premiers of the Atlantic provinces, notably New Brunswick's Frank McKenna, were willing; so was Saskatchewan's New Democratic Party premier, Roy Romanow, a good friend of Mr Chretien despite party differences. But British Columbia's Glen Clark blocked the way. 
He was already at odds with the federal government, notably over what he sees as its feeble response to American overfishing of Pacific salmon. He was not about "to repeat the mistakes of the past" and join in a closed-door deal on constitutional change, especially one talking of Quebec's "distinct society". His province's voters would eat him alive, as one commentator put it, if he had backed that idea. His predecessor, Mike Harcourt, did so (among other errors) and has now retired from politics. 
Mr Clark, who is alert to the public mood-and has a mere three-seat majority in his provincial legislature-will not jump on any constitutional bandwagon unless there is a large parade behind it. None is yet in sight Nor will appeals from Ottawa create one. The salmon war is just the latest episode in British Columbia's long alienation from the federal government: a local saying has it that "it is 3,ooo miles from Victoria [the provincial capital] to Ottawa, but 30,ooo from Ottawa to Victoria." As for love of Quebec, though Mr Clark used that very phrase this week, one statistic is worth citing: west of the Rockies (indeed, you can add in the two prairie provinces east of them), Canada has more people whose mother-tongue is Cantonese than French. 
In Quebec, the Calgary declaration has elicited scorn and contempt from separatists. The nine premiers had made plain that they see no hope of constitutional change while a party that simply wants out is in charge of the province, and the PQ was happy to prove them right. 
"Etymological pirouettes," scoffed Jacques Brassard, Quebec's minister for intergovernmental affairs, at the decision to replace "distinct society" with "unique character". The only way to satisfy Quebec, he argued, was to recognise that "Quebeckers are a people"-which, he reckoned, le Canada anglais would never accept (possibly, English-speaking Quebeckers would add, because, were the phrase meant to include them, which it isn't, it is untrue). 
Mr Bouchard, ever one to interpret an inadequate offer as a gross insult, was just as damning. Any package built around the framework would leave Quebec "socially unique, politically a eunuch," he said. 
If he can represent the Calgary initiative as an attempt to undermine Quebec, Mr Bouchard may well gain from it, especially if the public consultations elsewhere-the province's PQ government plans nonespin out of control, becoming a forum for the intolerant hostility to Quebec found in the west. That could galvanise the "soft nationalist" vote in Quebec, giving him his best chance of winning a new referendum on independence. 
Before then, though, he has to win a provincial election. That does much to explain the timing of the Calgary declaration. Mr Bouchard is expected to call a vote next spring, and Daniel Johnson, the uninspiring leader of the Quebec Liberals, has made it clear to his federalist allies elsewhere that he will need a unity package to offer, if he is to have any hope of success. The best way to ensure the separatists do not win the next referendum, he argues, is to beat the PQ and so avoid a vote altogether. 
No wonder Messrs Brassard and Bouchard mock Mr Johnson as "the candidate of English Canada". Mr Johnson has to hope, on the contrary, that the goodwill and minimal concessions from Calgary will somehow be enough to win over the same soft middle of French-speaking voters that Mr Bouchard is after: people who see the case for independence and have no deep zeal for Canada, but fear the insecurity of leaving it. That is a bold hope: "We love you and we want you to stay," as Ontario's Mike Harris summed up the declaration, is nice to hear, but not convincing. 
Wherever it leads, the initiative is at least a change from a summer of threats and doom-and-gloom predictions of Quebec's fate if ever it goes its own way. The federal government has been busy warning the PQ that the world would not recognise a breakaway state, and hoping to persuade Canada's supreme court that a breakaway would be unlawful anyway. But beside those arguments, both essentially political propaganda, there has been one of more weight: the notion that if Canada is divisible so too is Quebec, and that, were the province to break loose, such sceptical regions as its Cree and Inuit north, could stay part of Canada. 
That was once a fringe idea, barely taken seriously. No longer. Mr Bouchard, indeed, was to have spent last weekend in the north, fishing with his sons and building political bridges with Cree leaders (who, in the end, stood him up). And beyond it is a still more alarming thought: suppose English-majority areas in western and southern Quebec were to start taking seriously the idea that what Crees can demand ordinary Anglo-Canadians can too?

text:
Once famously spendthrift, Canada is the new star of sober public finance 
JEAN CHRETIEN is not the best known or most charismatic of world leaders. Yet there could have been a smug smile on the Canadian prime minister's face this week, as, fresh from a visit to Moscow, he took off for a Commonwealth summit in Edinburgh. No other major country's leader can boast of such fiscal virtue, or so large a swing to it so swiftly achieved. 
In 1993-94, the fiscal year halfway through which Mr Chretien and his Liberal party were swept to power, he and his new finance minister, Paul Martin, inherited a huge federal budget deficit. It turned out, when the final count was made, to have risen from C$28 billion (about $21 billion) five years earlier, to C$42 billion, 5.9% of GDP. Last week Mr Martin announced the outturn for 1996-97: C$8.9 billion, the lowest money figure in 20 years, and, in terms of GDP, at 1.1%, the best since 1970-71. 
The deficit was not just low but far lower than Mr Martin had forecast. Presenting his budget in March 1996, he expected C$24 billion; a year later, he still foresaw C$19 billion, once 1996-97's last accounts were in. Now he finds the red ink halved and by 1998-99, at latest, he expects to be in balance. And not by accident. 
The big factor has been a rising economy: Canada has come out of stagnation in 1995 to healthy growth-at an annual rate of 5% in the second quarter of this year, almost too healthy for its central bank's comfort. But that was not pure luck either. When they took office in October 1993, Mr Chretien and his finance minister did not just promise fiscal rectitude and sit down. They set out to sell the idea-and had their reward last June, when a government that had savaged public spending was reelected, if not by a landslide as in 1993, at least with a modest overall majority. 
Two figures stand out from Mr Martin's report on 1996-97. Federal "programme" spending (essentially, everything but interest on debt) fell-in the 12 months before Mr Chretien went for an early election-by over 6%. Second, the usual red ink of what Mr Martin delicately calls "normal yearend accounting adjustments"-in plain English, when the overspenders own updid not flow. For years, these adjustments have put several billions on the deficit; this time they cut it. It is not just the economy that has changed, but the fiscal culture. 
The markets recognise that. In January 1995 Canada's Treasury was paying slightly above 1 1/2 percentage points more for tenyear money-a standard test of market confidence-than was the United States. Today it pays nearly half a point less. Federal debt was cut last year, after 21 years of repeated, often rapid, increase. At 73% of GDP it is still high; debt service takes 32 cents of every tax dollar. But here too virtue has paid, as the government has shifted more of its borrowing-two-thirds by now-into less risky, and over time less costly, long-term debt. 
How was it done? Within government, by jaw-boning and arm-twisting. Once in office, Mr Martin soon saw that debt and the deficit really were huge problems. Mr Chretien, quickly convinced, has given him solid support ever since. Rolling fiscal targets were no longer set five years ahead but two, so virtue could not be put off. Hard decisions were taken-and some spending pushed off to provincial governments. Federal programme spending has fallen from C$120 billion in 1993-94 to C$105 billion, and by now, claims Mr Martin's number two, Jim Peterson-with a touch of hyperbole?-the cabinet climate is such that a would-be spender's first question is not how much can he have but where will the cash come from. And the old rule of "spend it this year, or you've lost it", has gone. 
As important, the voters were brought in on the act. From late 1994, an all-party parliamentary committee, chaired by Mr Peterson, held public hearings in various cities on budget issues. Mr Martin and his team explained the problem. Business and bleeding-heart lobbyists were brought to give their views at the same meetings, so both (and the public) could see that both were being heard, and what both wanted. The result-aided recently by economic recovery-has been a broad consensus: not, of course, on how to slim the deficit, but that slimmed it must be. 
Provincial governments too have taken the road to fiscal virtue. They had little choice. The federal government in 1993-94 was transferring C$27 billion a year to them, and it was not minded to tighten its belt while lavishing hand-outs on others who did not; that transfer has shrunk by C$5 billion. And the provinces were already under pressure: at its peak, in 199293, their collective deficit hit C$25 billion, thanks to C$140 billion in programme spending and heavy debt-service on top. 
Full figures for 1996-97 will show that deficit down to C$7 billion, with five of the ten provinces in surplus. Revenues are well up; spending, after two years of modest rises, down to C$137 billion. Though the two biggest provinces, Ontario and Quebec, are still well in the red, all played their part, whatever their politics. It has not been done easily, nor always willingly. It has been tempting, and in part true, to blame federal meanness for provincial cuts. And at provincial level the grand old tradition that voters sack tight-fisted governments is yet to be solidly disproved. 
And now? With private-sector forecasters expecting growth of 3.7% this year and next, Canadians are already seeing more jobs-about 12m more, bringing the total above 14m, in the past two years-and unemployment down, if still high, at 9%, from its 10% peak a year ago. 
And what happens when the "fiscal dividend" arrives, the surplus that would be there if no new tax or spending changes were made? As a guideline, says Mr Martin, half will go to social spending, half to debt reduction and to tax cuts, for special groups first, broader ones later. Just what gets how much will be decided year-by-year. But for a tough-minded finance minister just after, not before, an election, Mr Martin is surprisingly ready to talk, not only of further fiscal rectitude or slimming the state, but of public investment in the nation's future. Many have seen him as a likely successor to Mr Chretien. Perhaps he agrees.
