text:
Canada's right 
Unity, slowly 
OTTAWA 
IN A general election in 1997, Canada's two main right-wing parties, Reform and the Progressive Conservatives, shared 38% of the vote between them, a similar proportion to that obtained by the governing Liberal Party. But whereas the Liberals won 155 of the 301 seats in the House of Commons, giving a second term to the prime minister, Jean Chretien, Reform managed only 60 and the Conservatives just Zo. Fears that the next election might have a similar outcome led Preston Manning, Reform's leader, to launch a crusade aimed at creating a single right-of-centre party at the federal level, to be called the United Alternative. Yet powerful as the electoral logic of unity might be, so is the hesitation about Mr Manning's proposal. 
In a referendum of Reform members held earlier this month, 60.5% of those voting backed the United Alternative. Mr Manning has taken this as a green light to proceed. But is it? Despite much prodding from party officials, under half of Reform's 64,580 members voted-and only 1,119 of them in the five provinces east of Ontario. Meanwhile, Conservative victories in provincial elections in Ontario and New Brunswick this month do not necessarily help Mr Manning's campaign to "unite the right". Joe Clark, the federal Conservative leader, is a steadfast opponent of the United Alternative. 
Reform's strength is in Canada's west. Mr Manning, who founded the party as a populist movement in 1987, is the son of a former premier of Alberta (and an evangelical preacher). But even in Alberta and British Columbia, over a third of those voting rejected Mr Manning's project, apparently fearing that it would dilute the party's principles, especially family values, greater accountability of MPS to their electors, and reform of the federal Senate. This last plank appeals to the country's westerners, who want an elected and more powerful chamber in which each of the ten provinces would have equal representation, instead of the present appointed body, which they see as dominated by prime-ministerial nominees from Quebec and Ontario. 
The Reform Party swept western Canada for the first time in the 1993 election, when the Liberals routed the Conservative govemment. In 1997, though Reform added to its seats and became the official opposition, its share of the popular vote stalled at 19%. In Ontario, Canada's most populous province, the right's division meant that the Liberals took all but two of the 103 seats. 
If Ontario is the key to the fortunes of Canada's right, the province's newly reelected Conservative premier, Mike Harris, is happy to be clutching it. The Reform Party does not compete in provincial elections (except in British Columbia), so Mr Harris faced a clear run on the right in Ontario's poll on June 3rd. But the 45% share of the vote won by the Conservatives went well beyond the core support of both right-wing parties, and owed much to Mr Harris's personality. That might give him a strong claim to lead the United Alternative, if it ever succeeds in becoming a formal party. Mr Harris, however, lacks rapport with French-speaking Quebec, and may prefer to remain on his home turf as a kingmaker. 
The initiative may lie with Mr Clark. He has argued that Reform has reached its ceiling-and its geographical frontier. After the referendum, he invited Reform members (he meant the dissatisfied ones) to help his federal Conservatives draft policy at their convention in September. He has also accepted in principle a scheme for joint candidates in some Ontario constituencies at the next federal election. For Mr Manning this is Plan B, a retreat from-or only a small step towardsforming a new party. But he has a harder hand to play than Mr Clark. In developing policies for the putative United Alternative, Mr Manning must reassure Reform fundamentalists while attracting more centrists. Some doubters have rallied to him since the vote, but time is running out. The Liberals, with or without Mr Chretien at their head, are likely to call an election in 200.

This last plank appeals to the country 's westerners , who want an elected and more powerful chamber in which each of the ten provinces would have equal representation , instead of the present appointed body , which they see as dominated by prime - ministerial nominees from Quebec and Ontario . 
 The Reform Party swept western Canada for the first time in the 1993 election , when the Liberals routed the Conservative govemment . In 1997 , though Reform added to its seats and became the official opposition , its share of the popular vote stalled at 19 % . In Ontario , Canada 's most populous province , the right 's division meant that the Liberals took all but two of the 103 seats . 
 If Ontario is the key to the fortunes of Canada 's right , the province 's newly reelected Conservative premier , Mike Harris , is happy to be clutching it . The Reform Party does not compete in provincial elections ( except in British Columbia ) , so Mr Harris faced a clear run on the right in Ontario 's poll on June 3rd . But the 45 % share of the vote won by the Conservatives went well beyond the core support of both right - wing parties , and owed much to Mr Harris 's personality . That might give him a strong claim to lead the United Alternative , if it ever succeeds in becoming a formal party . Mr Harris , however , lacks rapport with French - speaking Quebec , and may prefer to remain on his home turf as a kingmaker . 
 The initiative may lie with Mr Clark . He has argued that Reform has reached its ceiling - and its geographical frontier . After the referendum , he invited Reform members ( he meant the dissatisfied ones ) to help his federal Conservatives draft policy at their convention in September . He has also accepted in principle a scheme for joint candidates in some Ontario constituencies at the next federal election . For Mr Manning this is Plan B , a retreat from - or only a small step towardsforming a new party . But he has a harder hand to play than Mr Clark . In developing policies for the putative United Alternative , Mr Manning must reassure Reform fundamentalists while attracting more centrists . Some doubters have rallied to him since the vote , but time is running out . The Liberals , with or without Jean Chretien at their head , are likely to call an election in 200 .

text:
HOW can outsiders persuade, or bludgeon, Cuba into respecting human rights? In January last year, a visit by the Pope brought the release of some prisoners, and hopes of greater liberalisation of Fidel Castro's Communist regime. Yet things such as harassment of dissidents and treatment of prisoners have not improved, and indeed in some respects have worsened. 
According to a report released this week by Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, Cubans are being jailed for an ever-increasing range of peaceful activities that are deemed disrespectful or damaging to the state. These include "dangerousness", which means showing signs (such as "anti-social conduct") of being likely to offend, even if no crime has been committed. Due process of law is often violated; courts are subordinate to the government. Prison conditions are poor; physical torture is rare, the report says, but psychological torture is common. 
This year the government has cracked down on common crime, which has been fuelled by rising inequalities in wealth induced by Cuba's attempts to replace lost Soviet support with tourism and foreign investment. The Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation, a Havana-based group, says that ten people were executed in the first three months of this year-far more than is usual. It also estimates that the jail population has grown by several thousand. But the number of political prisoners is gradually decreasing, and the Catholic church has enjoyed slightly more freedom since the Pope's visit. 
The outside world has tried various ways of getting Mr Castro's regime to soften, but none has had much success. Canada has gone furthest with "constructive engagement". Last year, Jean Chretien, Canada's prime minister, visited Cuba, and privately asked Mr Castro to release four leading dissidents who had been held for nearly a year without trial. No luck: in March, Cuba tried the four and sentenced them to stiff jail terms. Canada is now reviewing its policy, and has reduced its economic assistance. 
For the past three years, the European Union, whose members account for about half of all foreign business ventures in Cuba, has made further economic cooperation conditional on improvements in human rights. After the jailing of the four dissidents, the United Nations passed a censure motion, and Spain's royals cancelled a visit. But mutterings among South American countries that they would prefer to hold the ninth annual Ibero-American summit somewhere other than Havana this November came to nothing. 
Nor can the United States claim success for the embargo it has imposed on Cuba since 1961. This, as Human Rights Watch notes, has not only failed to bring about human-rights improvements, but has served Mr Castro as a pretext for repression. Lifting the embargo would not only rob Mr Castro of his nationalist card; it might trigger an uncontrollable flood of American investors and tourists-perhaps what Mr Castro, struggling to maintain a semblance of socialist order, most fears. President Clinton's government has taken a few timid steps to encourage more "peo ple-to-people" contact. But earlier this year, his administration rejected a pro posal for a bi-partisan commission to re examine Cuban policy. In Washington, a! in Havana, the stalemate continues.

text:
Canada many be a midget tethered to a giant, but it has no need to feel inferior. What it could do with, writes John Andrews, is some American self-confidence 
THE 19th century was the century of the United States; the 20th century will be the century of Canada." With hindsight, Wilfrid Laurier's prediction, made shortly after the 1896 election which made him Canada's first French Canadian prime minister, looks hopelessly wrong. America is moving from this century to the next as the world's only superpower, supreme in its technology, military power, commercial energy, even (dare disdainful foreigners admit it?) its culture. 
As for Canada, its dollar has sunk against the mighty greenback; businessmen and workers alike complain of high taxes; the media obsessively monitor the "brain drain" southwards of the nation's best and brightest; and at the back of everybody's mind is the thought that one day French-speaking Quebec will secede, with incalculable consequences for Canada's very existence as a nation. So forgive Sir Wilfrid's present-day successor, Jean Chretien (above), if his national pride seems a touch less strident: "We are North Americans but not Americans. We are different because of history and geography, but basically we have built a different society." 
The prime minister is right. Travel across the vast expanse of Canada, to windswept Newfoundland on the Atlantic coast, or cloud-covered Vancouver on the Pacific coast, or the ice-scape of Nunavut in the Arctic, and you discover that Canadians define their country not by what it is, but what it is not. The word they invariably use is "un-American"; the phrase they use is "kinder and gentler"-than America, naturally. They shudder at what one Canadian politician calls America's "three Gs": guns, ghettoes and gated communities. 
Instead, there is unanimous support across the political spectrum for the publicly funded system of universal health care ("We don't check your credit card in the hospital on the way to check your pulse," says Brian Tobin, premier of Newfoundland, in a dig at American health care). So too with education, where Canada's state schools, unlike America's, are generally good, and where a local student at McGill University, for example, has to pay a mere C$1,668 a year for his tuition. Everyone in Canada, it seems, likes Americans-but few want to live like them. 
Or do they? As John Kenneth Galbraith, a distinguished Canadian economist long ago embraced by the United States, once observed: "I was brought up in southwestern Ontario, where we were taught that Canadian patriotism should not withstand anything more than a five-dollar-a-month wage differential. Anything more, and you went to Detroit." 
The price of being different 
There has always been a price to pay, in lower earnings or higher taxes, for resisting the magnetic pull of America, with its huge market and its seemingly boundless opportunities for an individual with energy and initiative. But at what level does the price become too great? In global terms the Canadian economy is performing well: inflation and interest rates are comfortably low; growth this year will be the second highest among the top seven industrial economies (G7), after America, and next year it may come joint first; when federal, provincial and local accounts are added up, the nation's total govemment balance is in surplus; and unemployment has been falling, from a peak of almost 12% of the workforce at the end of 1992 to around 8% today. 
But the global comparison is, for many, beside the point. What really counts is the comparison with America, where the budget is also in surplus; where economic growth has been faster; and where the unemployment rate is only half that of Canada. If there were an ocean between Canada and America, such statistics might not matter. Instead, they share the world's longest land border, made ever more porous by ten years of a bilateral free-trade agreement and five years of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA); and by the relentless bombardment by America's Tv and radio stations, channelled into almost every Canadian home. No wonder the typical Canadian, living within 200 miles (about 300km) of the United States, feels that his standard of living is slipping behind that of his American counterpart next door. Ten years ago a Canadian dollar was worth around 84 us cents; today it is worth about 68. In other words, the price of being Canadian-of being un-American-is rising. 
This survey will argue that the price remains worth paying. In a sense Canadians have no alternative. No matter that some pundits, both Canadian and foreign, predict that Canada's provinces and territories will be inexorably transformed into a new set of American states: a country cannot unwrite its history, and Canada's history sets it very much apart from America. Whereas 18th-century Americans fought a revolution to free themselves from British rule, their Canadian contemporaries (even those who had once been French) were essentially loyalists. Indeed, in the aftermath of America's war of independence, Canada was the obvious sanctuary for those Americans in the Thirteen Colonies who had kept faith with Britain. 
That loyalty has had both political and cultural implications. Americans think of government as a necessary evil: the less of it, the better. Canadians think of government as a public good, to be judged by its efficiency rather than its size. That way of thinking makes Canadians, whatever their ethnic origins, "European" in a way that Americans inherently are not. 
Moreover, the price of being Canadian still buys something worth having. The Canadian dollar's purchasing power is well above its value on the foreign-exchange markets, giving Canada the lowest cost of living in the G7; housing is cheap; and health care (despite a few gripes) and schooling are good. 
Once more, with feeling 
But there are other, less tangible reasons too for paying the price. Canada is a less aggressive place than America at home, and shows a sense of moderation abroad ("soft power", in the oft-quoted phrase appropriated by the foreign minister, Lloyd Axworthy). During the Vietnam war, young Canadians travelling the world would put the maple leaf flag on their backpacks, lest they be mistaken for Americans; a generation later, the maple leaf still conveys the same message. And, if the world competitiveness ranking produced by Switzerland's IMD business school is to be believed, Canada is easily the safest place to live in the industrial world. It is certainly one of the most beautiful. 
Is all that enough to close what one might call "the Galbraith gap"? It would be foolish to be complacent. Last April, when two gun-wielding Colorado high-school students killed a teacher, a dozen fellow students and finally themselves, Canadians expressed the usual un-American horror at their southern neighbours, certain that such things do not happen north of the border. Unhappily they do. A week later a 14-year-old boy in Taber, Alberta, walked into his former high school, shot one student dead and wounded another. Suddenly America and Canada seemed not so different after all.

text:
The economy has been overhauled, but it still needs some fine-tuning 
FOREIGNERS tend to have a straightforward view of how Canada eams its living. It pumps out oil and gas; fells trees; dams rivers to create hydropower; grows wheat on the vast plains of Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan; and harvests salmon and other fish from the oceans. In short, it has a resource-based economy, selling raw materials and farm produce to the rest of the world and financing its comfortable welfare state from the proceeds. 
There is some truth in this generalisation. Canada can boast (though it rarely does, because boasting is not the Canadian way) of being the world's largest exporter of zinc, uranium, potash and asbestos. It is also, unsurprisingly, the biggest exporter of timber, pulp and newsprint-after all, it is the world's second biggest country by area, and a quarter of its territory is covered by forest. Moreover, it is one of the world's largest exporters of fish. 
But many Canadians find this generalisation irritating and out of date. They view the economy as being driven not by resources but by services and manufacturing. Their poster-image of Canada's ability to earn its way in the world is not the new Hibernia oil platform, some 190 miles east of Newfoundland, but the modem car-making factories and software start-ups in Toronto or the pharmaceutical firms in Montreal. Their country may be huge, but it has a mere 3om people, 85% of whom live within about 200 miles of the border with the United States, the world's biggest economy. In an era of soft commodity prices, they say, it is unwise for Canadians to rely on nature's bounty; they must seek their future in "knowledge-based" industries that serve the rest of the world. 
They have a point. It is the foreigners' perception that has weakened the Canadian dollar, mirroring the decline in commodity prices. Take the argument one step forward, and it is this foreign perception that makes Canadians the poor relations of the Americans, and so threatens to worsen the flight south of Canadian talent and energy. 
But thoughtful Canadians are less quick to blame the outside world. It is true that the resourcebased industries and agriculture together employ only 5% of the workforce, whereas manufacturing employs around 16% and the service sector nearly three-quarters. But what is just as relevant is that Canada has an economy more dependent than most on foreign trade (exports and imports are equivalent to 82% of gross domestic product, compared with 24% in the United States and 21% in Japan). Although commodities as a share of the country's exports have fallen from almost 60% in 1980, they still account for some 35%. 
The real question is whether Canada is sheltering behind its weak currency as it switches increasingly into services and manufacturing, delaying the economic and workplace reforms that would boost its productivity and hence keep it competitive even if and when its dollar rises. There is no easy answer. To the dismay of politicians such as John Manley, the industry minister, and Paul Martin, the finance minister, who are keen to keep up the pressure for economic reform, a recent OECD study found that in terms of total factor productivity, Canada was actually performing rather well. However, other studies, concentrating on labour productivity alone, show that Canada is lagging behind the southern neighbour against which it must always measure itself. The us Bureau of Labour Statistics, for example, calculates that the gap in manufacturing productivity between Canada and America in 1997 was a daunting 28%-so thank goodness for a weak currency. 
Lies, damn lies and statistics? Commonsense evidence suggests that Canada is indeed less productive than America. Otherwise, surely more of Canada's cars would be as glossy, new and expensive as America's. Last year's most popular car in the United States was the Toyota Camry, which in Canada carries a basic price tag of C$21,300; the most popular car in Canada was the Honda Civic, priced at C$15,700. As Mr Manley pointed out in a recent speech: "Most people can't afford the mid-sized car; they stay with the compact." And for good reason: the after-tax income of a Canadian family is about a third lower than in the United States. 
Home comforts 
But it is worth bearing in mind that things could have been so much worse. Canada has not become an underpopulated, underpaid provider of cheap resources to its rich neighbour. Instead, it remains an enviable place to live in, despite the commodity slump of the 1990s and despite the Asian crisis of the past three years, which has cut Canada's exports across the Pacific by a third. One reason is that the Canadian economy has echoed the astonishing boom of its American neighbour (now in its ninth year of continous expansion). Ford, Chrysler, GM, Honda, Toyota and the rest of the car and component manufacturers of the Toronto area-all of them beneficiaries of the 1965 "Auto Pact" with America, to which they export most of their output-have prospered thanks to the heroic spending habits of the American consumer. 
But there are two other reasons for Canada's success that have less to do with luck and more with good management. The first is that over the past decade Canada, under the Conservative government of Brian Mulroney, had the courage to embrace free trade, not an easy decision with the American giant lurking next door. The second is that the Liberal government of Mr Chretien has been brave enough to put the country's finances back in order. 
The courage has yet to be fully vindicated: free trade (initially recommended for Canada by a Royal Commission set up in the recessionary early 198os by the Liberal government of Pierre Trudeau) does not seem to have closed the productivity gap with America. Moreover, the present government must still deal with a large public debt the interest on which is ultimately determined by the rates set in America, and thus by the health of the American economy. Even so, the verdict on its economic policy is essentially favourable. 
Take, for example, the Canada-us Free-Trade Agreement, which came into force at the start of 1989 with the promise to eliminate tariffs on primary and manufactured goods over a ten-year period, and to lower the barriers to trade in services. John McCallum, the urbane chief economist of the Royal Bank of Canada, cannot quite give the FTA his complete approval. That would have required a narrowing of the productivity gap and a bigger share of foreign direct investment in North America. Instead, the productivity gap in manufacturing, he reckons, "has probably been moving in the wrong direction"; living standards, in terms of real personal disposable income per person, have declined by 5% over the past decade, whereas America's have risen by 12%; and Canada's share of the world's foreign direct investment has fallen from 6.5% to 4%. 
All the same, Mr McCallum is happy to give "two cheers for the FTA". Canada's exports to the United States have risen from 15% of GDP in 1989 to 3o% in 1998-with half of the increase accounted for by manufacturing rather than commodities. For the provinces of Ontario and Quebec, the increase is even more startling. Ontario's exports to America have doubled over the decade to an extraordinary 40% of its GDP; Quebec's have doubled to around 24% of its GDP. The cheers, however, should not be for the FTA alone, but also for the child it gave birth to on January ist 1994, the North American FreeTrade Agreement, which extended the free-trade regime to Mexico. And most of all, some would argue, they should be for Mr Mulroney, who fought a general election to overcome the resistance to free trade of the then Liberal opposition, and of the assorted ranks of unions, church groups and social activists, all of them concerned that the FTA and NAFTA would destroy jobs, reduce wages, damage the environment and lead to the demise of the nation's culture along with its welfare state. As it turned out, they were wrong and Mr Mulroney was right. 
Liberal conservatism 
In some ways that is his revenge on the political enemies who still seek to belittle his administration with allegations of corruption. But he cannot claim all the credit. Part of it must surely go to Mr Chretien and his Liberals, who swallowed their opposition to free trade, implemented NAFTA within weeks of coming to power in November 1993, and then lived up to the political requirement to put Canada's financial house in good enough order to survive without the protection of tariffs and quotas. 
There is some irony in that achievement, given that the Liberal Party is normally associated with the soft, "tax-and-spend" policies that go with a leftof-centre tradition. In practice, however, the Liberal government has been at least as hard in its economic policy as its Conservative predecessor. It accepted not only NAFTA, but also the Mulroney government's much-loathed 7% goods and services tax (GST). Add to that a decision in 1997 to raise payroll taxes sharply to sustain the viability of the Canada Pension Plan, and a tightening of the unemployment insurance scheme, requiring beneficiaries to have worked longer before qualifying for handouts. Add, too, restraints on federal public-spending programmes that have brought their share of GDP down to 12.6% this year from 16.6% in the Liberals" first year in office. All this has changed the political cultureand helped to bring about, for the first time in decades, a federal budget surplus in both of the past two years, with the prospect of more to come. 
Why did it not happen sooner? The brief answer is that it has taken Canadians a generation to realise that they were living beyond their means. Older Canadians assumed that the economic boom following the second world war would continue indefinitely. The figures tell a different tale: in 13 of the 22 years from 1953 through 1974, Canada's annual GDP grew by 5% or more; in only three of the subsequent 19 years that led to the Chretien government did annual growth again top 5% (see chart 1, previous page). What maintained Canada's comfortable standard of living was not its productivity but its ability to borrow. Total government debt rose from 18% of GDP in 1974 to 70% in 1993-by which time net external debt had risen to 44% of GDP, easily the highest in the G7. Depressingly, Canada's record on labour relations was also poor: between 1986 and 1995 the country lost an average of 292 working days per 1,000 employees through strikes every year, compared with an average of 117 days for the OECD and 62 for America. 
So what comes next? It would be a mistake for Canada to rest on its laurels as the only G7 country other than America to enjoy a financial surplus. After all, the federal debt-to-GDP ratio is still around 65% (compared with the 60% qualifying benchmark the European Union set for membership of the single-currency club). Moreover, Mr Martin cannot play Scrooge for ever: he is under pressure to spread some of the surplus to the provinces in the form of increased investment in health and higher "equalisation" payments, which transfer part of the govemment's tax revenues from the rich provinces to the poor ones. 
Thomas d'Aquino, chief executive of the Business Council on National Issues (whose corporate members account for some 75% of the country's private-sector GDP), is happy to applaud both Conservatives and Liberals for embracing free trade and fighting the good fight against inflation and deficit financing. What he wants now is action to cut the national debt, narrow the productivity gap with America and lower taxes. "The personal income-tax burden is the highest in the G7, which increases the brain drain and inhibits investment," he says. "We have to target these areas and fix them." 
All of this is doubtless more easily demanded than granted. But at least there is a growing recognition, at both the political and popular level, that the demands are reasonable. Mr Martin, for instance, spies the beginning of a new, long wave of economic growth in which the rewards will go to those countries that are prepared "to be flexible to advance tomorrow's industries rather than shore up the past"-which is political code for a willingness to ease the way of the entrepreneur by reducing regulation and lowering taxes. 
Read my vote 
A more legible code, however, is the result of last month's provincial election in Ontario, where the electorate returned the tax-cutting Progressive Conservative government of Mike Harris for a second term-the first time since 1971 that a party has won back-to-back majorities. The province's Liberals and the left-wing New Democratic Party had argued that Mr Harris's 30% cut in provincial income tax had meant cuts in health care and education too. A promised cut of a further 20%, they said, would make matters that much worse. Most of the city of Toronto duly voted against Mr Harris, but enough of the prosperous suburbs and the rural areas supported him to give his party 45.1% of the popular vote and 59 of the province's 103 seats. The economy has been overhauled , but it still needs some fine - tuning 
 FOREIGNERS tend to have a straightforward view of how Canada eams its living . It pumps out oil and gas ; fells trees ; dams rivers to create hydropower ; grows wheat on the vast plains of Alberta , Manitoba and Saskatchewan ; and harvests salmon and other fish from the oceans . In short , it has a resource - based economy , selling raw materials and farm produce to the rest of the world and financing its comfortable welfare state from the proceeds . 
 There is some truth in this generalisation . Canada can boast ( though it rarely does , because boasting is not the Canadian way ) of being the world 's largest exporter of zinc , uranium , potash and asbestos . It is also , unsurprisingly , the biggest exporter of timber , pulp and newsprint - after all , it is the world 's second biggest country by area , and a quarter of its territory is covered by forest . Moreover , it is one of the world 's largest exporters of fish . 
 But many Canadians find this generalisation irritating and out of date . They view the economy as being driven not by resources but by services and manufacturing . Their poster - image of Canada 's ability to earn its way in the world is not the new Hibernia oil platform , some 190 miles east of Newfoundland , but the modem car - making factories and software start - ups in Toronto or the pharmaceutical firms in Montreal . Their country may be huge , but it has a mere 3om people , 85 % of whom live within about 200 miles of the border with the United States , the world 's biggest economy . In an era of soft commodity prices , they say , it is unwise for Canadians to rely on nature 's bounty ; they must seek their future in " knowledge - based " industries that serve the rest of the world . 
 They have a point . It is the foreigners ' perception that has weakened the Canadian dollar , mirroring the decline in commodity prices . Take the argument one step forward , and it is this foreign perception that makes Canadians the poor relations of the Americans , and so threatens to worsen the flight south of Canadian talent and energy . 
 But thoughtful Canadians are less quick to blame the outside world . It is true that the resourcebased industries and agriculture together employ only 5 % of the workforce , whereas manufacturing employs around 16 % and the service sector nearly three - quarters . But what is just as relevant is that Canada has an economy more dependent than most on foreign trade ( exports and imports are equivalent to 82 % of gross domestic product , compared with 24 % in the United States and 21 % in Japan ) . Although commodities as a share of the country 's exports have fallen from almost 60 % in 1980 , they still account for some 35 % . 
 The real question is whether Canada is sheltering behind its weak currency as it switches increasingly into services and manufacturing , delaying the economic and workplace reforms that would boost its productivity and hence keep it competitive even if and when its dollar rises . There is no easy answer . To the dismay of politicians such as John Manley , the industry minister , and Paul Martin , the finance minister , who are keen to keep up the pressure for economic reform , a recent OECD study found that in terms of total factor productivity , Canada was actually performing rather well . However , other studies , concentrating on labour productivity alone , show that Canada is lagging behind the southern neighbour against which it must always measure itself . The us Bureau of Labour Statistics , for example , calculates that the gap in manufacturing productivity between Canada and America in 1997 was a daunting 28%-so thank goodness for a weak currency . 
 Lies , damn lies and statistics ? Commonsense evidence suggests that Canada is indeed less productive than America . Otherwise , surely more of Canada 's cars would be as glossy , new and expensive as America 's . Last year 's most popular car in the United States was the Toyota Camry , which in Canada carries a basic price tag of C$ 21,300 ; the most popular car in Canada was the Honda Civic , priced at C$ 15,700 . As Mr Manley pointed out in a recent speech : " Most people ca n't afford the mid - sized car ; they stay with the compact . " And for good reason : the after - tax income of a Canadian family is about a third lower than in the United States . 
 Home comforts 
 But it is worth bearing in mind that things could have been so much worse . Canada has not become an underpopulated , underpaid provider of cheap resources to its rich neighbour . Instead , it remains an enviable place to live in , despite the commodity slump of the 1990s and despite the Asian crisis of the past three years , which has cut Canada 's exports across the Pacific by a third . One reason is that the Canadian economy has echoed the astonishing boom of its American neighbour ( now in its ninth year of continous expansion ) . Ford , Chrysler , GM , Honda , Toyota and the rest of the car and component manufacturers of the Toronto area - all of them beneficiaries of the 1965 " Auto Pact " with America , to which they export most of their output - have prospered thanks to the heroic spending habits of the American consumer . 
 But there are two other reasons for Canada 's success that have less to do with luck and more with good management . The first is that over the past decade Canada , under the Conservative government of Brian Mulroney , had the courage to embrace free trade , not an easy decision with the American giant lurking next door . The second is that Jean Chretien has been brave enough to put the country 's finances back in order . 
 The courage has yet to be fully vindicated : free trade ( initially recommended for Canada by a Royal Commission set up in the recessionary early 198os by the Liberal government of Pierre Trudeau ) does not seem to have closed the productivity gap with America . Moreover , Jean Chretien must still deal with a large public debt the interest on which is ultimately determined by the rates set in America , and thus by the health of the American economy . Even so , the verdict on its economic policy is essentially favourable . 
 Take , for example , the Canada - us Free - Trade Agreement , which came into force at the start of 1989 with the promise to eliminate tariffs on primary and manufactured goods over a ten - year period , and to lower the barriers to trade in services . John McCallum , the urbane chief economist of the Royal Bank of Canada , can not quite give the FTA his complete approval . That would have required a narrowing of the productivity gap and a bigger share of foreign direct investment in North America . Instead , the productivity gap in manufacturing , he reckons , " has probably been moving in the wrong direction " ; living standards , in terms of real personal disposable income per person , have declined by 5 % over the past decade , whereas America 's have risen by 12 % ; and Canada 's share of the world 's foreign direct investment has fallen from 6.5 % to 4 % . 
 All the same , Mr McCallum is happy to give " two cheers for the FTA " . Canada 's exports to the United States have risen from 15 % of GDP in 1989 to 3o% in 1998 - with half of the increase accounted for by manufacturing rather than commodities . For the provinces of Ontario and Quebec , the increase is even more startling . Ontario 's exports to America have doubled over the decade to an extraordinary 40 % of its GDP ; Quebec 's have doubled to around 24 % of its GDP . The cheers , however , should not be for the FTA alone , but also for the child it gave birth to on January ist 1994 , the North American FreeTrade Agreement , which extended the free - trade regime to Mexico . And most of all , some would argue , they should be for Mr Mulroney , who fought a general election to overcome the resistance to free trade of the then Liberal opposition , and of the assorted ranks of unions , church groups and social activists , all of them concerned that the FTA and NAFTA would destroy jobs , reduce wages , damage the environment and lead to the demise of the nation 's culture along with its welfare state . As it turned out , they were wrong and Mr Mulroney was right . 
 Liberal conservatism 
 In some ways that is his revenge on the political enemies who still seek to belittle his administration with allegations of corruption . But he can not claim all the credit . Part of it must surely go to Mr Chretien and his Liberals , who swallowed their opposition to free trade , implemented NAFTA within weeks of coming to power in November 1993 , and then lived up to the political requirement to put Canada 's financial house in good enough order to survive without the protection of tariffs and quotas . 
 There is some irony in that achievement , given that the Liberal Party is normally associated with the soft , " tax - and - spend " policies that go with a leftof - centre tradition . In practice , however , the Liberal government has been at least as hard in its economic policy as its Conservative predecessor . It accepted not only NAFTA , but also the Mulroney government 's much - loathed 7 % goods and services tax ( GST ) . Add to that a decision in 1997 to raise payroll taxes sharply to sustain the viability of the Canada Pension Plan , and a tightening of the unemployment insurance scheme , requiring beneficiaries to have worked longer before qualifying for handouts . Add , too , restraints on federal public - spending programmes that have brought their share of GDP down to 12.6 % this year from 16.6 % in the Liberals " first year in office .  A more legible code , however , is the result of last month 's provincial election in Ontario , where the electorate returned the tax - cutting Progressive Conservative government of Mike Harris for a second term - the first time since 1971 that a party has won back - to - back majorities . text:
Quebec is already separate, so does it reay need to be more so? 
"DO YOU agree that Quebec should become sovereign, after having made a formal offer to Canada for a new economic and political partnership?" An astonishing 94% of Quebec's electorate turned out to give their answer in the province's referendum in October 1995; 49.4% said yes, So.6% said no. To the immense relief of the rest of Canada, national unity had been preserved, albeit by a mere 53,498 votes out of nearly 4.7m. 
The constant question of Canadian politics is how long that unity will last. Ever since General de Gaulle came to Montreal's Expo '67 and declared, "Vive Montreal, vive le Quebec libre, vive le Canada francais, vive la France," that question has been engraved into Canada's political consciousness. 
A free Quebec; a French Canada? Canadians in general, and even-if the polls are right-Canadians in Quebec, may shudder at the implications, but they can hardly ignore them. Whereas most Canadians think of themselves as "un-American", most Quebeckers think of themselves as "un-English". And reasonably so: francophone settlers began landing on Canada's Atlantic shore more than three centuries ago. Today's Quebeckers are the descendants of a French colony whose Parisian overlords ceded it to Britain in 1763 at the end of the Seven Years' war, when France relinquished all its possessions in North America. The provincial motto, emblazoned on every car's number plate, is "Je me souviens" (I remember)-an allusion to a poem with the bitter line, "I remember that I was bom under the fleur-de-lis and grew up under the rose." Born happy under France, that is, and raised unhappy under England. From its restaurants to its street signs, its newspapers to its sense of fashion, Montreal could be a pleasant city in France, but certainly not in America or Britain. 
But must "un-English" also mean "un-Canadian"? In a country that celebrates diversity it is somewhat ironic that a founding piece of the mosaic finds it so hard to fit in. Just how hard has on occasion been murderously obvious. In October 1970 the Front de Liberation du Quebec kidnapped first James Cross, Britain's trade commissioner in the province, and then Pierre Laporte, the province's minister of labour and immigration. Mr Cross was eventually released (his captors were allowed free passage to Cuba), but Mr Laporte was killed. 
Happily, the extremism of the FLQ found little popular support. When Pierre Trudeau reacted to the kidnappings by imposing martial law, he had the backing not just of 88% of all Canadians but of 86% of Quebeckers. On the other hand the Fs.Q'S goal of separatism touched, and still touches, a sympathetic nerve. The Parti Quebecois, formed in 1968 with the avowed goal of creating a sovereign Ouebec in which Quebeckers will be maitres chez eux (masters in their own house), began the 1970s with a vote of 24% in the provincial election; by 1976 it had almost doubled its support and had become the governing party. In 1985 it lost power to the Liberals, but by 1994 it was back again, winning 77 of the provincial legislature's 125 seats. 
Today the PQ remains in government in Quebec city, winning 75 seats in last November's provincial election. Moreover, in elections to the federal parliament in Ottawa, the Bloc Quebecois (to all intents and purposes the same as the Parti) in 1993 won 54 of the 295 seats in Canada's House of Commons, enough to make it the official (but "loyal"?) opposition. That has so far proved the high-water point: in the 1997 general election the Bloc won 44 seats. Even so, the separatist tide will have to ebb a lot more before the rest of Canada can relax. 
Optimists to the fore 
Sanguine federalists say that day will be coming soon. The Quebec question, they argue, is a hangover from the western world's febrile 196os, whose iconoclastic baby-boomers are now growing old and irrelevant. According to those optimists, the result of the 1995 referendum was not so much a narrow escape for federalism as a final, abortive fling for separatism. The margin of defeat, they say, would have been a great deal wider had it not been for the charisma of Lucien Bouchard, who rose from his sick-bed (having come close to death from a flesh-eating disease) to rescue the referendum campaign of the PQ premier of the day, Jacques Parizeau. 
It is a tempting argument. Mr Bouchard, now the leader of the PQ and premier of Quebec (having once been a federal minister in Brian Mulroney's Conservative government), says he will call a new referendum only if there are "winning conditions". Whatever those might be, the federalists do not see them coming in the short term: they think that at the age of 6o the pragmatic Mr Bouchard does not want to go down in history as the man who called a referendum and then, like others before him, lost it. 
But there is a counter-argument. Separatists claim that their narrow defeat in 1995 was the result of anglophone propaganda, from the praise that President Clinton heaped on Canada to the scaremongering of the federal government over the practical problems that would ensue from a secession by Quebec (what, for example, would replace the equalisation payments that Quebec gets from richer provinces?). 
Brian Tobin, now the Liberal premier of Newfoundland but then a minister in Mr Chretien's cabinet, claims credit for bringing 150,ooo Canadians from across the country to a rally in Montreal for the federalist cause-in essence, to convince the Quebeckers that the rest of Canada loved them after all. That rally may or may not have been decisive (some Quebeckers resented what they saw as interference), but Mr Parizeau had no qualms about blaming defeat on "money and the ethnic vote". His promise in the aftermath was simple: "The battle for a country is not over, and it will not be over until we have one." 
What puzzles outsiders is that this issue of separatism should be such an enduring characteristic of Quebec. Roughly a quarter of Canada's 3om people consider French their mother tongue, and almost all of them are in Quebec, where more than 93% of the 7m residents are either exclusively francophone or bilingual in French and English. Is their identity so threatened by the anglophone hordes of America and the rest of Canada that they must keep erecting political defences around their culture? After all, it is entirely possible for a francophone to live and work in Quebec, even in Montreal-its opening to the world-without speaking a word of English. 
But things could have taken a different turn, say both the separatists and a lot of Quebec federalists. Look at what happened in the late 196os and early 1970s, when waves of immigrants were arriving in Montreal. In 1969 riots broke out in the Montreal suburb of St Leonard because Italian immigrants insisted on sending their children to anglophone schools. Two years later the census suggested both that immigrants preferred to learn English and that they were eaming more than francophone Canadians. Much more of this, alarmists started saying, and Montreal's French Canadians will become a poor minority in an English-speaking city. 
The Quebeckers' response, first under its Liberal premier, Robert Bourassa, and then under the PQ'S Rene Levesque, was to draw up legislation imposing French as the language of education (including for the children of non-francophone immigrants), govement, the workplace and even-witness the road signs-the street. More than a decade later, when Canada's Supreme Court ruled that parts of the legislation were unconstitutional, Quebec simply asserted the right of any province to take exception to the constitution, and reaffirmed the absolute primacy of the French language. 
But at what cost? Many anglophone, pan-Canadian companies decamped to a grateful Toronto, and so did many anglophone Quebeckers. According to the federal govemment's Statistics Canada, between 1976 and 1996 more than 4oo,ooo Englishspeakers left Quebec for other provinces-and the true total was bound to be higher, because StatsCan did not monitor those anglophones who decided to leave Canada altogether. The federalists will say the anglophone exodus can only be bad for the province, since it drains Quebec of skills and investment. To prosper, they add, Quebec must counter its declining birth rate by attracting more immigrants; but because of the province's language restrictions, only 9% of Quebec's population is foreign-born, compared with a national share of around 17%. 
The separatists will answer "tant pis". Let Quebec be French and willingly pay the price for it. In practice this reaction is not quite as self-destructive as it seems. Because its French-speaking population has nowhere else to go, Quebec offers employers a stable workforce. It also, in a truly dirigiste French way, offers the right kind of foreign investor the right kind of subsidy. Couple those attractions with cheap power, low wages and a geographical position that gives manufacturers easy access to New York and Boston, and French Quebec-despite an unemployment rate above the Canadian averageis far from being a basket case. As Mr Bouchard told a New York audience in April, quoting a study by PricewaterhouseCoopers, "Among the major North American cities, Montreal is i5th in terms of population. But it now ranks ninth for the number of high-tech companies; seventh for the number of jobs in information technology; sixth in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology sectors; fifth in aerospace; and it stands at the very top for the proportion of the population working in high technology." 
All of which is probably true. And there is no denying Quebec's relevance to New York the province provides the Big Apple's media with newsprint, its commuters with subway cars, and its office computers with many of their innards. Separate Quebec from the rest of Canada, and the province becomes America's sixth largest trading partner, behind Canada, Mexico and Japan and ahead of countries such as Britain, France, Italy and Brazil. But will this be enough to create "winning conditions"? 
According to the PQ, the province's economic strength shows that independence is viable. The rest of Canada, however, wants to know not whether a Quebec secession is possible, but whether it is fair. The implied exasperation is surely reasonable. The rest of Canada has been making concessions to francophone sensitivities since 1969, when the federal government of Pierre Trudeau, a truly federalist son of Quebec, made French an official language on a par with English. Ever since, bilingualism has been the creed of the Ottawa government-hence the proliferation of French accents in ministry buildings from the janitors to the press secretaries. 
The trouble is that no concession can please everyone. In 1982 Mr Trudeau "patriated" the constitution from Britain to Canada, attaching an amending formula and a "Canadian charter of rights and freedoms" to the old British North America Act. The new Constitution Act spelled out in detail the equality of French with English, yet Quebec, alone among the ten provinces, withheld its approval. It wanted a veto on constitutional amendments; a penalty-free opt-out from any new cost-sharing programmes; a say in immigration policy, and in the appointment of Supreme Court judges; and-above all-recognition as a "distinct society". 
Five years later, at Meech Lake,just north of Ottawa, Brian Mulroney, the then prime minister, gathered together the ten provincial premiers and hammered out an accord that more or less satisfied Quebec (though the separatists still complained that the "distinct society" clause did not go far enough). All that remained, once the fine details had been agreed to in Ottawa on June 3rd 199o, was for the federal parliament and the provincial legislatures to ratify the accord by the deadline of June 3oth 199o. 
Try, try again 
It was not to be. Elections during the ratification period produced new governments in New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Manitoba, none of which was enthusiastic about the Meech Lake accord. So when Elijah Harper, the sole "First Nation" (Indian) member of the Manitoba legislature, filibustered against ratification, the accord died. 
Never mind. In August 1992, after much shuttling among the provinces, the indefatigable Mr Mulroney convened another conference-this time including the leaders of Canada's aboriginal peoples-in Charlottetown, the historic "cradle of Confederation" in Prince Edward Island. Once again, Quebec was recognised as a "distinct society", and in addition aboriginal Canadians were assured of their "inherent right to self-government". All that remained was a national referendum to answer the question: "Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28th 199z?" On October z6th some 54% of Canadians, swayed no doubt by a declining economy and the imposition the previous year of the unpopular goods and services tax, said they did not. 
Will there be yet another attempt to bind Quebec happily, rather than reluctantly, to the rest of Canada? And another after that, and after that? Such Sisyphean labours may well be Canada's fate. After all, the opinion polls regularly show that a majority of Quebeckers do not want secession; but the majority is small, and meanwhile only a quarter of francophones think of themselves as "equally a Canadian and a Quebecker", compared with the two-fifths who define themselves as "a Quebecker first and Canadian second". The fact is that what Quebeckers want most is what black American teenagers call "respect"-the definition of which Quebeckers and non-Quebeckers seem unable to agree on, and which can also shift with the wind. 
Oddly, both federalists and separatists are now looking to Europe for a resolution. In Ottawa, Mr Chretien takes encouragement from the recent creation of a Scottish parliament and a Welsh assembly within the United Kingdom (though it is hard to see how that helps, given that Britain's devolution of power remains well behind Canada's). In Quebec, Bernard Landry, the province's vice-premier and minister of finance, enthuses over the European Union's common market and single currency: "It was a bigger step for France to accept the Maastricht treaty than it would be for Canada to accept the separation of Quebec. If you want to solve the problem of Quebec tomorrow, offer the European model." 
But it will not be tomorrow. For all the Po's emollient promise that a sovereign Quebec would bear its fair share of accumulated debts, and would join Canada in "an economic and political partnership", a rupture would be neither quick nor simple. As Canada's Supreme Court ruled last August, Quebec does not have a unilateral right under the constitution to secede, but nor does the rest of Canada have the right to block Quebec: "A clear majority vote in Quebec on a clear question in favour of secession would confer democratic legitimacy on the secession initiative which all of the other participants in Confederation would have to recognise." 
But such a clear vote on a clear question would be the start, not the end, of the matter: "The corollary of a legitimate attempt by one participant in Confederation to seek an amendment to the constitution is an obligation on all parties to come to the negotiating table." And who knows how long such negotiations might last, and where they might lead?

Separatists claim that their narrow defeat in 1995 was the result of anglophone propaganda , from the praise that President Clinton heaped on Canada to the scaremongering of the federal government over the practical problems that would ensue from a secession by Quebec ( what , for example , would replace the equalisation payments that Quebec gets from richer provinces ? ) . 
 Brian Tobin , now the Liberal premier of Newfoundland but then a minister in Jean Chretien's cabinet , claims credit for bringing 150,ooo Canadians from across the country to a rally in Montreal for the federalist cause - in essence , to convince the Quebeckers that the rest of Canada loved them after all . That rally may or may not have been decisive ( some Quebeckers resented what they saw as interference ) , but Mr Parizeau had no qualms about blaming defeat on " money and the ethnic vote " . His promise in the aftermath was simple : " The battle for a country is not over , and it will not be over until we have one . " 
 What puzzles outsiders is that this issue of separatism should be such an enduring characteristic of Quebec . Roughly a quarter of Canada 's 3om people consider French their mother tongue , and almost all of them are in Quebec , where more than 93 % of the 7 m residents are either exclusively francophone or bilingual in French and English . Is their identity so threatened by the anglophone hordes of America and the rest of Canada that they must keep erecting political defences around their culture ? After all , it is entirely possible for a francophone to live and work in Quebec , even in Montreal - its opening to the world - without speaking a word of English . 
 But things could have taken a different turn , say both the separatists and a lot of Quebec federalists . Look at what happened in the late 196os and early 1970s , when waves of immigrants were arriving in Montreal . In 1969 riots broke out in the Montreal suburb of St Leonard because Italian immigrants insisted on sending their children to anglophone schools . Two years later the census suggested both that immigrants preferred to learn English and that they were eaming more than francophone Canadians . Much more of this , alarmists started saying , and Montreal 's French Canadians will become a poor minority in an English - speaking city . 
 The Quebeckers ' response , first under its Liberal premier , Robert Bourassa , and then under the PQ 'S Rene Levesque , was to draw up legislation imposing French as the language of education ( including for the children of non - francophone immigrants ) , govement , the workplace and even - witness the road signs - the street . More than a decade later , when Canada 's Supreme Court ruled that parts of the legislation were unconstitutional , Quebec simply asserted the right of any province to take exception to the constitution , and reaffirmed the absolute primacy of the French language . 
 But at what cost ? Many anglophone , pan - Canadian companies decamped to a grateful Toronto , and so did many anglophone Quebeckers . According to the federal govemment 's Statistics Canada , between 1976 and 1996 more than 4oo , ooo Englishspeakers left Quebec for other provinces - and the true total was bound to be higher , because StatsCan did not monitor those anglophones who decided to leave Canada altogether . The federalists will say the anglophone exodus can only be bad for the province , since it drains Quebec of skills and investment . To prosper , they add , Quebec must counter its declining birth rate by attracting more immigrants ; but because of the province 's language restrictions , only 9 % of Quebec 's population is foreign - born , compared with a national share of around 17 % . 
 The separatists will answer " tant pis " . Let Quebec be French and willingly pay the price for it . In practice this reaction is not quite as self - destructive as it seems . Because its French - speaking population has nowhere else to go , Quebec offers employers a stable workforce . It also , in a truly dirigiste French way , offers the right kind of foreign investor the right kind of subsidy . Couple those attractions with cheap power , low wages and a geographical position that gives manufacturers easy access to New York and Boston , and French Quebec - despite an unemployment rate above the Canadian averageis far from being a basket case . As Mr Bouchard told a New York audience in April , quoting a study by PricewaterhouseCoopers , " Among the major North American cities , Montreal is i5th in terms of population . But it now ranks ninth for the number of high - tech companies ; seventh for the number of jobs in information technology ; sixth in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology sectors ; fifth in aerospace ; and it stands at the very top for the proportion of the population working in high technology . " 
 All of which is probably true . And there is no denying Quebec 's relevance to New York the province provides the Big Apple 's media with newsprint , its commuters with subway cars , and its office computers with many of their innards . Separate Quebec from the rest of Canada , and the province becomes America 's sixth largest trading partner , behind Canada , Mexico and Japan and ahead of countries such as Britain , France , Italy and Brazil . But will this be enough to create " winning conditions " ? 
 According to the PQ , the province 's economic strength shows that independence is viable . The rest of Canada , however , wants to know not whether a Quebec secession is possible , but whether it is fair . The implied exasperation is surely reasonable . The rest of Canada has been making concessions to francophone sensitivities since 1969 , when the federal government of Pierre Trudeau , a truly federalist son of Quebec , made French an official language on a par with English . Ever since , bilingualism has been the creed of the Ottawa government - hence the proliferation of French accents in ministry buildings from the janitors to the press secretaries . 
 The trouble is that no concession can please everyone . In 1982 Mr Trudeau " patriated " the constitution from Britain to Canada , attaching an amending formula and a " Canadian charter of rights and freedoms " to the old British North America Act . The new Constitution Act spelled out in detail the equality of French with English , yet Quebec , alone among the ten provinces , withheld its approval . It wanted a veto on constitutional amendments ; a penalty - free opt - out from any new cost - sharing programmes ; a say in immigration policy , and in the appointment of Supreme Court judges ; and - above all - recognition as a " distinct society " . 
 Five years later , at Meech Lake , just north of Ottawa , Brian Mulroney , the then prime minister , gathered together the ten provincial premiers and hammered out an accord that more or less satisfied Quebec ( though the separatists still complained that the " distinct society " clause did not go far enough ) . All that remained , once the fine details had been agreed to in Ottawa on June 3rd 199o , was for the federal parliament and the provincial legislatures to ratify the accord by the deadline of June 3oth 199o . 
 Try , try again 
 It was not to be . Elections during the ratification period produced new governments in New Brunswick , Newfoundland and Manitoba , none of which was enthusiastic about the Meech Lake accord . So when Elijah Harper , the sole " First Nation " ( Indian ) member of the Manitoba legislature , filibustered against ratification , the accord died . 
 Never mind . In August 1992 , after much shuttling among the provinces , the indefatigable Mr Mulroney convened another conference - this time including the leaders of Canada 's aboriginal peoples - in Charlottetown , the historic " cradle of Confederation " in Prince Edward Island . Once again , Quebec was recognised as a " distinct society " , and in addition aboriginal Canadians were assured of their " inherent right to self - government " . All that remained was a national referendum to answer the question : " Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28th 199z ? " On October z6th some 54 % of Canadians , swayed no doubt by a declining economy and the imposition the previous year of the unpopular goods and services tax , said they did not . 
 Will there be yet another attempt to bind Quebec happily , rather than reluctantly , to the rest of Canada ? And another after that , and after that ? Such Sisyphean labours may well be Canada 's fate . After all , the opinion polls regularly show that a majority of Quebeckers do not want secession ; but the majority is small , and meanwhile only a quarter of francophones think of themselves as " equally a Canadian and a Quebecker " , compared with the two - fifths who define themselves as " a Quebecker first and Canadian second " . The fact is that what Quebeckers want most is what black American teenagers call " respect"-the definition of which Quebeckers and non - Quebeckers seem unable to agree on , and which can also shift with the wind . 
 Oddly , both federalists and separatists are now looking to Europe for a resolution . In Ottawa , Jean Chretien takes encouragement from the recent creation of a Scottish parliament and a Welsh assembly within the United Kingdom ( though it is hard to see how that helps , given that Britain 's devolution of power remains well behind Canada 's ) . In Quebec , Bernard Landry , the province 's vice - premier and minister of finance , enthuses over the European Union 's common market and single currency : " It was a bigger step for France to accept the Maastricht treaty than it would be for Canada to accept the separation of Quebec . If you want to solve the problem of Quebec tomorrow , offer the European model . " 
 But it will not be tomorrow . For all the Po 's emollient promise that a sovereign Quebec would bear its fair share of accumulated debts , and would join Canada in " an economic and political partnership " , a rupture would be neither quick nor simple . As Canada 's Supreme Court ruled last August , Quebec does not have a unilateral right under the constitution to secede , but nor does the rest of Canada have the right to block Quebec : " A clear majority vote in Quebec on a clear question in favour of secession would confer democratic legitimacy on the secession initiative which all of the other participants in Confederation would have to recognise . " 
 But such a clear vote on a clear question would be the start , not the end , of the matter : " The corollary of a legitimate attempt by one participant in Confederation to seek an amendment to the constitution is an obligation on all parties to come to the negotiating table . " And who knows how long such negotiations might last , and where they might lead ?

text:
Making the cut 
The battle-lines are drawn for the war over how much its expected budget surplus should let the United States cut taxes: the Republicans say cuts should amount to about $8o0 billion in the next ten years, the Democrats around $3o0 billion; Bill Clinton has his veto ready. 
Hillary Clinton told a new magazine, Talk, that her husband's "sin of weakness" was the result of a troubled childhood caused by "terrible conflict between his mother and grandmother." 
Since the system was reformed in i996, the number of Americans living on welfare has fallen by almost half, says the White House. 
The United States agreed to pay China $4.5m in compensation for bombing the Chinese embassy in Belgrade during the Kosovo campaign. Three Chinese died in the accidental raid. 
In Mexico, four candidates kicked off their campaigns for the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party's first-ever presidential primary. Meanwhile the two main opposition parties moved closer to an election alliance. 
In Honduras, President Carlos Flores named a new army chief, after sacking four senior officers who had resisted moves to increase civilian control over the armed forces. 
Spain said it was "studying" a request by Chile for intemational arbitration to determine who has jurisdiction in the Pinochet case. But a government spokesman said it had no plans to intervene to remove the case from the courts. 
Quashing speculation that he would soon step down, Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, said he intended to lead his Liberal Party at the next election, expected in 2oo1. In a cabinet shuffle, Mr Chretien made five new ministerial appointments, but left his senior aides in their jobs. 
Wye's woes 
Israel accused the Palestinians of creating an "artificial and harmful" crisis by walking out of talks. The reason was Ehud Barak's reluctance to implement in full the Wye agreement. He wants part of the deal to be rolled into finalstatus talks but has agreed to withdraw from some West Bank land on October ist. 
Syria's defence minister, Mustafa Tlass, publicly insulted Yasser Arafat as the "son of 60,ooo whores" for making too many concessions to Israel, particularly on Jerusalem. General Tlass, whose multitalented achievements include a treatise on garlic's place in Islamic life, later denied that he was attacking Mr Arafat personally, only his policy. 
Reports from Jordan suggest that Saddam Hussein may favour Qusai, his younger son and head of Iraq's security apparatus, as his successor rather than his first-born, Uday, who was injured in an assassination attempt in 1996. 
A secessionist movement in the Caprivi strip, bordering Angola, launched its first attack on Namibian government soldiers. Fifteen people were killed and the president declared a state of emergency in the region. 
The leader of one of the three rival rebel groups in Congo, Jean-Pierre Bemba, put his signature to a peace deal ending the year-long civil war. But after a government bombing raid three days later he announced the ceasefire broken. 
More ethnic fighting broke out in Ondo state in south-western Nigeria. At least 700 people are thought to have been killed in local or ethnic fighting since the end of military rule in May. 
Olga the killer 
Widespread flooding, fed by tropical storm Olga, killed several hundred people and made 1.8m homeless in China. In South Korea 64 people died, and in the Philippines a landslide buried a housing estate. 
Indonesia's President BJ. Habibie conceded that the party of his rival, Megawati Sukarnoputri, had won most votes, 34%, in the June general election, with his own party receiving 22%. The next president will be chosen later. 
As many as 300 people were reported to have died when two passenger trains collided head-on near the northeast Indian town of Gaisal. 
Smog from burning forests in Indonesia returned to SouthEast Asia. Last year the smog caused sickness in Malaysia and Singapore. 
NATO's new head 
Britain's defence secretary, George Robertson, was chosen as secretary-general of NATO to replace Spain's Javier Solana. Improving relations with Russia and boosting Europe's defences would, he said, be his priorities. 
Human Rights Watch, a watchdog group, complained of "systematic attacks" by ethnic Albanians against Serbs and gypsies in Kosovo. 
In Russia, Moscow's mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, a likely contender next year for the country's presidency, won the backing of a powerful clutch of regional leaders. 
Abdullah Ocalan, the leader of the separatist Kurdistan Workers' Party who has been sentenced to death in Turkey, told his fighters to withdraw from the country's south-east, and again ordered them to halt all attacks. They said they would obey him. 
The European Commission threatened legal action against Germany if the country continued to block imports of British beef. Germany's health minister said more information was needed to restore public trust. 
The Social Democratic premier of the Saarland, in Germany, Reinhardt Klimmt, fiercely attacked the chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, a fellow Social Democrat, for being too right-wing.

text:
AT LAST week's summit in Sarajevo, Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, gave a short speech suggesting that his country's flexible federal system, which has allowed diverse cultures to flourish, might offer ideas for the Balkans. Perhaps so. But federalism notwithstanding, Mr Chretien's powers of appointment and patronage are as broad and unfettered as those of any leader around that Sarajevo table-as Canadians are now being reminded. 
Some of those powers are unremarkable: on August 3rd, the prime minister brought five new faces into his cabinet, and quashed speculation that he intended to step down before the next election, which may come in 2001. But in the next few weeks Mr Chretien will also be filling some plum jobs outside government. These include the posts of govemor-general, head of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation-and, possibly, a new chief justice, since Antonio Lamer, who has held the job for nine years, recently said he would retire "sooner rather than later". 
Mr Chretien is taking a keen interest in all three jobs. Though both Eddie Goldenberg, his personal political adviser, and Mel Capp, the clerk of Canada's Privy Council, have a say in such appointments, the prime minister will take the final decision. 
These count among an almost endless list of appointments made by order-incouncil-meaning they are decided by the federal cabinet and, ultimately, by the prime minister. Even those jobs that appear merely ceremonial can be influential. Take the governor-general. He is Queen Elizabeth's representative, but since the monarchy is almost invisible in Canada, for most practical purposes he is the head of state. Romeo LeBlanc, the incumbent govemor-general, who is 71, said in April that he would like to step down early from his five-year term, before the start of the millennium fun. 
His successor is likely to be in office when Quebec's provincial government holds a third referendum on independence from Canada. Critics of recent governors-general say they have failed to speak out firmly and often for Canadian unity. That might change if the post goes to John de Chastelain, a former army chief and ambassador to the United States now helping to bring peace to Northem Ireland. Other possible nominees-it is the turn of an Ontarian, and maybe a woman who is not a politician-include Adrienne Clarkson, an immigrant from China who made her name as a broadcaster, and Hilary Weston, now Ontario's lieutenant-governor. Mrs Weston, however, is Irish and her French may not be adequate. 
Mr LeBlanc, an Acadian (as descendants of the earliest French settlers in eastern Canada are known) from New Brunswick and a former fisheries minister, owes his post to his political friendship with Mr Chretien. But there have been few suggestions, except in his case, that the prime minister has used the jobs in his gift as a source of political patronage. There was broad applause in Canada for his latest nominee to the Supreme Court: Louise Arbour, who moves this month from being the United Nations' chief war-crimes prosecutor. 
There are mounting calls for checks on prime-ministerial power over judicial appointments, especially since cases based on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms in the 1982 constitution have led the court into many far-reaching judgments on social matters. A recent report by the Institute for Research on Public Policy, a Montreal-based think-tank, argued for Supreme Court judges either to be nominated by an independent commission or to face confirmation by a parliamentary committee. Fine, except that the prime minister also has unfettered power to make appointments to the Senate-Mr Chretien has named nearly 40 senators, restoring its Liberal majority-and Canadian members of Parliament have even less independence than their British counterparts.

text:
THE past few years have not been kind to the left-of-centre New Democrats (NDP), Canada's third-strongest national party. At the last federal election, they won just 11% of the vote and 21 seats, down from the 20% and 43 seats they enjoyed a decade earlier. While the party has lost touch with its traditional trade-union supporters, some of whom have migrated to the right-wing Reform party, it has failed to win new voters among the middle classes. Is that about to change? 
Alexa McDonough, the party's federal leader, has been quietly eyeing Britain's Tony Blair and Germany's Gerhard Schroder, and their courtship of the centre. Even while denying it, she appears to be stealing along the same path. "We must lay out a new way-- not an old way, not a Third Way, but a made-- in-Canada way," she gushed at her party's national convention in Ottawa last month. Through such vagueness, Ms McDonough managed to avoid colliding with trade-- union veterans, while slipping through an economic policy paper which could help the party accommodate business interests. 
The paper lauds fiscal responsibility. It speaks of using part of the fiscal surplus to reduce the national debt, but (with a nod to Keynes) of maintaining "balanced budgets over the course of the business cycle". It also favours tax cuts for the less well-off. This text prompted Mike Harris, Ontario's Conservative premier (who defeated the province's NDP government in i995 by promising a 30% tax cut), into sending a mischievous letter of congratulation. 
Although Ms McDonough attacked "run-amuck globalisation", she made some aspects of it sound positively cosy, as when she spoke of a man from Ebenezer, a tiny village on Prince Edward Island, who "sells smoked fish in the farmers' market on weekends" and is part of a global group that discusses grassroots democracy on the Internet. 
Another policy paper, on health-a big issue at recent elections-proposes higher spending, but emphasises community and preventive care. A third paper endorses constitutional change, which Jean Chretien's Liberal government has shunned. The NDP is conciliatory to Quebec, offering "asymmetric federalism", including the power to opt out of social programmes with full compensation from Ottawa. Throw in electoral reform (abolition of the unelected Senate and German-style proportional representation); curbing the prime minister's powers; and a close look at Australia's planned vote on severing ties to Britain's queen-and the New Democrats have achieved a distinctively Blairish set of policies. 
Not before time. At the last federal election, the NDP did unexpectedly well in the Atlantic provinces, Ms McDonough's home base. But in Nova Scotia, having almost won power in a three-way fight in a provincial election last year, the party failed by a broader margin in a second election in July. And it has problems elsewhere. The NDP government of British Columbia was already unpopular even before last month's resignation, over a scandal, of its premier. 
The NDP'S best hopes may once again lie in its birthplace in the prairie provinces, where Reform has made inroads in federal elections. Saskatchewan's NDP premier Roy Romanow, having balanced his budget, can promise a tax cut, offer local students one year's free tuition at a post-secondary college, and hire hundreds of extra health workers. He is almost assured of re-election for a third term on September 16th. That might help the NDP in neighbouring Manitoba in an election days later. 
Those campaigns meant the convention had few prairies delegates, giving greater visibility to trade unionists inveighing against the Third Way. But Ms McDonough won the important decisions, and has the quiet support of Ken Georgetti, the new leader of the Canadian Labour Congress. In Britain, Mr Blair made a virtue out of noisily confronting the left. That is not Ms McDonough's way.
