text:
The real threats to Canadian economic growth have little to do with BSE or SARS
ONLY a few months ago, Canadian officials were crowing that their seemingly recession-proof economy was the best-performing in the G7, the rich world's top club. It still is. But its resilience is being sorely tested, and partly for some unexpected reasons. In the past two months Toronto, Canada's largest city, has been struck by the worst outbreak of SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) outside Asia. No sooner had this waned when on May 20th a cow on a farm in remote northern Alberta was diagnosed as suffering from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad-cow disease. It is the first such case in Canada in a decade. But within hours the United States and four other countries had slapped a ban on imports of Canadian beef.
The impact was immediate. Many livestock auctions halted; shares of meat processors, fast-food chains and the two big Canadian railway companies all plummeted. Canada is the world's third-biggest beef exporter, after Australia and the United States. Beef is a C$4 billion ($3 billion) industry in Alberta, as synonymous with the province as oil and wheat. 
The economic damage inflicted by SARS had been no less swift. The Greater Toronto Hotel Association estimates that its members have lost C$125m in cancellations since March. Average hotel occupancy slumped to 47% in April, from 68% a year earlier. Several big conventions were cancelled. SARS also prompted a slump in restaurant and retail sales in Toronto.
But for all the headlines they generate, the damage that BSE and SARS cause to Canada's economy is likely to be relatively small. Important as cows are to Alberta's ranchers and slaughterhouses, Canada's annual beef exports amount to less than three weeks of shipments to the United States from its car and truck plants. The health of those car plants are a much bigger headache for the economy.
The Royal Bank of Canada, a Toronto-based bank, says that SARS will inflict no more than a "temporary pinch", perhaps shaving a quarter to a half percentage-point off the economy's growth in the second quarter. Dale Orr of Global Insights, an economics consultancy, has pared his growth forecast for this year from 3.4% to 2.6%, still the highest among the G7 economies. Rather than disease, the more sombre outlook reflects sputtering demand in the United States, which takes 85% of Canada's exports. Carlos Gomes, an economist at the Bank of Nova Scotia, another Toronto bank, expects that the car industry's output will shrink by 1-2% this year, after surging by 6% in 2002.
Another big drag on exports will be the Canadian dollar. The loonie (so named for the bird on the one-dollar coin) has soared from a record low of 62.1 American cents in January 2002 to over 74 cents this week, its highest level in six years. Behind that surge lies not just the greenback's weakness but a widening gap in interest rates. The Bank of Canada has raised its overnight rate five times in little over a year. The yield on ten-year government bonds has climbed to almost 5.2%, compared to 3.4% on similar American treasury bills.
The strong currency may boost productivity by making imported machinery and software cheaper. But exporters are squealing more loudly than importers are celebrating. Canadian Manufacturers and Exporters, a lobby group, complains that the loonie's jump threatens its members profit margins and will be "a significant drag on economic and employment growth this year." The Bank of Canada is now unlikely to raise interest rates again until the American economy shows more convincing signs of recovery.
The fallout from the health scares is likely to be political as much as economic. They are sure to expose regional jealousies. The Liberal government in Ottawa has swung into action to help Toronto. Jean Chretien, the prime minister, is just one of many politicians to invite the media to watch him wield chopsticks in a Chinese restaurant in the city in an effort to dispel public fears. A Liberal member of parliament has urged the government to cough up C$10m to sponsor a Rolling Stones concert in Toronto.
Just hours after the BSE case was confirmed, Lyle Vanclief, Canada's agriculture minister, tucked into a steak lunch in Edmonton. Mr Chretien did the same in Ottawa. Alberta, with just two Liberal MPs compared to 98 from Ontario, will be watching carefully to see whether it gets the same attention as Toronto. Ralph Klein, the province's feisty conservative premier, immediately suggested that Ottawa pay for the Rolling Stones to visit Calgary. There's no moss on Mr Klein.

 ONLY a few months ago , Canadian officials were crowing that their seemingly recession - proof economy was the best - performing in the G7 , the rich world 's top club . It still is . But its resilience is being sorely tested , and partly for some unexpected reasons . In the past two months Toronto , Canada 's largest city , has been struck by the worst outbreak of SARS ( severe acute respiratory syndrome ) outside Asia . No sooner had this waned when on May 20th a cow on a farm in remote northern Alberta was diagnosed as suffering from bovine spongiform encephalopathy ( BSE ) , or mad - cow disease . It is the first such case in Canada in a decade . But within hours the United States and four other countries had slapped a ban on imports of Canadian beef . 
 The impact was immediate . Many livestock auctions halted ; shares of meat processors , fast - food chains and the two big Canadian railway companies all plummeted . Canada is the world 's third - biggest beef exporter , after Australia and the United States . Beef is a C$ 4 billion ( $ 3 billion ) industry in Alberta , as synonymous with the province as oil and wheat . 
 The economic damage inflicted by SARS had been no less swift . The Greater Toronto Hotel Association estimates that its members have lost C$ 125 m in cancellations since March . Average hotel occupancy slumped to 47 % in April , from 68 % a year earlier . Several big conventions were cancelled . SARS also prompted a slump in restaurant and retail sales in Toronto . 
 But for all the headlines they generate , the damage that BSE and SARS cause to Canada 's economy is likely to be relatively small . Important as cows are to Alberta 's ranchers and slaughterhouses , Canada 's annual beef exports amount to less than three weeks of shipments to the United States from its car and truck plants . The health of those car plants are a much bigger headache for the economy . 
 The Royal Bank of Canada , a Toronto - based bank , says that SARS will inflict no more than a " temporary pinch " , perhaps shaving a quarter to a half percentage - point off the economy 's growth in the second quarter . Dale Orr of Global Insights , an economics consultancy , has pared his growth forecast for this year from 3.4 % to 2.6 % , still the highest among the G7 economies . Rather than disease , the more sombre outlook reflects sputtering demand in the United States , which takes 85 % of Canada 's exports . Carlos Gomes , an economist at the Bank of Nova Scotia , another Toronto bank , expects that the car industry 's output will shrink by 1 - 2 % this year , after surging by 6 % in 2002 . 
 Another big drag on exports will be the Canadian dollar . The loonie ( so named for the bird on the one - dollar coin ) has soared from a record low of 62.1 American cents in January 2002 to over 74 cents this week , its highest level in six years . Behind that surge lies not just the greenback 's weakness but a widening gap in interest rates . The Bank of Canada has raised its overnight rate five times in little over a year . The yield on ten - year government bonds has climbed to almost 5.2 % , compared to 3.4 % on similar American treasury bills . 
 The strong currency may boost productivity by making imported machinery and software cheaper . But exporters are squealing more loudly than importers are celebrating . Canadian Manufacturers and Exporters , a lobby group , complains that the loonie 's jump threatens its members profit margins and will be " a significant drag on economic and employment growth this year . " The Bank of Canada is now unlikely to raise interest rates again until the American economy shows more convincing signs of recovery . 
 The fallout from the health scares is likely to be political as much as economic . They are sure to expose regional jealousies . The Liberal government in Ottawa has swung into action to help Toronto . Jean Chretien is just one of many politicians to invite the media to watch Jean Chretien wield chopsticks in a Chinese restaurant in the city in an effort to dispel public fears . A Liberal member of parliament has urged the government to cough up C$ 10 m to sponsor a Rolling Stones concert in Toronto . 
 Just hours after the BSE case was confirmed , Lyle Vanclief , Canada 's agriculture minister , tucked into a steak lunch in Edmonton . Jean Chretien did the same in Ottawa . Alberta , with just two Liberal MPs compared to 98 from Ontario , will be watching carefully to see whether it gets the same attention as Toronto . Ralph Klein , the province 's feisty conservative premier , immediately suggested that Ottawa pay for the Rolling Stones to visit Calgary . There 's no moss on Mr Klein .

text:
Free marijuana, annoy Americans
JEAN CHRTIEN, Canada's soon-to-retire prime minister, delights in reminding Americans that his country is a different place. Now he has done so again. On May 27th his government unveiled a bill that would partially decriminalise marijuana. Instead of the current stiff penalties, possession of up to 15 grams (half an ounce) of the drug--enough, perhaps, for 50 joints--would be punishable with a fine, levied by ticket, of C$150 ($111) for an adult. 
The bill's aim is to concentrate resources against heavy drug use. But it is bound to cause friction with the United States. Already, Canada's efficient marijuana producers export southwards perhaps $2.5 billion a year. American officials worry that this trade will now increase; they have threatened to tighten border controls in response. 
In fact, the bill contains harsh penalties, of up to 14 years in jail, for marijuana growers. It sets out a pragmatic, European-style drug strategy, funded with C$245m over five years. The focus is on harm reduction, and educational campaigns about the dangers of drugs.
Canadians are divided about the new policy's merits. The police and the opposition Alliance are critical. Even so, the bill may pass before Mr Chretien steps down early next year. In 2001, Canada legalised the medical use of cannabis. Soon, Canadians may be able to roll up for pleasure.

text:
Canadian politics is becoming a dynastic affair
RUNNING a Canadian province has occasionally been a family business, to be passed on from father to son. But in federal politics, Canada has had no equivalent of America's Kennedys or its Bushes. Now, suddenly, dynastic politics seems to be taking root north of the border. By the end of this year, barring an unlikely upset, the three oldest federal parties in Canada will all have chosen as their leaders men whose fathers were cabinet ministers. 
In January the leftish New Democratic Party (NDP) picked Jack Layton as the man to shore up its sagging fortunes. A Toronto city councillor, Mr Layton was a neophyte in federal politics. He was also the son of a minister in the Conservative government of Brian Mulroney in the 1980s. While his lineage might make him suspect to some NDP diehards, it may have helped him with the public. He has pushed up the party's showing in the opinion polls.
Last weekend it was the turn of the Conservatives to choose a new leader. They opted for Peter MacKay, the son of another member of Mr Mulroney's government. The Tories have sunk even lower than the NDP. Can Mr MacKay revive them? He has good looks, affability and an endearing tendency not to take himself too seriously. And he has a winsome girlfriend whose father was...yes, yet another of Mr Mulroney's ministers.
But Mr MacKay's victory owed more to Dallas than to Dynasty. Facing a fourth ballot at an unexpectedly dramatic and deadlocked convention, Mr MacKay won by promising to "review" the costs and benefits of Canada's free-trade agreement with the United States. A small but well-organised group of Conservatives sees free trade as fatal to Canada's independence. But most of the Tory party--including the new leader himself--see the agreement as Mr Mulroney's crowning accomplishment. So Mr MacKay has hurt his own prospects. 
That prompted relief and gloating from the governing Liberals of Jean Chretien, who plans to step down as prime minister early next year. They have been in power since 1993, thanks partly to the opposition's divisions. Only a revitalised Tory party might pose a serious national threat to them.
The Liberals have a family saga of their own. Paul Martin, Canada's finance minister until last year, looks certain to win the Liberal leadership at a party convention in November, and thus become prime minister. Mr Martin's father ran several times for the Liberal leadership, but never with the money or organisation that his son commands. Mr Martin looks likely to hold the top job for a while--perhaps until Justin Trudeau, the son of another Liberal prime minister, makes his anticipated entry into politics.

text:
A decisive step towards same-sex marriage
FOR gays in Canada--and perhaps for those in the United States--June 17th may well go down in history as marking a big step towards their enjoyment of a right previously confined to heterosexuals. Just a week after the Ontario Court of Appeal ruled that same-sex marriages were legal in Canada's most populous province, the federal government announced that it would draft a bill to make this national policy. So, to the dismay of social conservatives, it was not a bad day for Canadian judicial activism either.
The bill is likely to become law. If it does, Canada would follow Belgium and the Netherlands to become the third country to give legal status to same-sex unions. Canadian marriage licences are accepted in the United States; many gay Americans are now likely to cross the border to wed, throwing American law into confusion.
Many Canadians were surprised at the speed with which Jean Chretien's Liberal government endorsed the court's decision. The House of Commons' justice committee, which had heard hundreds of witnesses on the issue, had yet to report. Although one poll shows 54% support for the move, a large majority of older people and those in rural areas are against. 
The government had two reasons for haste. Lower courts in British Columbia and Quebec had already made similar rulings. The justice minister had to decide by June 30th whether to appeal the British Columbia ruling to the Supreme Court. Secondly, and more compellingly, the Ontario court made its ruling of June 10th effective immediately, ordering officials to issue licences that day. More than 100 gay couples rushed to get married. One person to do so was a former bank manager, another a crown attorney.
The Ontario court, like the others, based its ruling on Section 15 of Canada's Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which the judges have interpreted as forbidding discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. The court called the exclusion of gays from the institution of marriage illogical, offensive and unjustifiable. These words carried additional clout since they were delivered by Roy McMurtry, Ontario's Chief Justice, who as a provincial minister in 1982 worked alongside Mr Chretien (then the federal justice minister) in a three-man "kitchen cabinet" to win support for the Charter.
But backing among Liberal MPs for same-sex marriage is far from solid. Their doubts were on display at a meeting last week of the House of Commons' justice committee. When Svend Robinson, an MP for the leftish New Democrats and a gay activist, moved a motion to accept the Ontario court ruling, the Liberals on the committee split 5-4 in favour, even though government whips had replaced two opponents of the measure with supporters. Bill Graham, the foreign minister, whose Toronto constituency has Canada's largest population of gays and lesbians, gave a passionate speech in favour to a meeting of Liberal MPs. He got a mixed reaction. Some opposition stems from growing disquiet about judicial activism. 
Mr Chretien has said he will refer the bill to the Supreme Court to make sure it is constitutional, and then submit it to a free vote in Parliament. The battle will be bruising. An influential group of lawyers, professors, bishops and Islamic leaders issued a statement against the change. If the bill is approved, Ralph Klein, the conservative premier of Alberta, threatens to use a constitutional get-out clause to block its implementation in his province. But Canada as a whole is less socially conservative than Alberta, or than the United States. And the judiciary has left Parliament with little choice but to follow its lead. It has probably set the country on the road to a small revolution in family law and family life.
Caption: Just don't try it yet in Alberta

text:
A clean-up with mixed motives
IN SOME ways Jean Chretien's last summer as Canada's prime minister is proving less serene than he might have hoped. Most of his Liberal Party's caucus of MPs, and many of his ministers, have now switched their loyalties to his likely successor, and bitter rival, Paul Martin. When they return to Ottawa in the autumn, the caucus may prove obstreperous, perhaps blocking social measures, such as an overhaul of the Indian Act. Mr Chretien intends these to be part of his legacy (he plans to step down next February). Instead, his last year may be remembered for another radical measure--one that has caused some of the Liberal discontent.
Late last month, Mr Chretien secured approval of a law that imposes a sweeping ban on all but the smallest political donations by businesses or trade unions. Instead, private individuals will be encouraged to contribute more to politics through bigger tax breaks. But most of the shortfall will be picked up by taxpayers through an elaborate system of public finance, based on votes at previous elections. A one-off federal payment to the parties of C$20m ($14.8m) will cover the transition costs of switching to the new system next year. 
Mr Chretien's government has been tainted by scandals in which big Liberal donors have received favours, including juicy contracts which were not put out to tender. One of the more nagging cases implicated the prime minister himself; another is the subject of police investigations which could embarrass Mr Chretien even in retirement. The prime minister denies that those controversies inspired the law. The problem, he says, is a public perception that influence is for sale, which breeds cynicism and mistrust of politicians.
The law applies to political parties, their leadership contenders and their election candidates. Its main beneficiaries are likely to be opposition parties such as the right-wing Canadian Alliance and the separatist Bloc Quebecois. Neither raises a fraction as much corporate cash as the Liberals. Each will now receive millions of dollars of public money. And the left-wing New Democrats will no longer have to depend on labour unions for cash.
The Alliance still voted against the law. But the sharpest opposition came from Mr Chretien's own ranks. The Liberals have become the party of corporate Canada, and have most to lose financially from the new rules. "Dumb as a bag of hammers," was the verdict of Stephen LeDrew, the Liberal Party president, a supporter of Mr Martin. (Mr Chretien's right-hand man returned the compliment by sending Mr LeDrew a bag of hammers, with a note encouraging him to use them to "knock some sense into your head".) 
To his critics, the law looks plain hypocritical. In a decade as prime minister, Mr Chretien has made a regular ritual of big-donor dinners, bringing in as much as C$1m a night. Now, his successors will be denied this source of wealth. Mr Martin is even closer to Canadian business than Mr Chretien. Whether or not it succeeds in cleaning up the image of Canadian politics, the new law is likely to make life difficult for Mr Martin. That just might have been the intention.
Caption: Martin will be reduced to sponsored hoops

text:
Politics
Saddam Hussein's sons, Uday and Qusay, were killed in an American missile barrage on a villa in Mosul after an informant, who presumably gets the $30m bounty on offer, led the Americans to their hideout. A message from Saddam, apparently recorded two days earlier, urged resistance to continue; two American soldiers were killed immediately after the sons' deaths, and three more the next day. George Bush said the death of Saddam's sons should reassure Iraqis that the former regime would not come back.
Rebels continued their assault on Liberia's capital Monrovia. A force of about 1,300 Nigerian peacekeepers, now in Sierra Leone, is supposed to be redeployed to Liberia in about a week.
After strong disagreement between Israel and the Palestinian Authority over the number of Palestinian prisoners that Israel is prepared to release, Mahmoud Abbas set off for his first visit as prime minister to President George Bush in Washington. Ariel Sharon will follow him there next week.
In a wide security sweep, Saudi Arabia arrested 16 suspected al-Qaeda supporters. Iran also announced that it was holding several senior members of al-Qaeda. Morocco began the trial of people charged with involvement in the suicide bombing in Casablanca in May.
Canada recalled its ambassador from Tehran when Iran declined its request that the body of Zahra Kazemi, a Canadian journalist who died from a blow to the head while under arrest, should be returned to Canada.
So Tome's president returned home after signing a deal with the coup leader who toppled him last week.
Mass destruction
The row in Britain over the government's alleged "sexing-up" of intelligence on Iraq's supposed weapons of mass destruction spun out of control. David Kelly, a defence ministry adviser exposed as a source for the BBC's allegation, committed suicide. The press savaged Tony Blair and his chief spin doctor, Alastair Campbell--and the BBC. 
Italy's senate passed a bill easing restrictions on large television companies. Big gainer: Mediaset, controlled by Fininvest, a vehicle of Silvio Berlusconi. The bill went to the lower house. That house passed a bill that was supposed to regulate Mr Berlusconi's conflicts of interest. It won't, said the left.
In Spain, ETA terrorists seeking independence for the Basques exploded two bombs on the Costa Blanca tourist coast at the other side of the country. And in France, Corsican separatists set off bombs on the island and the mainland. Corsicans recently narrowly voted down a government plan to give the island more autonomy.
Poland's government dropped a media bill that would make it harder for press publishers to buy into television. It had led to a scandal over claims that politicians had sought bribes from the publisher most concerned to ease the rules.
Platon Lebedev, a major shareholder in Yukos, Russia's biggest oil producer, was freed after three weeks in jail. His arrest, following probes into Yukos's dealings and taxes, had been seen as an attack on the company and its boss, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, badly rattling the stockmarket.
Good ol' boys
Italy's controversial prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, visited George Bush at his ranch in Crawford, Texas. At a brief news conference, both men, wearing cowboy boots, spoke about nuclear arms, peace in the Middle East and repairing relations between Europe and America.
James Davis, a member of New York's city council, was shot dead at City Hall by a political opponent. The killer was subsequently shot dead by a policeman.
California's secretary of state said that the campaign to unseat Gray Davis, California's governor, has collected 1.3m votes, more than enough to force a recall ballot. A special election could now be held as early as September 23rd.
A grand-jury investigation into allegations of sexual abuse by priests in Boston's Catholic archdiocese will not result in any criminal indictments; instead it has reported on ways to prevent further cases. Alleged victims criticised the decision as "deference" to the church.
Private Jessica Lynch returned to a hero's welcome in her hometown of Palestine, West Virginia. The details of her unit's capture and subsequent rescue during the Iraq war are still hotly disputed.
Concealed weapons
Amid fears that North Korea's nuclear-weapons programme may be more advanced than was previously thought, Japan was said to be urging America to make concessions to end the tension in the peninsula.
Two of Japan's opposition parties, the Democratic Party and the Liberal Party, agreed to merge in a move to defeat Junichiro Koizumi's ruling coalition. Speculation grew that a general election may be held this year.
An Australian-led peacekeeping force began to arrive in the Solomon Islands to restore law and order to the troubled Pacific archipelago.
Eight soldiers and seven civilians were killed in attacks in Indian-administered Kashmir. India blamed Pakistan-backed guerrillas, but its defence minister, George Fernandes, said it would continue to seek peace with its neighbour. 
Not very Manley
John Manley, Canada's deputy prime minister, pulled out of the contest to succeed Jean Chretien as leader of the Liberal Party (and thus prime minister). He gave his backing to Paul Martin, a former finance minister and long the front-runner for the job.
Carlos Castano, the leader of Colombia's right-wing paramilitary vigilantes, said that 5,000 of his men would assemble at government-patrolled camps within three months, as part of peace talks.
Some 100,000 people lined the streets of New York for the funeral of Celia Cruz, a Cuban-born salsa singer.
Brazil's senate unanimously approved a bill imposing tough new gun controls and proposing a referendum in 2005 to ban gun sales. The bill now goes to the lower house.

 Italy 's controversial prime minister , Silvio Berlusconi , visited George Bush at his ranch in Crawford , Texas . At a brief news conference , both men , wearing cowboy boots , spoke about nuclear arms , peace in the Middle East and repairing relations between Europe and America . 
 James Davis , a member of New York 's city council , was shot dead at City Hall by a political opponent . The killer was subsequently shot dead by a policeman . 
 California 's secretary of state said that the campaign to unseat Gray Davis , California 's governor , has collected 1.3 m votes , more than enough to force a recall ballot . A special election could now be held as early as September 23rd . 
 A grand - jury investigation into allegations of sexual abuse by priests in Boston 's Catholic archdiocese will not result in any criminal indictments ; instead it has reported on ways to prevent further cases . Alleged victims criticised the decision as " deference " to the church . 
 Private Jessica Lynch returned to a hero 's welcome in her hometown of Palestine , West Virginia . The details of her unit 's capture and subsequent rescue during the Iraq war are still hotly disputed . 
 Concealed weapons 
 Amid fears that North Korea 's nuclear - weapons programme may be more advanced than was previously thought , Japan was said to be urging America to make concessions to end the tension in the peninsula . 
 Two of Japan 's opposition parties , the Democratic Party and the Liberal Party , agreed to merge in a move to defeat Junichiro Koizumi 's ruling coalition . Speculation grew that a general election may be held this year . 
 An Australian - led peacekeeping force began to arrive in the Solomon Islands to restore law and order to the troubled Pacific archipelago . 
 Eight soldiers and seven civilians were killed in attacks in Indian - administered Kashmir . India blamed Pakistan - backed guerrillas , but its defence minister , George Fernandes , said it would continue to seek peace with its neighbour . 
 Not very Manley 
 John Manley , Canada 's deputy prime minister , pulled out of the contest to succeed Jean Chretien as leader of the Liberal Party ( and thus Jean Chretien ) . He gave his backing to Paul Martin , a former finance minister and long the front - runner for Jean Chretien . 
 Carlos Castano , the leader of Colombia 's right - wing paramilitary vigilantes , said that 5,000 of his men would assemble at government - patrolled camps within three months , as part of peace talks . 
 Some 100,000 people lined the streets of New York for the funeral of Celia Cruz , a Cuban - born salsa singer . 
 Brazil 's senate unanimously approved a bill imposing tough new gun controls and proposing a referendum in 2005 to ban gun sales . The bill now goes to the lower house .

text:
Paul Martin's main rival drops out
THE contest to succeed Jean Chretien as leader of the Liberal Party and thus as Canada's prime minister is an epic, but hardly a drama. The successor will not be chosen until November. But ever since last August, when Mr Chretien announced that he planned to retire in February 2004, the undisputed favourite has been Paul Martin, his former finance minister. The whole exercise became even more anti-climactic on July 22nd when John Manley, the deputy prime minister and Mr Martin's strongest rival, pulled out, admitting that he couldn't win. Neither, he said, can Sheila Copps, the leftish heritage minister, the only remaining challenger.
Mr Manley said that it would be "irresponsible" to continue to demand the time and money of his supporters. Money was a problem. He had raised less than a third of the C$6.4m ($4.6m) Mr Martin has amassed, and recently had to lay off campaign workers. Mr Manley may also have been thinking about his job prospects. 
Both men are on the Liberal right. With few policy differences between them, Mr Manley chose to attack Mr Martin's integrity, and especially the conflicts of interest raised by his business empire. That got few results beyond hard feelings in the Martin camp. By dropping out, Mr Manley has allowed time for the bitterness to subside. By predicting that Mr Martin will make "an excellent prime minister", he may have reserved a top cabinet job for himself. 
He has also avoided the potential embarrassment of finishing behind Ms Copps. She has little money, but does have a clear policy message and passionate supporters. Defeat at her hands might have doomed Mr Manley in a race he might win: that to succeed Mr Martin, who at 64 is not expected to serve much more than one term as prime minister. Mr Manley, like Ms Copps, is more than a decade younger than Mr Martin. 
Ms Copps pledges to fight to the last, even though some pundits predict that she will lose by as much as nine to one. In power since 1993 and facing weak opposition, the Liberals "need a great debate", she says. "We can't sleepwalk our way into a new government without a test of ideas." 
Even so, Mr Manley's withdrawal may put pressure on Mr Chretien to step down before February. The November leadership convention looks a formality. So the Liberal caucus in parliament will now take their cue from Mr Martin. Senior civil servants are already doing as much. By leaving early, Mr Chretien, who has long tried to thwart his rival's leadership ambitions, might disrupt Mr Martin's plans for an early election next spring--and might thus turn it into a real contest.

text:
Jean Chretien, historical monument
POLITICIANS, more than most mortals, like to be remembered by something tangible and preferably grandiose. Canadian prime ministers are no exception--or at least not Liberal ones. Lester Pearson gave his country its maple-leaf flag, and built Ottawa's National Arts Centre, opened in 1969. Pierre Trudeau added a new home for the National Gallery, and the Canadian Museum of Civilisation. 
So how to remember Jean Chretien, who plans to step down in February after more than ten years as prime minister and 40 years in parliament? Ottawa already has some 15 museums, celebrating everything from aircraft to skis. Instead, officials came up with the idea of building a mile-long Washington-style boulevard up to the Parliament Buildings. But this would have involved demolishing several historic buildings, and was derided by architects and many others. So the scheme has been abbreviated to a plaza, two blocks long, near Parliament.
Another notion was to associate Mr Chretien's name with a cultural project already under way. One contender was the new national portrait gallery being housed in the former American embassy, opposite Parliament. But it is too modest. So how about the Canadian War Museum? It is due to open in 2005, Mr Chretien turned the first earth, and the federal government has contributed C$84m ($61m). Apart from its escalating cost, there is another problem: it is hardly the most suitable memorial for a man who opposed both wars against Iraq and shrank the armed forces.
Finally, Mr Chretien's aides have hit on the former railway station, plumb in the middle of Ottawa. It was the venue for negotiations over Canada's 1982 constitution (in which Mr Chretien took part as justice minister) and for the signing in 1999 of the Treaty of Ottawa, banning landmines. It narrowly escaped being turned into a national Sports Hall of Fame. Instead, earlier this summer, Mr Chretien, in an unusually eloquent speech, announced that it will become the Canadian History Centre. 
That met howls of protest. Provincial museums claim to be starved of federal funds; they squealed at the estimated cost of C$100m. Mohawk leaders want museums to return ancestral bones. Museums, Mr Chretien has found, are alive with controversy.

text:
Politics
George Bush, pledging "no retreat" in Iraq, claimed that America was making good progress in restoring order to the country. But the State Department signalled, for the first time, that America might consider a multinational force under the UN provided it was led by an American.
Meanwhile, bloody incidents continued in Iraq, including an assassination attempt on a leading Shia cleric. Relief agencies cut back their operations. The UN Security Council voted to increase protection for aid workers in conflict zones. Paul Bremer, the American administrator, said Iraq would need aid of "several tens of billions" in the coming year. 
The United States, fulfilling a promise made in the wake of invading Iraq, closed its operations at Prince Sultan airbase in Saudi Arabia.
In a further sign of his unwillingness to surrender control to the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, Yasser Arafat appointed General Jibril Rajoub as national security adviser in open rivalry to Muhammad Dahlan, the security minister. But he also called on militant groups to return to the ceasefire they renounced last week.
A leaked report on Iran from the International Atomic Energy Agency says inspectors found traces of highly enriched uranium in samples taken from the Natanz nuclear facility. Iran claims that the samples were contaminated by imported equipment.
The British arrested Hadi Soleimanpour, a former Iranian ambassador to Argentina who is studying for a doctorate at Durham University, for possible extradition to Argentina in connection with a bombing in 1994. Another wanted Iranian was briefly arrested in Belgium. In a separate case, two Iranian interrogators are being charged over the death of a Canadian journalist, Zahra Kazemi, in custody in Tehran.
Rwanda's president, Paul Kagame, won 95% of the vote in a presidential election. Though there is convincing evidence that voters were intimidated, Mr Kagame has earned support across the country's bitter ethnic divide.
South Africa's anti-graft unit, the Scorpions, said it had a prima facie case of corruption against the deputy president, Jacob Zuma, but had decided not to prosecute him. Opposition parties demanded that he resign, but President Thabo Mbeki stood by him.
The 14 countries of the Southern African Development Community signed a mutual defence pact. This allows for diplomatic or military intervention in a member country to stop internal conflict. 
On the spot
Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, gave evidence to the Hutton inquiry into the suicide of David Kelly, a Ministry of Defence scientist who had claimed that the government's dossier of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction had been "sexed up". Mr Blair said he contested the allegation because it was so serious. If it were true, he would have had to resign, he said.
Germany's government published a long-awaited public-pensions plan by a commission headed by an economist, Bert Rurup, who said that Germans should retire at 67 rather than today's 65 and that they should expect pensions worth 40% of gross average earnings rather than today's 48%.
Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said his government might raise the retirement age; many Italians in the public sector can get a pension at 57.
The governor of Russia's oil-rich Pacific-coast island of Sakhalin, died with 19 others in a helicopter crash on the Kamchatka peninsula. 
Three bombs killed three people in the southern Russian city of Krasnodar, and a car bomb killed Mahomedsalikh Gusayev, a minister in the Russian republic of Dagestan, next to Chechnya. Terrorists are presumed to have made both attacks.
Trading partners
Peru agreed to become an associate member of Mercosur, South America's main trade block headed by Brazil and Argentina; Chile and Bolivia are already associates, having signed a free-trade agreement with the group without joining its customs union.
Venezuela's supreme court appointed a provisional electoral authority, whose first job will be to organise a referendum on the rule of President Hugo Chvez.
Canada's prime minister, Jean Chretien, signed an agreement granting self-government to the Tlicho, an Indian people. Under the agreement, the Tlicho will get a share in the royalties of three diamond mines in the Northwest Territories.
Blasts in Mumbai
More than 50 people were killed, and over 150 injured, by two bombs in Mumbai (formerly Bombay). Initial suspicion fell on a domestic group, with links to a Pakistan-based terrorist organisation.
Talks between America, North Korea, South Korea, Japan, China and Russia started in Beijing, aimed at ending the crisis triggered by last year's discovery of North Korea's illicit nuclear programme.
Indonesia postponed plans to divide Papua province into three, following violent clashes which left four dead. The province was until recently called Irian Jaya, a name resented by Papuans.
The chief minister of Uttar Pradesh, India's largest state, resigned.
Moving words
A two-ton block of granite depicting the Ten Commandments was removed from the state courthouse in Alabama. Roy Moore, the state's chief justice, was suspended for defying decrees by a federal court and fellow judges that the installation broke constitutional rules on the separation of church and state.
The General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative unit, published its findings into the Bush administration's energy policy. The report criticised Vice-President Dick Cheney for hampering the inquiry by his refusal to hand over key documents relating to corporate influence on the 2001 "energy task force".
The Department of Justice reported that 23m serious crimes were committed in America in 2002, the lowest level since 1973. However, preliminary figures indicated that 16,110 people had been murdered, a slight rise over 2001.

text:
An innovative land-rights treaty
CANADIANS have long been proud of their tolerance of cultural diversity. Now it is taking them down some innovative legal paths. On August 25th, Jean Chretien journeyed to the remote village of Rae-Edzo, deep in the Northwest Territories, and signed an agreement bestowing self-government and mineral wealth on the 4,000 Dogrib Indians, who prefer to call themselves the Tlicho First Nation. "We lead the world in the recognition of aboriginal rights," the prime minister said. 
Indeed. The Tlicho treaty is only the second of its kind in Canada--the first, in 1998, involved the Nisga'a of north-west British Columbia--but more may now follow. Indian claims on much of British Columbia have cast doubt on who owns what and held up mining investment. The Tlicho accord clears up the doubts by granting full rights to the aboriginals. Eight other first nations may now reach similar agreements, though claims in urban areas, such as Vancouver, will be trickier to settle.
The Tlicho are fortunate that their ancestral land abuts a diamond industry of sparkling promise, which Canada's government wants to expand. Mines at Ekati and Diavik produce diamonds worth C$1 billion ($710m) per year; a third mine is due to start production in 2006. Canada is already the world's fourth-biggest diamond producer, with 12% of the market. The Tlicho will now gain 2% of the royalties from these three mines (most of the rest goes to the federal government). But they will get all the royalties from any new mines. Though most Canadian diamonds are sent abroad for processing, the Tlicho want to make Yellowknife a centre for cutting and polishing, and making jewellery. 
Diamonds are not the end of the story. The treaty gives the Tlicho ownership of an area almost as big as Switzerland around Yellowknife, together with its natural resources. They will also get C$152m in cash over 15 years and a C$5m training fund. Companies owned by the Tlicho (which include an ore haulier, an electricity generator and a travel agent) will have preference in the award of contracts. Their local governments will be able to make and enforce laws, collect taxes, levy royalties on mines, and regulate land use, education, family law and traditional medicine. After many years in limbo under federal control, "We're now going to have some say in our lives," said John Zoe, the Tlicho negotiator. Indian peoples elsewhere can only look on in envy. Unless they try to emulate the Tlicho.

text:
Politics
President George Bush defended the Iraq war at the United Nations and urged member states to help America rebuild the country; France's Jacques Chirac criticised the war and called on the Americans to transfer authority speedily to the Iraqis; Germany's Gerhard Schroder said differences over the war "have been left behind". A forthcoming report by the teams searching for Iraq's weapons of mass destruction was said to have found evidence of "programmes", but no actual arms. 
Iraq's Governing Council, appointed and guided by the Americans, announced that Iraq's economy is to be privatised and opened up to foreign investment, with the exception of its oil industry, which remains a state monopoly. 
In a second attack on the UN's headquarters in Baghdad, a car bomb exploded, killing the driver and an Iraqi policeman. A member of the Governing Council, Aqila al-Hashimi, was attacked outside her home and later died. The Iraqi Governing Council decided to limit the operations of two leading Arabic news channels, al-Jazeera and al-Arabiya, at least temporarily, for "encouraging terrorism".
Twenty-seven Israeli pilots, mostly reservists, said they would refuse to participate in "illegal and immoral" raids in the occupied West Bank and Gaza.
A special session of the UN General Assembly on 
HIV/AIDS
heard that 41m people are now infected, 30m of them Africans. At another AIDS conference in Kenya, it was reported that nearly 60% of the infected Africans are women.
The police in Zimbabwe cracked down harder on the Daily News, a banned independent newspaper, saying they would arrest the owner and about 60 journalists for operating without a licence, shortly after a government media commission refused to grant one.
A sharia appeals court in Nigeria acquitted Amina Lawal, a woman convicted of adultery by a lower court last year and sentenced to death by stoning. 
Rebels in Cote d'Ivoire suspended their participation in the power-sharing government. Both sides accused the other of scuttling the peace effort. The road linking north to south was closed. Cocoa prices soared.
The case for defence
The leaders of Britain, Germany and France, meeting in Berlin, agreed to move ahead towards defence co-operation under the European Union's aegis, but it was unclear how much ground, if any, Britain had given to Germany and France, which have been keener in the past to integrate EU defence.
In a speech at the UN in New York, after meeting George Bush, Mr Schroder indirectly asked for a permanent seat for Germany on the UN's Security Council.
The Christian Social Union, the Bavarian sister-party of Germany's Christian Democrats, crushed the Social Democrats in a state election on September 19th, by a margin of three to one. The result may strengthen the resolve of Edmund Stoiber, Bavaria's incumbent CSU premier, who failed narrowly to become Germany's chancellor last year, to seek Germany's top job next time round.
The Dutch foreign minister, Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, has been appointed NATO's secretary-general, replacing Britain's Lord Robertson, who is due to step down at the end of the year.
Latvians voted in a referendum, by 67% to 32%, to join the EU next year.
At a memorial service near Srebrenica in honour of the 7,000-plus Bosnian Muslims murdered there by Bosnian Serbs in 1995, the Bosnian Serbs' prime minister asked for "respect for the dead" and called for reconciliation.
Up to the job?
President George Bush's job-approval rating fell to 49%, the lowest of his presidency so far, according to the latest poll. It also showed that Wesley Clark, the latest Democratic candidate to enter the race for the presidency, trails Mr Bush by just seven percentage points.
An appeals court ruled that California's recall election should go ahead in October, reversing its earlier decision to postpone the ballot. The candidates held a third televised debate, with Arnold Schwarzenegger taking part this time.
An American air force translator working at Guantanamo Bay was charged with espionage. A Muslim army chaplain was also arrested on suspicion of spying.
In the wake of Hurricane Isabel, utility companies struggled to return electricity to more than 1m people along America's eastern seaboard. The storm will cost insurers some $1 billion. 
No change
Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, was re-elected as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party. In a cabinet reshuffle, Mr Koizumi retained his key economics minister, Heizo Takenaka, in both his posts, despite pressure from anti-reformists.
South Korea's government proposed the largest increase in defence spending in seven years. This comes on the heels of North Korea's refusal to dismantle its nuclear programme, as called for in a resolution from the UN's nuclear agency.
South Korea's ruling Millennium Democratic Party split. A new grouping, called the "People's Participatory Party", was launched by 37 members of parliament who fled from the MDP. The new party is the third-largest political group in parliament.
The prime ministers of China, Russia and four Central Asian countries signed agreements to establish a regional anti-terrorism centre in Uzbekistan. They also agreed to give the Shanghai Co-operation Organisation a central role in increasing economic ties among its members.
Next in line
Paul Martin, a former finance minister, took another big step towards becoming Canada's next prime minister, replacing Jean Chretien, who plans to step down in February. In an election for delegates to the ruling Liberal Party's leadership convention, some 90% of those chosen back Mr Martin.
Argentina offered short shrift to its creditors. It proposed to write down by 75% the value of $94 billion of bonds on which it defaulted in 2001. The bondholders wailed.
A young Briton escaped from kidnappers in a mountainous jungle region in northern Colombia. The kidnappers, thought to be from the ELN guerillas, continue to hold seven other foreigners.

A member of the Governing Council, Aqila al-Hashimi, was attacked outside her home and later died. The Iraqi Governing Council decided to limit the operations of two leading Arabic news channels, al-Jazeera and al-Arabiya, at least temporarily, for "encouraging terrorism".
Twenty-seven Israeli pilots, mostly reservists, said they would refuse to participate in "illegal and immoral" raids in the occupied West Bank and Gaza.
A special session of the UN General Assembly on 
HIV/AIDS
heard that 41m people are now infected, 30m of them Africans. At another AIDS conference in Kenya, it was reported that nearly 60% of the infected Africans are women.
The police in Zimbabwe cracked down harder on the Daily News, a banned independent newspaper, saying they would arrest the owner and about 60 journalists for operating without a licence, shortly after a government media commission refused to grant one.
A sharia appeals court in Nigeria acquitted Amina Lawal, a woman convicted of adultery by a lower court last year and sentenced to death by stoning. 
Rebels in Cote d'Ivoire suspended their participation in the power-sharing government. Both sides accused the other of scuttling the peace effort. The road linking north to south was closed. Cocoa prices soared.
The case for defence
The leaders of Britain, Germany and France, meeting in Berlin, agreed to move ahead towards defence co-operation under the European Union's aegis, but it was unclear how much ground, if any, Britain had given to Germany and France, which have been keener in the past to integrate EU defence.
In a speech at the UN in New York, after meeting George Bush, Mr Schroder indirectly asked for a permanent seat for Germany on the UN's Security Council.
The Christian Social Union, the Bavarian sister-party of Germany's Christian Democrats, crushed the Social Democrats in a state election on September 19th, by a margin of three to one. The result may strengthen the resolve of Edmund Stoiber, Bavaria's incumbent CSU premier, who failed narrowly to become Germany's chancellor last year, to seek Germany's top job next time round.
The Dutch foreign minister, Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, has been appointed NATO's secretary-general, replacing Britain's Lord Robertson, who is due to step down at the end of the year.
Latvians voted in a referendum, by 67% to 32%, to join the EU next year.
At a memorial service near Srebrenica in honour of the 7,000-plus Bosnian Muslims murdered there by Bosnian Serbs in 1995, the Bosnian Serbs' prime minister asked for "respect for the dead" and called for reconciliation.
Up to the job?
President George Bush's job-approval rating fell to 49%, the lowest of his presidency so far, according to the latest poll. It also showed that Wesley Clark, the latest Democratic candidate to enter the race for the presidency, trails Mr Bush by just seven percentage points.
An appeals court ruled that California's recall election should go ahead in October, reversing its earlier decision to postpone the ballot. The candidates held a third televised debate, with Arnold Schwarzenegger taking part this time.
An American air force translator working at Guantanamo Bay was charged with espionage. A Muslim army chaplain was also arrested on suspicion of spying.
In the wake of Hurricane Isabel, utility companies struggled to return electricity to more than 1m people along America's eastern seaboard. The storm will cost insurers some $1 billion. 
No change
Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, was re-elected as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party. In a cabinet reshuffle, Mr Koizumi retained his key economics minister, Heizo Takenaka, in both his posts, despite pressure from anti-reformists.
South Korea's government proposed the largest increase in defence spending in seven years. This comes on the heels of North Korea's refusal to dismantle its nuclear programme, as called for in a resolution from the UN's nuclear agency.
South Korea's ruling Millennium Democratic Party split. A new grouping, called the "People's Participatory Party", was launched by 37 members of parliament who fled from the MDP. The new party is the third-largest political group in parliament.
The prime ministers of China, Russia and four Central Asian countries signed agreements to establish a regional anti-terrorism centre in Uzbekistan. They also agreed to give the Shanghai Co-operation Organisation a central role in increasing economic ties among its members.
Next in line
Paul Martin, a former finance minister, took another big step towards becoming Canada's next prime minister, replacing Jean Chretien, who plans to step down in February. In an election for delegates to the ruling Liberal Party's leadership convention, some 90% of those chosen back Mr Martin.
Argentina offered short shrift to its creditors. It proposed to write down by 75% the value of $94 billion of bonds on which it defaulted in 2001. The bondholders wailed.
A young Briton escaped from kidnappers in a mountainous jungle region in northern Colombia. The kidnappers, thought to be from the ELN guerillas, continue to hold seven other foreigners.

text:
Exciting times, but much unfinished business, in the north
IN 1995, the Wall Street Journal, pondering Canada's economic slump, bottomless fiscal deficit and towering public debt, judged that America's northern neighbour had become "an honorary member of the Third World". Four years earlier, The Economist had fretted that Canada was "on the brink of bust-up". We quoted a Canadian who compared his country's federation to a "boring party where the guests are too polite to leave. However, when the first guest makes a move to go, the others each claim other engagements and make a quick exit." Still a fair description? Today's Canada is neither boring nor so exciting that it is on the brink of disintegration. Indeed, a cautious case can be made that Canada is now rather cool. 
Part of what makes it cool is a certain boldness in social matters. Canada's government has recently announced its support for pioneering bills to legalise gay marriage and decriminalise marijuana, both excellent liberal ideas. It has granted home rule and control over mineral rights to some of its indigenous Indians. While other rich countries suffer a racist backlash over immigration, Canadians welcome migrants and are proud of their tolerance and cultural diversity. This has turned Canada's big cities into vibrant, cosmopolitan places. Canadian writers and other cultural figures enjoy unprecedented international success.
This social liberalism points to an increasingly self-confident country. Canada has at last tackled--or at least learnt to manage--the problems that beset it a decade ago when Jean Chretien took office as prime minister. In 1995, a referendum on independence in Quebec was lost by only a few thousand votes. This year, the separatists lost power in the province after an election in which independence was barely an issue. Mr Chretien can claim some credit: he has been a robust federalist, ramming through the Clarity Act, which places legal obstacles in the path of separation. And Quebec, in turn, has benefited from Canada's economic turnaround.
Deficits have been left far behind and the public debt slashed. Since the late 1990s, Canada's economy has outperformed the rest of the rich world. It no longer depends only on lumber, mining, oil and cars. Like any economy, Canada's is vulnerable to shocks, such as the recent outbreak in Toronto of the SARS respiratory disease and a case of mad-cow disease which has curtailed beef exports. But Canada has begun to close the gap between its living standards and those in the United States. Though this gap, at 15%, is far from trivial, many Canadians believe that their public health care, better protection of the environment and lower crime rate make them better off than their southern neighbours. Throw in its social liberalism, and Canada's "third way" looks to some like an attractive alternative to an increasingly conservative America. Certainly, Canadians themselves seem content. This week, Paul Martin took another big step on his irresistible journey to the prime minister's office ()see page 57. Though he and Mr Chretien are personal rivals, they are the Liberal Party's co-architects of Canada's economic renaissance. Pundits expect Mr Martin to call a general election next year--and for the Liberals to win a fourth consecutive term.
The contrast across the 49th parallel between Canada and the United States makes for healthy competition in social and economic policy. But as with many a good-news story, Canada's loses a bit of its lustre under closer inspection. People continue to vote with their feet: a few thousand Americans move north each year, but are still outnumbered by Canadians moving south--and not, probably, just for the sun. Though the poor fare better in Canada, the middle classes earn less and pay higher taxes. The Liberal Party's domination of Canadian politics is far from being an unalloyed good. Without an effective opposition, much of the job of holding the government in check falls to the judiciary, policing a Charter of Rights which on one view, unlike America's Bill of Rights, tilts too far towards the rights of groups rather than individuals. 
Unfinished masterpiece
On top of this, there are some big things that Canada continues to get wrong, and other big things that could go wrong without preventive action. In general, Canada still taxes too much, invests too little, and enjoys a free ride in defence from the United States. Since the terrorist attacks of September 2001, security and defence are a special worry. Much of Canada's economic success is built on a 1988 free-trade agreement that has seen a massive expansion in cross-border trade: the United States now takes 88% of Canada's exports. Just-in-time production means that components can cross the border three times in the making of a car, for example. If security threats turn the border into a barrier, firms will think twice before putting a factory in Ontario rather than Ohio. That does not stop Canada from holding different views about the world from those of George Bush, but it needs to work harder than Mr Chretien has done at keeping the trust of the United States. 
Conversely, firms also need positive reasons to invest in a market that is only a tenth the size of America's. This implies that Canada should continue with the tax cuts that Mr Martin launched as finance minister. At some point, however, this will damage the welfare state on which Canadians set such store. So far, the federal government has been able to balance its books mainly by passing this problem on to the provinces, whose finances are poised to unravel. The cities, too, have demands: today, the most visible cleavage in Canada is not between French-speaking Quebec and the English-speaking rest, but between five large urban areas (dynamic, successful, with many immigrants but with strained public services) and the rest (mainly rural, declining economies with high unemployment, kept alive by federal aid).
To keep its new cool, Canada must therefore overhaul the way its government allocates power and money. Quebec's new Liberal government could lead the way: it wants the private sector to help to deliver public services, as well as some further devolution. The rest of the country should follow. Canada has turned a corner. But it is not yet time to abandon its new spirit of risk-taking and experimentation.

text:
The Liberal hegemon marches on, but circumstances may require the new leader to embrace change as well as continuity
LAST week, on the second day of the new parliamentary session, Canada's right-wing opposition went for the jugular. It denounced Jean Chretien's Liberal government for what one opposition leader called an "activist assault on marriage" in the form of a bill giving legal status to unions between two people of the same sex. The opposition scored a moral victory: its motion won the support of backbench Liberals, and failed only narrowly. 
But the debate in the gothic Commons chamber in Ottawa, a less claustrophobic but no less rowdy clone of Westminster, served to show the opposition's own marginal status. According to the opinion polls, a narrow majority of Canadians back same-sex marriage; among younger and urban voters, far more do. In choosing the issue for its showpiece debate, the opposition underlined that on the main battlegrounds of politics, on issues of money, the Liberals are dominant.
That dominance is based on Mr Chretien's success, in a decade in office, in sorting out Canada's public finances without abandoning its welfare state. In 1993, Canada's fiscal deficit stood at 6% of GDP and public debt totalled 64% of GDP. By 1997, the budget was in balance, and deficits were going out of fashion in the provinces. Mr Chretien achieved this partly be retaining an unpopular sales tax introduced by his Conservative predecessor. But he also slashed defence spending, foreign aid and transfers to the provinces, for health and other services. As economic growth returned, the government began cutting taxes and repaying public debt (which now stands at 40% of GDP) while restoring some of the cuts.
This was a double act between Mr Chretien and Paul Martin, his finance minister from 1993 until last year. In political terms, it has been highly effective. "Our success is that we've covered such a wide ground in the middle," Mr Chretien told The Economist. "A right-winger who wants a balanced budget can't complain at me. If on the left you want more money for health and education, you're happy too. That makes it very difficult for the opposition." Indeed so, though the opposition, split four ways and lacking national reach, has added difficulties of its own. 
Partners to rivals
Partners in government, Mr Chretien and Mr Martin are personal rivals. Many Canadians believe that Mr Chretien, who has been the target of small-scale corruption allegations (which he denies), should have stepped down earlier. His departure is an awkwardly lengthy one: he is not due to go until February. But all his efforts to block Mr Martin have failed. Last weekend, Liberals chose the delegates to their leadership convention, due in November. Some 90% of them are known to be supporters of Mr Martin, with only 10% backing Sheila Copps, a nationalist from the Liberal left who is his only remaining rival. 
Mr Martin's arrival will herald a personality change at the top. Mr Chretien, a federalist Quebecker, is a skilled and instinctive political fighter whose antennae are tuned resolutely to Canada rather than the world. Mr Martin, an Ontarian who speaks fluent French and whose political home is in Montreal, has broader experience. He entered politics only after building a shipping business. He is often said to be further to the right than Mr Chretien. But a new book* by a Canadian journalist describes a more complex figure: a gregarious technocrat, almost Clintonian in his intellectual interests if not in charisma. As the son of one of the Liberal founders of Canada's welfare state he is less conservative than he looks. He has a reputation for competence, but some detect a tendency to dither. 
Will policy change, too? Mr Martin faces an agenda that is more challenging than many Canadians might imagine. It can be summarised under four, overlapping, headings: the economy and the public finances; federal-provincial relations; immigration; and foreign policy.
Take the economy first. Canada has competed successfully with the United States (see chart 1 on next page) partly because of lower wages and a weaker currency. If it is to close the income gap that still divides the two countries, as Mr Martin says he wants to, it needs to raise its productivity further. Canadian workers are less productive because businesses invest less than their American counterparts (see chart 2).
"Canada has a small, dispersed population and a cold climate. In North America, the United States has a huge market and Mexico has lower costs. So we have to have better public policies to tilt towards Canada," says Jack Mintz of the CD Howe Institute, a Toronto research centre. Canada has something of an edge in education and health: for now, at least, the extra cost in taxes of Canada's public health system is similar to the health-insurance contributions made by American firms, says Mr Mintz. But despite cuts in corporate income tax, Canada's tax system still penalises investment. There are also legal restrictions on foreign investment (in banking, for example) which some would like to relax, but others argue are needed to defend Canadian national identity. 
Fiscal imbalance
Tax cuts are only one among many claims on the public purse. Perhaps the most pressing is the increasingly expensive health service, enshrined in the Canada Health Act. In February, Mr Chretien agreed to increase federal health spending, by more than C$30 billion ($20 billion) over five years. But the provinces, which are responsible for health and education, still complain of a "fiscal imbalance". All of them except energy-rich Alberta are poised to sink back into deficit, according to Hugh Segal of Montreal's Institute for Research on Public Policy. He says that health costs, which now account for about 50% of spending by the provinces (excluding debt payments), are "crowding out" other spending needs. Jean Charest, Quebec's new premier, wants a new Council of the Federation, at which the provinces would push Ottawa for further devolution. Meanwhile, big-city mayors, an impotent bunch in Canada, want a slice of the federal petrol tax.
Some Canadians argue that it was Mr Chretien, rather than his finance minister, who was the fiercer fiscal hawk. But on the public finances, Mr Martin insists that he will "stay the course"; he wants public debt to be "no higher than 25% of GDP". He also opposes more devolution, except of provincial powers to the cities. But maintaining the balancing act of economic growth and welfare provision may require more radical measures.
One solution would be to allow private health provision for the rich. That would create uproar. "It would be easier to campaign for a change in the Ten Commandments than in the Canada Health Act," says Mr Segal. So provinces will have to seek innovative ways of doing more with less. Marginally more feasible might be to tinker with the formula ("equalisation") under which money is shunted from rich provinces (Alberta and Ontario) to poor ones (the rest). This formula is a monument to the principle of universal public service: it encourages the unemployed in depressed areas such as Nova Scotia to stay at home on provincial welfare rolls rather than move in search of a job.
That is all the more ironic since Canada faces skill shortages. The solution has been large-scale immigration (230,000 immigrants arrived last year, in a country of 31.5m people). Nowadays, most are Asians, rather than Europeans. Denis Coderre, the immigration minister, insists the policy enjoys support across the political spectrum and is essential to maintain economic growth and social benefits. "We're a land of immigrants. It's the Canadian way," Mr Coderre says. Even so, Canada risks a backlash next time the economy cools. Already, there are signs that recent migrants are not doing as well as their predecessors--even though Canada selects most of them for their skills. "There is discrimination, there is racism. We're too polite to talk about them," says Usha George, who teaches social work at the University of Toronto. 
Lastly, some Canadians fret that their country is losing its place in the world. That argument looks exaggerated, except in one respect. Canada's defence spending has slipped to embarrassing levels. Even had the government and the country wanted to take part in the Iraq war (neither did), Canada would have been hard put to make a meaningful contribution (though it has 2,000 troops in Afghanistan). Berel Rodal, a banker in Ottawa, puts it this way: Canada has become "the world's biggest suburb, a wealthy place that worries about schools and parks" while leaving the "downtown issues" of defence and nuclear proliferation to others. 
According to Mr Martin, Canada's "number one challenge is keeping that American border open." Mr Chretien's relations with George Bush have evolved from distant to bad. That is partly because he made little effort to explain his Iraq policy to Canada's main trading partner. Since September 2001, the government has worked with its American counterpart to improve border security without disrupting trade. But Mr Martin wants closer ties, between legislators in each country as well as officials. He also talks more vaguely of trying to set up new international bodies to tackle issues such as migration and disease. And he wants Canada to be more active in trading with China, India, Brazil and Russia, where he sees an opportunity to lessen his country's dependence on the American market.
For now, Liberal hegemony looks as secure under Mr Martin as under Mr Chretien. Traditionally, Canadians have balanced their politics by ensuring that their province is governed by a different party than that in power in Ottawa. This balance is breaking down: this year the Liberals seized Quebec, and look poised to win Ontario from the Progressive Conservatives (Tories) in an election on October 2nd. 
The prospect of years more of opposition has pushed two conservative parties, the Western-based Alliance and the Tories into a fresh round of merger talks this month. Unity would be hard: the Alliance is conservative on the social issues that dominate the headlines in Canada, and the Tories are not. But Mr Martin would be unwise to assume he will lack opposition for ever. The better life in Canada gets, the harder it may be to keep it so.
*"Juggernaut: Paul Martin's Campaign for Chretien's Crown". By Susan Delacourt. Published in October 2003 by McClelland & Stewart, Toronto.

 Lastly , some Canadians fret that their country is losing its place in the world . That argument looks exaggerated , except in one respect . Canada 's defence spending has slipped to embarrassing levels . Even had the government and the country wanted to take part in the Iraq war ( neither did ) , Canada would have been hard put to make a meaningful contribution ( though it has 2,000 troops in Afghanistan ) . Berel Rodal , a banker in Ottawa , puts it this way : Canada has become " the world 's biggest suburb , a wealthy place that worries about schools and parks " while leaving the " downtown issues " of defence and nuclear proliferation to others . 
 According to Mr Martin , Canada 's " number one challenge is keeping that American border open . " Jean Chretien's relations with George Bush have evolved from distant to bad . That is partly because Jean Chretien made little effort to explain Jean Chretien's Iraq policy to Canada 's main trading partner . Since September 2001 , the government has worked with its American counterpart to improve border security without disrupting trade . But Mr Martin wants closer ties , between legislators in each country as well as officials . He also talks more vaguely of trying to set up new international bodies to tackle issues such as migration and disease . And he wants Canada to be more active in trading with China , India , Brazil and Russia , where he sees an opportunity to lessen his country 's dependence on the American market . 
 For now , Liberal hegemony looks as secure under Mr Martin as under Jean Chretien . Traditionally , Canadians have balanced their politics by ensuring that their province is governed by a different party than that in power in Ottawa . This balance is breaking down : this year the Liberals seized Quebec , and look poised to win Ontario from the Progressive Conservatives ( Tories ) in an election on October 2nd . 
 The prospect of years more of opposition has pushed two conservative parties , the Western - based Alliance and the Tories into a fresh round of merger talks this month . Unity would be hard : the Alliance is conservative on the social issues that dominate the headlines in Canada , and the Tories are not . But Mr Martin would be unwise to assume he will lack opposition for ever . The better life in Canada gets , the harder it may be to keep it so . 
 * " Juggernaut : Paul Martin 's Campaign for Jean Chretien's Crown " . By Susan Delacourt . Published in October 2003 by McClelland & Stewart , Toronto .

text:
After their triumph in Ontario, the Liberals are rampant
WHEN Ontario's Liberals secured a landslide victory in the provincial election of October 2nd, they also produced a political situation that Canada has not seen for 60 years. Given that the Quebec Liberals routed the separatists in their election in April, Liberals now control the two largest provinces, which together account for about two-thirds of the country's total population, economy and trade. Meanwhile, the federal Liberals this month mark a decade in power in Ottawa under Jean Chretien, and are set to win a fourth successive election under Paul Martin's leadership next year. Canada is looking increasingly like a one-party state.
In the past, Canadian voters have maintained a political balance by electing different parties at provincial and federal levels. Except for 17 Tory years, the Liberals have run the federal government since 1935, while the Progressive Conservatives have ruled Ontario for all but ten years of the past 60. Voters have sometimes contrived to spread power still more evenly by electing minority administrations at both levels. Last week the exaggerations of the first-past-the-post system gave Ontario's Liberals, led by Dalton McGuinty, a huge majority--72 of the 103 seats, with only 46% of the vote--while the Conservatives and New Democrats, who between them won half the popular vote, got just 31.
The erstwhile power balance had its downside, which may partly explain why Ontario voted as it did. Relations between Ottawa and the provinces are often fractious, with each blaming the other for unforeseen problems, such as this year's SARS outbreak. Doubtless the provincial premiers will still complain about the control Ottawa exercises over taxation, and the reduced funds that it has distributed for education and welfare services since 1994 (when Mr Martin, as finance minister, began eliminating the federal budget deficit). But Mr Martin--a shoo-in to take over as prime minister in February--has arranged an informal and unusual meeting with all the provincial premiers on November 16th. Meanwhile, Jean Charest, leader of the Quebec Liberals, is gathering the premiers on October 23rd at a meeting of the Council of the Federation, the body he has conceived to present the case for a more stable (and better-financed) relationship with Ottawa.
To his credit--and, it seems, to his benefit--Mr McGuinty ran a high-minded campaign, ignoring the personal attacks that Ernie Eves, the normally courteous outgoing Conservative premier, allowed his backroom staff to launch. Among other slurs, they alleged that Mr McGuinty was "a kitten-eating alien". But while clean, Mr McGuinty's campaign could prove expensive, and he will welcome any help his fellow premiers can offer as he sets about winkling money out of Ottawa to meet his election promises. His costly platform included pledges to keep class sizes for young pupils to a maximum of 20 students, which will require more teachers and classrooms, and to hire 8,000 nurses to help revive the health service. 
Still, Mr McGuinty's chances of meeting his pledges may be enhanced by Canada's new political geometry. He campaigned heavily in the suburban areas around Toronto, which in two previous elections had helped to return the Conservatives. Mr McGuinty won over many of these voters by professing a deep concern about the state of urban services. Happily for him, Mr Martin has voiced similar concerns. Equally helpfully, he represents the constituency that sends John Manley, the federal finance minister, to Ottawa. Canada may now be a one-party state, at least in parts, but Liberal hegemony may have some advantages.
Caption: Lock up your kittens, here comes McGuinty

text:
Paul Martin knocks on the prime-ministerial door
BY ANY measure, the departure of Jean Chretien has been painfully drawn-out. Back in August 2002, after almost a decade as prime minister, he announced that he would retire--but not until next February. His successor, Paul Martin, his former finance minister but a personal rival, is due to be anointed at a party convention starting on November 14th. Now, Mr Chretien seems to have accepted that there is no point in staying around much longer.
He is said to have paid a quiet visit to the governor-general, to ask her to be available to swear in a new cabinet in late November. Aides denied a report that he would take on a role on Africa for the UN. But Mr Chretien himself recently amended his timetable, saying he will leave "between now and February".
If he does go this month, few Canadians will object. Unofficially, Mr Martin has been the leader in waiting for months. Fewer Liberal MPs have shown up for some of Mr Chretien's recent caucus meetings than have attended casual policy chats with Mr Martin. Spending plans announced by ministers were thrown into question when aides to Mr Martin said that they would be "reviewed" (read cancelled) as soon as their man took over. 
If Mr Chretien does go early, much proposed legislation may disappear with him. More than a dozen bills passed by the House of Commons are now before the Senate. They include a much-debated law to ban human cloning but allow some stem-cell research. Other parts of Mr Chretien's "legacy agenda", including a bill to decriminalise marijuana, have yet to make it out of the Commons. Mr Martin, who is expected to call an election next spring, may not mind too much if that bill goes up in smoke.
