text:
The armed forces suffer from government indifference 
LAST month two Canadian soldiers were killed in Afghanistan when they drove over a land mine. An inevitable accident of war, you might think, except that their vehicle was 20 years old and lacked armour--a death trap, rather than a lifesaver. Their fate is symptomatic of the woeful state of Canada's armed forces. During the 1990s, the defence budget was cut by about 30% in real terms, while deployments continued apace. Such is the resulting accumulated strain that unless the government invests billions of dollars in new equipment, the armed forces face "extinction" as a capable fighting force within 15 years, according to Brian Macdonald of the Royal Canadian Military Institute, a defence think-tank in Toronto.
Canada has a proud tradition of taking part in peacekeeping operations. More than 3,500 of its soldiers are abroad, in places such as Afghanistan and Bosnia. A report on defence in 1994 promised that up to 10,000 troops would be available for service abroad. But lack of equipment makes that impossible. 
Defence spending has sunk to just 1.1% of GDP, its lowest level since before the second world war. That compares with an average among NATO members, excluding the United States, of 1.9% of GDP. Manpower in the services has fallen by roughly 30% over the past decade to fewer than 60,000. The shortfall is now critical: training of recruits has been disrupted because instructors have had to be sent abroad. 
Equipment is in an even worse state than manpower. Capital spending takes up 18.5% of the defence budget. That is enough to equip only one of the three services properly, says Mr Macdonald. The navy has some modern ships, but is short of spare parts. Worst hit is the air force, with just 350 aircraft, down from 725 in 1991. It is flying 40-year old transport aircraft and has had to cut maritime patrol flights. Its elderly fleet of Sea King helicopters (known as "flying coffins") require 30 hours of maintenance for every hour of flight. And they are unavailable for operations 40% of the time, according to David Rudd, of the Canadian Institute of Strategic Studies, another Toronto think-tank. Its Hercules transport aircraft, dating from the 1960s, are in even worse repair. The result is that Canada must depend on American planes to take its troops abroad.
This penury reflects the low priority given by voters to the armed forces. Many Canadians would rather that scarce government money was directed to health and education. That is what has happened. Facing a huge budget deficit, Jean Chretien's government took an axe to defence spending in the mid-1990s. Recently, improved public finances have allowed it modestly to increase the defence budget again, by C$1 billion ($1.3 billion) in 2003-04, for example. 
Paul Martin, who as finance minister implemented the cuts, is due to be elected as the new Liberal leader, and thus prime minister, at a party convention this weekend. He has promised to spend more on the armed forces. But economic growth, and thus tax revenues, have slowed. Overstretched cities and provinces are clamouring for more funds, too. 
Despite the difficulties, Canadian troops have peformed well as peacekeepers, in the Balkans and Afghanistan. What is needed is an overall review of defence and foreign policy. But it may take more deaths before that happens.

text:
Politics
Two bombs went off in Istanbul on November 20th killing at least 25 people and injuring over 300. Five days earlier, at least 25 people were killed and more than 300 injured after truck bombs exploded outside two synagogues in the city. The suicide bombers in the synagogue attacks were Turkish Kurds with alleged links to al-Qaeda.
President George Bush paid a three-day state visit to Britain amid a huge security operation to protect him from anti-war protesters and terrorists alike. In a speech, he said that the use of force was sometimes necessary, but that he believed in international institutions--provided they were "alert to the dangers" facing the world.
After a spate of anti-Semitic attacks in France, including the burning of a Jewish school, President Jacques Chirac convened a summit of political leaders to discuss the issue. The summit condemned the rise of anti-Semitism but offered no quick solutions.
Serbia failed, for a third time in just over a year, to elect a president because the turnout was below 50%. The failure may have been a blessing in disguise, because the leading candidate was a strong right-wing nationalist. His showing is ominous for the general election that has been called for the end of December. 
A left-wing pro-independence party in Spain's Catalonia did well in regional elections on November 16th. The Republican Left almost doubled its representation, to 23 seats in the 135-member regional assembly. It now holds the balance of power between the Socialists and the right-leaning nationalists who have usually run Catalonia. 
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, was confirmed as leader of the Social Democrats, securing the support of over 81% of delegates at the party congress in Bochum. But his re-election came amid much grumbling from party stalwarts.
Poland's president, Alexander Kwasniewski, has reportedly called on Leszek Miller, the prime minister, to resign if he fails to get his budget cuts through parliament. The two men are long-time rivals for control of the political left.
You may kiss the groom
The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples in the state have a right to marry. The judges asked the state assembly to produce legislation within six months allowing gays to wed.
Kathleen Blanco narrowly beat Bobby Jindal to become the next governor of Louisiana, recapturing the seat for the Democrats. Mrs Blanco becomes the first ever female governor in America's "Deep South".
Arnold Schwarzenegger, was inaugurated as California's 38th governor, and immediately proposed a $15 billion bond to help clear the state's budget deficit. His finance director forecast a $62 billion shortfall by 2006-07 unless spending is cut.
A Yemeni cleric and his assistant were flown to the United States from Germany to face charges that they channelled money from a mosque in Brooklyn to al-Qaeda. Germany allowed the extradition after receiving assurances the pair would be tried in a civilian court and not face a capital sentence if found guilty.
John Allen Muhammad was found guilty in the Washington sniper trial and faces a possible death sentence. The trial of his alleged accomplice, Lee Boyd Malvo, continues.
A warrant was issued for the arrest of Michael Jackson, a former pop star, on multiple charges of child-sex abuse.
Forty years after the assassination of President John Kennedy, a poll revealed that 70% of Americans still believe that the killing was part of a wider conspiracy and not the actions of a lone gunman.
A quick turnabout?
In a sharp change of policy, America issued a new plan for Iraq that would speed the handover of power to Iraqis, who would have a provisional government, with more power than the current Governing Council, by the middle of next year. But elections of a parliament under a still-to-be-drafted constitution would not take place until 2005. 
Trade unionists in Zimbabwe called a strike to protest against the arrest of 360 people they said were rounded up for demonstrating against high taxes and economic mismanagement. The government admitted that inflation was 525%. 
The South African government approved a plan to give free anti-AIDS drugs to those who need them. 
The UN appealed for $3 billion to tackle 21 forgotten crises, most of them in Africa. It said the money could help save 45m lives. 
Still dangerous
A French UN worker was shot dead in her car in the eastern town of Ghazni in Afghanistan. The UN subsequently said it was withdrawing workers from southern and eastern Afghanistan. 
After a fresh outbreak of religious violence, security was tightened in Sulawesi, Indonesia's central province. A Christian minister and his driver were found dead in a river near Poso. The next day, a Christian man was beaten to death by a mob. 
China gave warning that Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, "risks war" if he launches any independence bid. The mainland has long threatened action against Taiwan, which it sees as a renegade province. 
Going early
Jean Chretien, Canada's prime minister, agreed to bring forward his planned retirement. He will now hand over power to Paul Martin, the Liberal Party's newly elected leader, on December 12th. 
In Mexico, President Vicente Fox's tax-reform plans ran into trouble. The Institutional Revolutionary Party, the largest in the Congress, rejected a plan to cut the VAT rate but start levying the tax on food and medicine.
Mexico's government fired its ambassador to the UN, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, after he had complained in a speech that the United States regarded Mexico as a "backyard" and that America would never consider it to be an ally on a par with Europe.

text:
The new prime minister wants a new relationship with the United States--and with Canada's own provinces
PAUL MARTIN'S long wait, impatiently endured, to become Canada's next prime minister is almost over. On November 14th he was crowned as leader of the governing Liberal Party, with the vote of 94% of the delegates at a convention. Four days later Jean Chretien, the present prime minister, abandoned his long effort to thwart his former finance minister and unreconciled rival. He agreed to hand over on December 12th, rather than hang on into the new year as he had planned. 
After more than a year of enforced circumspection, Mr Martin is at last able to say how he wants to change Canada. He will put more effort than Mr Chretien into good relations with George Bush's administration in the United States, and with provincial premiers at home. 
Mr Martin, a 65-year-old former businessman, is hardly a new face. But he will do his best to convince voters, in an election expected by next summer, that he represents a fresh start. He will spend the next three weeks forming a cabinet, which is likely to include only a minority of Mr Chretien's ministers. To provide momentum for the election, he may postpone by a fortnight or more the recall of Parliament (prorogued by Mr Chretien last week until January 12th), and thus of the Speech from the Throne containing his legislative plans. 
Mr Chretien, a man of working-class origins who plays politics by his instincts, curbed government deficits, took a tough line on separatism in French-speaking Quebec, opposed the war in Iraq, got on badly with George Bush, and embraced such measures as decriminalising drugs and legalising homosexual marriage. 
Now Mr Martin is expected to lean back to the right. During the leadership campaign, he defined himself partly by his silences on issues such as gay marriage, the Kyoto protocol on climate change (ratified by Mr Chretien), and cultural nationalism. But he has been explicit about the importance of improving Canada's rather uneasy relations with the United States. 
A 16-page policy paper released after the convention sets as a priority "attending to the security of our shared geography and common border". This will involve developing a domestic security framework to co-ordinate the armed forces, police, intelligence and other agencies to deal with threats of terrorism--in effect a counterpart to America's Department of Homeland Security. Mr Martin plans a special cabinet committee to oversee Canadian-American relations, which he will chair.
A 50-strong group of Canadian and American military commanders is already making plans to co-operate against possible terrorist threats ranging from nuclear bombs on container ships to attacks on power grids. These plans may include an integrated maritime command. But Mr Martin has ruled out a joint immigration policy for border security. 
The other thing he wants to change is federal-provincial relations, always a battleground in Canada. Mr Chretien kept a wary distance from the provincial premiers. Mr Martin's first act as party leader was to fly to Saskatchewan to meet them all. They backed a planned national health council. The election this year of Liberal governments in Quebec and Ontario helps co-operation. So does the promise by Mr Chretien of dollops of new money for health care, a headache for the provinces. Mr Martin's soft-pedalling over implementation of the Kyoto protocol goes down well with Ralph Klein, the abrasive Conservative premier of oil-rich Alberta. 
Mr Martin has also hinted at ways in which he may try to please his party's left. Whereas Mr Chretien often bullied his parliamentary caucus, the new leader promises more debate, and more free votes, to address a "democratic deficit" in Parliament. He invited Bono, a rock singer, to speak to the Liberal convention, and seems to favour his pleas for further debt relief and increased aid for Africa. 
The big test will be how Mr Martin handles competing demands on the public finances. As finance minister, he cut taxes and the federal debt. He is pledged to do more of both. But he would find it hard to reverse increased health spending, even if he wanted to. He also wants to help Canada's cities, whose roads and services are deteriorating, by turning over to them a generous slice of petrol-tax revenue.

text:
Politics
Saddam Hussein, Iraq's fugitive ex-dictator, was found in a pit under a hut belonging to his former cook. Though armed, he was captured by American troops without a shot being fired. A debate began as to how and where to try him for crimes against humanity. 
After talks with James Baker, a former American secretary of state, France, Germany and Britain said they would offer substantial debt relief to Iraq. 
A spokesman for South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, said Mr Mbeki would fly to Zimbabwe for talks with President Robert Mugabe to resolve that country's political and economic crisis. Inflation in Zimbabwe officially hit 620%, though economists said the true rate was much worse.
In Liberia, a UN scheme to disarm gunmen by paying them for their weapons was forced to halt, at least temporarily, when too many showed up and demanded cash for their weapons. Reports from neighbouring Sierra Leone suggested that guns were being smuggled into Liberia to take advantage of the scheme. 
Fragile constitution
A European summit broke down with no agreement on a European Union
constitution. The biggest stumbling-block was a dispute over countries' voting weights, with Poland and Spain on one side, and France and Germany on the other.
Gerhard Schroder, the German chancellor, secured agreement to his Agenda 2010 package of economic reforms. But he had to water them down to win opposition support. The outlook for the German economy next year remains gloomy.
The Italian president, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, rejected a media bill sent to him by parliament on the ground that it entrenched the media interests of his prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi. Mr Berlusconi said he would issue an emergency decree to achieve the same results.
As expected, President Jacques Chirac of France announced plans for a ban on the Muslim headscarf and other "ostensible" religious signs in schools. But he rejected proposals for schools to observe a pair of Jewish and Muslim holidays.
Elections in northern Cyprus ended in a dead heat for the two groups in favour of and opposed to UN plans for reunification. But those hoping for a peaceful settlement took heart when the long-serving Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, said he might step aside for a new government representative if and when the UN negotiations resume.
Heidar Aliev, Azerbaijan's long-serving former president, died after a long illness. His son Ilham, who took over this year, has so far kept his promise to change none of his father's disastrous policies.
Who's fuelling whom?
George Bush said that Halliburton, an energy company once headed by Dick Cheney, should repay the government if its subcontractor is found to have overcharged by $61m for petrol during the Iraq war. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court said it would hear arguments next year about the vice-president's refusal to hand over papers related to his energy task-force in 2001.
California's legislature finally approved Arnold Schwarzenegger's fiscal rescue plan. The governor's scheme to cut spending and raise borrowing will now go to the electorate as a ballot initiative in March.
Connecticut's Republican governor, John Rowland, faced pressure to resign after admitting that he had broken state ethics laws by allowing business associates to pay for work at his holiday home. Meanwhile, George Ryan, a former governor of Illinois, was indicted on 22 corruption charges.
John Breaux said he would not run for re-election in Louisiana next year, becoming the fifth Democratic senator from the South to announce his retirement before the poll.
A federal judge reinstated a National Park Service edict, suspended by the Interior Department in 2001, that phases out the use of snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton parks. The state of Wyoming said that snowmobilers should have full access to the parks for the rest of the winter season. 
Martin moves in
Paul Martin, a Liberal former finance minister, became Canada's prime minister. His 38-member ministerial team includes only 16 carry-overs from his Liberal predecessor, Jean Chretien. 
Opponents of Haiti's president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, staged a general strike and demonstrations aimed at forcing his resignation.
In Brazil, the Workers' Party of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva expelled four prominent legislators from its left-wing who had voted against a pension-reform bill. 
Peru's unpopular president, Alejandro Toledo, sacked his popular prime minister, Beatriz Merino, a technocrat. He replaced her with Carlos Ferrero, a leading figure in his party.
Bearded chins wag
A loya jirga, or grand council, opened in Afghanistan. Expected to last a couple of weeks or so, it aims to approve a new constitution, providing for presidential elections next year and parliamentary ones in 2005. But at the same time, the UN said that it may have to leave because of security concerns.
Pervez Musharraf, president of Pakistan, survived an assassination attempt, the third in less than two years.
Human Rights Watch, a New York-based lobbying group, accused Indonesia's government of committing widespread abuses in the mutinous province of Aceh.
South Korea's government said that it would send 3,000 troops, including combat units, to Iraq.
China vowed to "crush" attempts by Taiwan to seek independence, branding the island's president, Chen Shui-bian, as selfish and immoral.

text:
The new prime minister has quickly put his stamp on government. A real opposition may take longer to emerge
POLITICS in Canada can often seem as staid and orderly as Ottawa, the country's pleasant but hardly cosmopolitan capital. Yet in the space of a few winter days in mid-December, Canada gained a new government and a new opposition. Paul Martin, the new prime minister, is a Liberal, like Jean Chretien, his long-serving predecessor. But with a sweeping reshaping of government, Mr Martin has done his best to disguise continuity as change--and to signal his desire for warmer relations with the United States. 
Days earlier, Canada's two right-of-centre parties, the Alliance and the Progressive Conservatives, merged into a single Conservative Party. If this is to offer an effective challenge to Mr Martin, and not end up as less than the sum of its parts, it will have to reassure supporters of both former parties that change will not come at the expense of continuity. 
Of Mr Martin's 38-strong ministerial team, only 16 were carry-overs from Mr Chretien's cabinet. Several of these may be stopgaps until the next election, when several old friends of the new prime minister may enter parliament. 
Mr Martin had both personal and policy reasons for wasting no time in placing his own stamp on the Liberal government. After nine years as Mr Chretien's finance minister, he quarrelled with his former boss last year over his leadership ambitions. That quarrel split the Liberal parliamentary caucus. The new cabinet has no place for ministers who remained staunchly loyal to Mr Chretien, or who supported other leadership candidates. 
The new line-up is also a balancing act which, Mr Martin confessed, cost him sleepless nights. It aims to signal some new policy priorities. One is to heal relations with the United States, which were damaged by Canada's abstention from the Iraqi war. Another is to reach out to two important provinces, Alberta and Quebec, whose leaders had been alienated by Mr Chretien's abrasive disregard. Mr Martin imposed an immediate freeze on most capital spending, to safeguard promised extra transfers to the provinces for health care; his minister of health and intergovernmental affairs, Pierre Pettigrew, will be emollient with the provinces.
The top appointment serves both purposes. Anne McLellan, a former law professor in Alberta, will be not only deputy prime minister but also hold the new job of minister of public safety. She will become Canada's link with Tom Ridge, the United States' secretary of homeland security. She will deal with security and policing, as well as national emergencies ranging from forest fires to epidemics. Unlike Mr Ridge, she will not handle immigration. But she will oversee a new border agency, whose task is to ensure the seamless passage of people and goods across the border. That is vital, since the United States takes 85% of Canada's exports.
Mr Martin will chair a new cabinet committee on relations with the United States. He has recruited as his parliamentary secretary Scott Brison, a Progressive Conservative MP opposed to his party's merger, who wants closer ties with the United States. David Pratt, the new defence minister, is an advocate of closer military co-operation, and of Canadian participation in missile-defence research.
Mr Chretien got on famously badly with George Bush. Here, too, Mr Martin will strive for balance. His policy instinct is for good relations with Washington. But he is mindful that most Canadians are critical of Mr Bush's foreign policy, and are wary of subservience to their powerful neighbour. 
Mr Martin was quick to congratulate the American president on the capture of Saddam Hussein. This helped smooth a telephone conversation between the two men on December 15th, steering it away from the touchy subject of Canada's apparent exclusion from the list of 63 allies allowed to bid on primary reconstruction contracts. This exclusion was "difficult to fathom", according to Mr Martin. 
The prime minister will also chair another new cabinet committee, on "Canada and the world". He has launched a review of foreign policy. The new justice minister, Irwin Cotler, is a human-rights lawyer from Quebec. All this suggests that Mr Martin may seek a more active international role than Mr Chretien, whose eyes were fixed firmly on local politics.
A winning team? Probably. Parliament will return in mid-February, and everyone expects a quick budget and then an election called for April. The new Conservative Party leader will not be chosen until March. According to a poll by Ipsos-Reid, the Liberals have the support of 48% of voters, and the merged Conservative Party just 21%. It has suffered several defections, especially among the Progressive Conservatives in eastern Canada. They fear that Stephen Harper, the skilful leader of the Alberta-based Alliance, will take over the merger. In the last election, in 2000, the Alliance won 25.5% of the vote, double that of the Progressive Conservatives. 
The new party's first job will be to consolidate, convincing doubters that the Alliance's muscular social conservatism can be melded with the centrist "red Toryism" of the Progressive Conservatives. Only then will the new party have a realistic chance of frightening the Liberals. So Mr Martin seems assured of at least one full term to show that he really is different from Mr Chretien.

text:
Canada's picturesque but neglected cities are revolting 
QUEBEC CITY on its rocky bluff; Toronto by its lake; Ottawa and Winnipeg at the confluence of major rivers; most majestic of all, Vancouver stretched between mountain and ocean: Canada's cities are beautifully situated. But their public services are much less impressive. During his leadership campaign last year, Paul Martin, the new prime minister, pledged to find massive funds for urban renewal, and to improve the lot of Canada's increasingly restive urban-dwellers. Yet Mr Martin himself deserves a share of the blame for the cities' problems. 
As finance minister for nearly nine years, Mr Martin chopped billions from federal transfers to the provinces to help eliminate budget deficits. The provinces, in turn, offloaded responsibility for a range of social services to local municipalities, and cut their own cash transfers. Figures from the OECD show that, in 1995, federal and provincial funds made up 21.4% of municipal revenues; by 1999 they provided only 16.5%. To compensate, cities and towns raised property taxes sharply. Among federal states that the OECD monitors, the upper levels of government in Canada give least to their cities. 
Meanwhile, in population terms, Canadian cities have boomed. A century ago, 80% of the population was rural; today 80% of the country's 31m people live in towns and cities, and half are concentrated in five city-regions. When Canada was born in 1867 and its first constitution written, Toronto comprised some 50,000 citizens; today the Greater Toronto Area is home to 4.6m people, and may be the most cosmopolitan metropolis on the planet. Immigrants, now mostly from Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean, almost all find their way to the bigger cities. But urban roads, sewers, policing, housing and health care have suffered as the demands placed on them have grown. 
Canada's constitution has not changed to reflect this urban growth: the cities are still creatures of the provinces. And the premiers of the ten provinces and three territories have not collectively accepted Mr Martin's view that Ottawa should offer direct funding to the cities. Quebec's government argues that it should receive the funds and decide how they are spent.
Urban legends
The cities, however, are revolting. The amalgamation of a dozen or so municipalities into mega-cities--undertaken by the provinces to cut their own costs--has helped to produce a new crop of mayors with big ideas and new influence. The election, in November, of David Miller as Toronto's reforming mayor gave extra strength to a coalition of uppity civic leaders. Glen Murray, mayor of Winnipeg, has called for a new deal to allow "tax shifting", along Scandinavian lines. He wants to cut property taxes in his city--which, unusually, has a stagnant population--arguing that homeowners and businesses pay too much for their services, and to make up the difference with user fees. For instance, he wants to introduce a liquor tax to bolster the police force, and a hotel tax to help build convention space and develop tourism. Some other mayors disagree. Dave Bronconnier of Calgary is happy to increase property taxes in his booming city and pour the cash into roads. 
What will Mr Martin do? More, he implies, than his predecessor, Jean Chretien, whose planned investment in urban infrastructure lagged well behind independent estimates of what is required to put the cities right. The new prime minister has hinted that he would allocate half the revenues from a federal fuel tax, worth C$2.5 billion ($1.9 billion) a year, directly to the cities. He has appointed John Godfrey, a well-regarded Ontario MP, as his urban adviser, and persuaded Mike Harcourt, a former premier of British Columbia and once mayor of Vancouver, to chair a high-powered advisory committee on urban issues. Both men will feed ideas to a special cabinet committee on cities, which Mr Martin intends to chair. Canada's mayors expect him to put his money where his mouth was during his campaign.
Caption: But the view is wonderful

text:
Paul Martin gives and withholds
RATHER than the announcement of a legislative programme, it seemed like a manifesto for an early election. That was the opposition's view of the Throne Speech opening a new session of Canada's parliament on February 2nd. And the Liberal Party of Paul Martin, the new prime minister, did not deny it.
But in setting out the ground on which he will fight the election (likely to come once the snow has melted in May), Mr Martin faced a challenge. In nine years as finance minister under Jean Chretien, whom he succeeded in December, Mr Martin turned large budget deficits into surpluses partly by slashing transfers to the provinces, which run (most of) health and education. As prime minister, he seems to want to put behind him the image of a budget-cutting millionaire ship-owner on his party's right wing. 
So the speech was a lunge for the Liberals' habitual home in the broad centre ground, whence they have dominated Canadian politics for most of the past century. It included promises to improve health care, meet the standards set by the Kyoto protocol on the environment and tackle the decay of economically vibrant but cash-strapped cities. To give the appearance of change rather than continuity, the speech focused on issues and programmes that were overlooked or faltering under Mr Chretien. 
Mr Martin promises an overhaul of student loans, adding first-year college grants for poorer families; that may do more to attract younger voters than his predecessor's proposal to decriminalise marijuana (now dropped). He will set up a national public-health agency to co-ordinate efforts to combat global diseases such as SARS. And as promised in his leadership campaign, he offered cash to help cities build cheap housing and improve transport: C$580m ($440m) a year in rebates from the goods and services tax, with more later (perhaps from the federal petrol tax). text:
Politics
Big suicide-bombs on consecutive days killed around 100 Iraqis. The first, in Iskandariyah, a town 25 miles (40km) south of Baghdad, killed at least 53 people queuing for work at a police station, while the second, in Baghdad, killed some 47 people applying to join the new army. There was speculation that the bombers may have been outsiders, perhaps connected to al-Qaeda.
Meanwhile a team led by the UN secretary-general's special envoy to Iraq, Lakhdar Brahimi, was assessing what kind of elections might be held in time to produce a provisional government by July 1st, when the Americans want to hand over power to Iraqis.
America restored its diplomatic presence in Libya for the first time in over two decades. Britain's foreign secretary, Jack Straw, after a meeting in London with Libya's foreign minister, Mohammed Abderrahman Chalgam, signalled that Tony Blair and Muammar Qaddafi might soon meet as well.
Israeli troops killed at least 15 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip in raids said by the Israelis to be aimed at hitting militants who have been attacking Jewish settlements. 
After threatening to boycott the general election due on February 20th, the main reformist party in Iran said that it would compete after all, even though one-third of all candidates, including many reformists, have been disqualified from standing by the conservative Guardian Council.
Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, became the first royal Briton to visit Iran since the fall of the shah in the revolution of 1979.
Sudan's government said it had crushed the rebel forces fighting against it in the western region of Darfur, from which 800,000 people have fled in recent months. Rebels denied the claim. 
Kerry's winning streak
John Kerry won five more Democratic primary elections including two southern states, Tennessee and Virginia. Wesley Clark, a former NATO commander who made a late entry into the field, withdrew from the race. John Edwards and Howard Dean are hanging on.
George Bush said on TV that he "expected to find weapons" when he ordered the invasion of Iraq, a decision based on the "best intelligence possible". Later, the White House released 13 pages of military records to refute claims that Mr Bush had shirked his duty as a member of the National Guard during the Vietnam war.
Secular argument
France's National Assembly overwhelmingly approved a ban on the wearing of Muslim headscarves and other supposedly ostentatious religious symbols. The ban, supported by government and opposition parties, will become law later this year.
Serbia's quarrelsome political parties appeared to abandon efforts to form a coalition government. Another election is likely; hardline nationalists may do better than they did last December. The Serbs also denied claims by Carla Del Ponte, the Yugoslav war-crimes prosecutor, that Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader wanted in The Hague, was hiding in Belgrade.
The European Commission presented its proposals for the European Union budget over the seven year period from 2006. Against the wishes of the biggest contributors, which wanted to freeze spending, the commission suggested an increase of some 30%, mostly to pay for the new central European countries joining in May.
Germany's governing Social Democrats remained glum despite the unexpected resignation as party chairman of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder. Although the next federal elections are not due until 2006, the party faces the prospect of a string of defeats in local elections this year and next.
A Russian presidential candidate who had gone missing, Ivan Rybkin, turned up unexpectedly in Kiev. He claimed that he had gone for a break, switched off his mobile phone and seen neither television nor newspapers--all without telling either his campaign manager or even his wife. 
Gang warfare
Around 40 people were killed as violence spread in Haiti. Rebel gangs seized control of half a dozen towns, but police and gangs loyal to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide beat them back from three others. An American official said that Mr Aristide might have to go. 
Colombia's president, lvaro Uribe, called for Europe to back his democratic security policy in a speech at the European Parliament. Some MEPs staged a demonstration, calling for an aid cut-off. 
Two judges in America ordered restrictions on the sale of ten properties belonging to Argentina's government in actions brought by its creditors. Facing pressure from the IMF, the government appointed three investment banks to help manage its debt restructuring.
In Venezuela, the government of Hugo Chvez devalued the bolvar, by 16.7%, to 1,920 to the dollar; the free market rate is more than 3,000 to the dollar. The devaluation will boost the local currency value of the government's oil income. 
Canada's auditor-general criticised the government of Jean Chretien, the former prime minister, for the "blatant misuse" of public money over a C$250m ($190m) publicity campaign to promote federalism in Quebec between 1997 and 2003.
Going hungry
The UN World Food Programme said it faces a shortage of food for its distribution programme in North Korea because of a lack of funds. 
Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, dissolved parliament, called for early elections on April 2nd and later sacked 39 government ministers. The move is the latest ploy in a power struggle with the prime minister, Ranil Wickremesinghe.
Indonesia's Supreme Court overturned a corruption conviction against Akbar Tandjung, the parliamentary speaker and Golkar presidential candidate. In Malaysia, where Abdullah Badawi, the prime minister, has vowed to be tough on corruption, the land minister and a former steel magnate were charged with graft and fraud.
George Bush called for tougher curbs on nuclear proliferation after the discovery that Pakistan's top nuclear scientist had leaked nuclear technology to Iran, Libya and North Korea. Mr Bush suggested a ban on supplying nuclear-fuel technology to any country that could not already make the stuff, even if they had signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

text:
Sleaze changes the electoral calculations
ONE of Paul Martin's first moves on taking over as prime minister in December was to kill off a scandal-plagued publicity drive launched by his predecessor, Jean Chretien, to bolster the cause of Canadian unity in French-speaking Quebec. The message Mr Martin hoped to send was that even though the Liberals have been in power for more than a decade, under his leadership they are making a fresh start.
No such luck. An excoriating report by the independent auditor-general released this month says the publicity programme was abused to funnel C$100m ($75m) of public money to Liberal cronies. Canadians got little in return. Their anger over the affair has wounded Mr Martin's fledgling government. Only last month the prime minister was seen as certain to call a spring election with the expectation of romping to an easy victory. Now, the polls suggest the Liberals would be lucky to hang on as a minority government (see chart). A spring election suddenly looks less likely.
The roots of the scandal go back to a 1995 referendum in Quebec, in which the province came within a whisker of seceding. To prevent a repeat, Mr Chretien launched the C$250m campaign to promote federalism at sporting and cultural events. This turned into a slush fund: much of the money went to friendly advertising firms and back to government agencies--minus a hefty commission. The auditor found faked invoices, double-billing, and extravagant payments without tenders or contracts. One firm was paid C$550,000 for a report no one has ever seen. 
Most of this was already known--journalists began exposing the story two years ago. But the auditor's report added details and underlined the scale of the scam. It was an "outrageous" and "appalling" scheme "designed to put money" into the Liberal-linked advertising firms, she said.
Nothing to do with me, has in effect been Mr Martin's largely sure-footed response. He ordered an independent inquiry and promised to testify before it. He asked a special counsel to find out exactly where the missing millions went (to pay the Liberals' campaign debts, say some). He fired Canada's ambassador to Denmark, Alfonso Gagliano, who as Mr Chretien's public-works minister was closest to the scandal.
In daily press conferences and on talkshows, Mr Martin repeated that although he was finance minister when most of the cheques were written, his job involved economic policy, not the minutiae of spending. True enough--but many Canadians are disinclined to accept this. 
Already one Liberal backbencher has quit the party. Ironically, Canadian unity, the ostensible object of the original exercise, could also be damaged. English Canada sees the scandal as an example of Quebec's traditionally grubby politics. In the province, the secessionist Bloc Quebecois leads the opinion polls after being written off for dead two months ago.

text:
A new leader for a revamped force
LAST autumn, as Paul Martin prepared to replace Jean Chretien as Canada's prime minister, the divided right-wing parties were gloomily contemplating a second decade in opposition. So much has the political climate changed that the hurried merger of the Progressive Conservatives (PC) and the Canadian Alliance into a single Conservative Party has created a credible alternative to the Liberals.
The turnaround is partly due to the bursting of a sleaze scandal from the Chretien era, concerning a publicity campaign against separatism in Quebec which degenerated into a slush fund. That has damaged the Liberals. But it is also because the Conservatives' tricky merger went surprisingly well, thanks mainly to the negotiating skill of Stephen Harper, the Alliance leader. Despite his party's ties to social and fiscal conservatism, he persuaded Peter Mackay, the more centrist PC leader, that merger offered each their only hope of power. Mr Harper now stands a good chance of defeating two rivals to become leader of the merged party in a grassroots vote on March 20th. 
Though he grew up in Ontario, Mr Harper's base is in Alberta and the west. But he claims his role in the merger shows that he is a bridge-builder; he hints that he would offer the deputy-leader's job to Mr Mackay, who is from Nova Scotia. An economist who speaks fluent French, Mr Harper has tempered his past support for small government and a reduction in official bi-lingualism. Though 20 years younger than Mr Martin, he already has much parliamentary experience.
All of that gives him the edge over Tony Clement, who as Ontario's health minister dealt capably with last year's outbreak of the SARS respiratory disease in Toronto. The third candidate, Belinda Stronach, is an elegant political oddity. The chief executive of a car-parts firm, she makes a virtue of being a campaign novice. Her photogenic features have embellished the front pages for weeks. She stands slightly to the left of the other two on social policy, while promising to spend heavily on the armed forces. She has spent some of her fortune on signing up new party members in Quebec, a province that controls a quarter of the convention votes.
Whoever wins, the Conservatives will focus on ethical government and an assault on Liberal sleaze. All three leadership contenders also agree on the need for an elected Senate and some private health provision, and that the emotive subject of legalising same-sex marriages should be put to a parliamentary vote.
This spirit of unity means that the new party should come out of the convention having lost only a few "Red Tory" MPs such as Joe Clark, a former prime minister, while having gained 110,000 new members--and public support. The latest poll shows the Conservatives at 26%; the Liberals, at 38%, have slid ten points from their January peak.
That is worrying for Mr Martin. He had hoped to call an early election in May, partly to catch the newly-merged Conservatives before their policies were settled. Those plans have gone awry. On current polls, the Liberals would be reduced to a minority government. Never quick to take decisions, Mr Martin has called a by-election in Ottawa Centre, a difficult seat, for the distant date of November 29th. That suggests he might also postpone a general election until the autumn, giving time for the polls to change. Mr Harper, if it is he, has an opportunity.
Caption: The acceptable face of conservatism

text:
Can western Canada and Ottawa learn to love each other?
WHEN British Columbia joined the new Dominion of Canada in 1871, it was promised a transcontinental rail link to the Atlantic by 1883. The railway was built late, and only after the territory threatened to secede. Ever since, western Canada has tended to regard itself as a resource-rich colony, exploited by the more developed and populous east: over-taxed, and neglected by the federal parliament and its spending programmes. Notwithstanding the contempt with which westerners have historically viewed his Liberal Party, Paul Martin, prime minister since December, has vowed to address this rancour across the Rockies. Unfortunately for him, a scandal has endorsed the worst western fears about eastern politicians.
Easterners like Mr Martin often dismiss western grievances as the grumbling of fat-cat British Columbians and Albertans, or of glum Saskatchewan and Manitoba farmers. But the evidence for what sociologists call "western alienation" is compelling. The Canada West Foundation (CWF), a think-tank, last year reported a "deep-seated belief" among westerners that "the government of Canada doesn't listen [to them], doesn't understand, and doesn't care." Last month a CWF poll found that 64.7% of westerners felt their province's interests were poorly or very poorly represented at the federal level.
Unusually for a Canadian prime minister, Mr Martin acknowledges that the syndrome exists. He gave the two top jobs in his cabinet to westerners, and says he wants to co-operate more closely with provincial premiers. Responding to noisy opinion in Alberta, he has agreed to consider replacing the archaic, appointed Canadian Senate with an elected body that might better represent regional interests. Putting his money where his mouth was, he last week announced a generous C$995m ($750m) federal bail-out for (mainly western) cattle producers hit by last year's mad-cow scare.
Mr Martin claims that the cash is motivated by need, not by politics. Perhaps. Canadian elections tend to be decided in populous Ontario and Quebec, which together command most of the parliamentary seats. Hence all the attention governments lavish on them. But the Canadian right is now re-united under the Conservative Party--whose new leader, Stephen Harper, is an adopted westerner--and seems likely to make big gains in Ontario in the election expected in June. So, pundits and psephologists argue, the Liberals now need to win in the west. 
That might be feasible, were it not for a scandal reminiscent of sleazy episodes under previous Liberal regimes. In February, a report disclosed how a government publicity drive, concocted under Jean Chretien, was abused to funnel C$100m to advertising firms linked to the Liberals. Mr Martin has been scrambling to distance his administration from its predecessor--firing tainted officials and setting up an inquiry--and to deny any involvement while he was minister of finance. But once again, as Phil Resnick of the University of British Columbia puts it, "people out here are asking, 'Why should I trust those bastards?'"
Caption: The 1883 from the Atlantic will be delayed

But once again , as Phil Resnick of the University of British Columbia puts it , " people out here are asking , ' Why should I trust those bastards ? ' "

text:
Politics
George Bush delivered the first of six speeches intended to reassure voters that he has a clear plan for handing sovereignty back to the Iraqis at the end of June. At the same time, America and Britain circulated a draft UN Security Council resolution describing the powers of an interim Iraq government, but France and Russia said it was too vague and gave America too much control. Mr Bush said that the Abu Ghraib jail, where the abuse of Iraqi prisoners took place, would be demolished.
Muqtada al-Sadr, the anti-American cleric whose militia had occupied Iraq's holy city of Najaf, was reported to be preparing to withdraw his fighters.
At its annual summit, the 22-member Arab League--amid scepticism from Arab intellectuals--said its members would embrace political reform and promote women's rights.
In local elections, Lebanon's militant Islamist Shia party, Hizbullah, won more seats than any other.
Sudan's government signed a peace deal with rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army, bringing hopes of an end to a civil war that has lasted for decades. But bloodshed continues in a separate conflict in the western region of Darfur.
Namibia's president, Sam Nujoma, told a rally that some white people are "snakes" who want to recolonise the country. With an election looming, Mr Nujoma is overseeing aggressive land redistribution. He also sacked his foreign minister, Hidipo Hamutenya, who had been tipped to succeed him. 
Bingu wa Mutharika, a 70-year-old economist and protege of ex-President Bakili Muluzi, was sworn in as Malawi's new head of state after an election most observers deemed unfair. Brief riots ensued. 
Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's president, called Nobel peace-prize winner Desmond Tutu an "evil and embittered little bishop", after Bishop Tutu criticised him. He also denied that his country was short of food or that his police tortured dissidents. 
India's new faces
India's new Congress-led coalition government took office. The nomination of a reformer, Palaniappan Chidambaram, as finance minister reassured markets, but the new line-up was criticised for lacking new faces. This week too, 33 people died in an attack on a bus in the disputed region of Kashmir.
Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, returned from North Korea with five children of surviving Japanese citizens abducted 25 years ago. He was criticised for agreeing to resume humanitarian aid without obtaining a convincing explanation of the fate of others who are thought to be dead.
Senior military officers from North and South Korea held talks aimed at reducing tension along the border. North Korea agreed to consider proposals to improve military communication. Further talks are expected next month.
Over four years after its exclusion, after a military coup in 1999, Pakistan was readmitted to the (formerly British) Commonwealth.
A chance for reform
As expected, Horst Kohler won election as the next president of Germany. The former boss of the IMF may help the cause of economic reform.
The UN high representative in the troubled Serbian province of Kosovo, Harri Holkeri, resigned. The former Finnish prime minister was in poor health, but he also complained that he had not had enough western backing. Two months ago violence erupted between Kosovo's Albanians and Serbs, setting back hopes for a peaceful future there.
In his annual state address to parliament, President Vladimir Putin promised once again to double Russia's GDP by 2010. Earlier, the Russians reached agreement with the EU over the terms for their accession to the WTO; in exchange, Mr Putin made renewed (but still vague) promises to ratify the Kyoto protocol on climate change.
A section of a new terminal building at Paris's Charles de Gaulle airport collapsed, killing four people. The cause is not yet known, but it is possible that the entire building will have to be pulled down.
America on alert
John Ashcroft, America's top law official, said that "credible intelligence from multiple sources" indicated that al-Qaeda is planning a big attack in America during the summer. But Tom Ridge, the homeland security secretary, said that there were no plans to raise the national level of alert from "elevated".
The Supreme Court ruled that David Nelson, a convicted killer on death row in Alabama, could appeal against the method of his execution. He argues that death by lethal injection is a "cruel and unusual punishment", given the damage to his veins from years of drug abuse.
The FBI issued a rare public apology to Brandon Mayfield and said it would review its guidelines for analysing fingerprints. A federal judge dismissed the case against Mr Mayfield, a lawyer from Oregon held in detention for an alleged connection to the Madrid bombings last March.
Boston's Catholic church announced that it was closing 65 of its 357 parishes. Archbishop Sean O'Malley said the decision was based on falling attendance. Last autumn, the archdiocese reached an $85m out-of-court settlement with victims who alleged sexual abuse by the clergy.
After the storm
Some 2,000 people were reported killed and thousands more made homeless on the island of Hispaniola after torrential rains triggered floods and landslides in a border area between the Dominican Republic and Haiti. 
Paul Martin, Canada's prime minister, called a general election for June 28th. Having succeeded Jean Chretien last December, Mr Martin is seeking a mandate of his own. But polls suggest his Liberal Party may be reduced to a minority government.
Bolivia's president, Carlos Mesa, said that a referendum on his country's oil and gas industries would be held on July 18th. The questions include proposals to expand the role of the state-owned oil company and increase taxes on multinationals.

text:
If he is to get it, it should be based on a serious debate
WHEN Paul Martin succeeded Jean Chretien last December as leader of Canada's Liberals, and thus as prime minister, he let it be known that he would seek an election within weeks. Although he had served as Mr Chretien's finance minister for a decade, the two men were bitter rivals and Mr Martin yearned for a mandate of his own. Only three years of a possible five-year term for the Liberals had elapsed, but an election seemed to make sense--at least to Mr Martin. His party was well ahead in the opinion polls, and the opposition was divided. Until a slowdown last year--partly induced by an outbreak of the SARS respiratory disease--Canadians had basked for several years in steady growth and balanced budgets.
Last weekend, Mr Martin at last called the election--for June 28th, two months later than planned. Why the delay? Over the past few months, sudden squalls have darkened the horizon for the Liberals. The opinion polls suggest that the ruling party may end up swapping a comfortable majority for a precarious minority government. Far from the confident gambit imagined in December, the election now looks like a panicky recognition that further delay risks heavier defeat. 
The Liberals have been in office since 1993. An end to their automatic hegemony is good for Canada. Two things have caused it. First, the country now has the makings of a national opposition, after the recent merger of the western-based Canadian Alliance with the Progressive Conservatives. The Liberals can no longer win by default. Second, they have been hurt by a corruption scandal involving a publicity campaign promoting federalism in Quebec which was used to funnel C$100m ($73m) to their cronies. It happened on Mr Chretien's watch, and Mr Martin was quick to call for an independent inquiry. But the affair has led some Canadians to conclude that the Liberals have been in power too long. Mr Chretien's decision to cling to office for 18 months after announcing his retirement smacked of putting personal ambitions above the country's needs. So, perhaps, does Mr Martin's thirst for his own mandate: he is prime minister, not president.
More competition among the parties means that the campaign ought to produce a debate over the policy choices Canada faces. It needs to maintain the trust of the United States by careful management of its disagreements with its powerful neighbour. The public health-care system, in many ways admirable, demands ever more cash. So does defence, neglected in recent years. The finances of many provinces are unravelling. But Canadian taxes are already higher than those in the United States--and Canadian incomes buy some 15% less than those of their southern neighbours.
How to keep health care healthy
Yet will voters actually hear serious discussion of these issues? The newly-merged Conservatives would like to see more private investment in the delivery of publicly-financed health care. So would the health minister, Pierre Pettigrew. But any sort of adult discussion of the reform of health care is considered politically explosive: for many Canadians, Medicare is a touchstone of national identity. So the Conservative leader, Stephen Harper, prefers to campaign against Liberal sleaze. This is in part, perhaps, because his own party is not yet an alloy: the old Red Tories of the Progressive Conservatives are unhappy with the small-government agenda and social conservatism of the former Alliance, from which Mr Harper comes.
For his part, Mr Martin, who as finance minister presented himself as a tax-cutting fiscal conservative, promises an extra C$3 billion a year for health and other social programmes--with no reforms attached. That may be because he knows he may have to form a coalition with the leftish New Democrats. 
Canadians deserve better than this. Their country has done well under the Liberals, forging a distinctive amalgam of a North American economy with a European welfare state, while remaining as open to migrants as the United States. But this balancing act requires a constant weighing of priorities. A competitive election should mean a serious debate, not sloganising and evading the issues. It is not too late to have one.

text:
The debates fail to land a knockout blow
IN THE United States, televised campaign debates tend to be gladiatorial affairs between the two leading candidates. In Canada, they are a confusing brawl. In two debates this week, the first in French and the second in English, the leaders of the four main parties took turns to scrap against each other ahead of the vote on June 28th. That made it hard to point to a clear winner. Is that bad news for Paul Martin, the prime minister, who has moved from narrow favourite to struggling underdog?
The debate in French did settle one thing. Gilles Duceppe, leader of the separatist Bloc Quebecois, almost certainly clinched his hold over most of his province's 75 seats in the 308-seat House of Commons. Since his party wants to leave Canada, not govern it, he had the luxury of having nothing to defend. He attacked the prime minister for scandals over a decade of Liberal rule under Jean Chretien, when Mr Martin was finance minister, and for the supposed neglect of Quebec's industries. With neither the Liberals nor their chief opponents, the Conservatives, likely to win a majority, Mr Duceppe will hold great influence in the weeks ahead.
As the incumbent, Mr Martin was the main target of the other leaders in the debate in English. He suffered no knockout blow. He launched a furious attack on Stephen Harper, the Conservative leader, whose promises of lavish spending on the armed forces and health care as well as large tax cuts would punch a C$50 billion ($36 billion) "black hole" in the public finances, said the prime minister. He also posed unanswered questions as to whether the Conservatives would override the Charter of Rights to block abortion and same-sex marriages. 
It was not clear whether this was enough to halt Mr Harper's momentum. A poll by Ipsos-Reid taken on the eve of the debates gave the Conservatives 32%, the Liberals 31% and 17% for the leftist New Democrats. Mr Martin's hopes of winning more seats than the Conservatives depend on clinging on in Ontario, a traditional Liberal stronghold. Several of the Chretien loyalists, whom Mr Martin dismissed and angered when he became prime minister in December, have rallied to him. Is it too late? Many Canadians seem suddenly to have tired of Liberal rule. But while Mr Martin is down, he is not yet out.

text:
A campaign that turns on the balance between anger and fear of change
SIX months ago, the civil servants and immigrants who make up many of the voters in Ottawa South seemed sure to choose David McGuinty as their next Liberal member of Parliament. The seat has been held for 16 years by John Manley, a former Liberal deputy prime minister. Mr McGuinty's father represented the constituency for many years in Ontario's provincial legislature, and his older brother Dalton swept to office last October to become the first Liberal premier in Canada's most populous province in more than a decade. 
Yet, as in many other places, the Liberals can no longer count on winning Ottawa South on June 28th, in Canada's most tightly fought general election in years. In the final week of the campaign, the Liberal support rallied (see chart). But the polls have been volatile, voters are in surly mood and a fifth of them remain undecided. So the Liberals will be hugely relieved if they can scrape up enough seats to form a minority government. 
Their chances of doing so depend on how they fare in Canada's three main population centres: Ontario, Quebec and the west. Compared with the last election in 2000 (see map), the Liberals have lost popularity in all three, but in each case for slightly different reasons.
Ontario is the biggest battleground. Since calling the election on May 23rd, Paul Martin, the prime minister and Liberal leader, has had to spend far more time in the province than his strategists had planned. He was there again this week, struggling to turn back a Conservative tide which has engulfed a swathe of small cities and rural areas across the centre of the province, from the outskirts of Ottawa in the east to Niagara Falls in the south and the university town of London in the west. 
At the last election, the opposition's divisions denied them seats in Ontario. This time, the merged Conservative Party could snatch up to 50 seats in the province, according to John Wright of Ipsos-Reid, a Toronto polling firm.
Far from being an asset, the McGuinty name has turned into a millstone for the Liberals, and not just in Ottawa South. Support for the Conservatives rocketed in late May after Dalton McGuinty broke a campaign promise to balance the province's books without raising taxes. He has imposed a "health premium" of C$50 ($37) a month on the average Ontario family to help finance ballooning Medicare costs. "Voters are tired of people who say one thing before they're elected and another after they're elected," says Alan Riddell, a bilingual labour lawyer who is the Conservative candidate in Ottawa South. He is given a good chance of winning. 
The Liberals are also paying a price for Mr Martin's drive to grab the top job from his fellow-Liberal predecessor, Jean Chretien and, having done so, to ostracise his supporters. The Martin team's heavy-handed tactics have alienated local Liberal officials and volunteers. For example, the party executive in one Toronto constituency previously held by Mr Chretien's industry minister were dumbstruck when a Martin supporter showed up at the nomination meeting with 6,000 signatures. He won the nomination, but will be lucky to win the election. Few Chretien supporters have stepped forward to man phones or stuff envelopes in the campaign office. 
A surprise is the loosening Liberal grip on the political loyalty of immigrant Canadians. The Liberals have traditionally favoured immigration (including that of family members), and have doled out subsidies for an array of multicultural causes. But many among Ottawa South's large Muslim population are likely to cast their ballots next Monday for Monia Mazigh, of the left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP). Tunisian-born, she led a successful campaign last year to win the release of her husband who was deported by the United States to Syria as a suspected terrorist.
The NDP, under an energetic but garrulous new leader, Jack Layton, had hopes of a breakthrough in this election. But it may fall short of its target of ten seats in Ontario. There were signs that fear of a Conservative victory was driving leftish voters to the Liberal fold.
In Quebec, the Liberals were hoping that similar fears would blunt what looked like an impending massacre. One poll this week had Liberal support in the province plunging to 26%, against 50% for the separatist Bloc Quebecois. The Liberals could lose up to a score of seats in the province. But the outcome may not reflect a wider resurrection of support for secession in Quebec. Richard Schultz, a political scientist at McGill University in Montreal, points out that the Bloc has not made sovereignty an issue in the election. He says a defeat for the federal Liberals might even help Jean Charest's unpopular Liberal government in the province, allowing him to blame problems on Ottawa.
In western Canada, voters are accustomed to feeling like irrelevant bystanders: timezones mean that the election's outcome is usually determined before their votes have been counted. Not this time. The balance of power in Ottawa may depend on a three-way dogfight in British Columbia, where the latest poll gives the Conservatives 36%, ahead of the Liberals (28%) and NDP (26%). That has forced candidates to return to old-time campaigning, knocking on doors and holding local candidate debates. 
Mr Martin has drafted in two prominent recruits, David Emerson, a former businessman, and Ujjal Dosanjh, British Columbia's former NDP premier. He has also offered C$450m in extra money to help fix Vancouver's transport problems. But that is unlikely to assuage westerners' gripes about being ignored by Ottawa, nor break the Conservative ascendancy west of the Prairies.
Across Canada, the election has turned into a contest between fear and anger. Mr Harper has professed moderation on social and economic issues. He would devolve more power to the provinces. More controversially, he would pull out of the Kyoto protocol. Outside his political base of Alberta, many fear that his new party has inherited the social conservatism of its chief forebear, the Canadian Alliance. They worry that Mr Harper would make Canada more like the United States. 
On the other hand, Mr Harper's assault on the Liberals' "waste, mismanagement and corruption" has struck a chord with many voters. Whether their anger at the Liberals will be enough to outweigh their fear of change may not be clear until the last British Columbian votes are tallied.

The balance of power in Ottawa may depend on a three - way dogfight in British Columbia , where the latest poll gives the Conservatives 36 % , ahead of the Liberals ( 28 % ) and NDP ( 26 % ) . That has forced candidates to return to old - time campaigning , knocking on doors and holding local candidate debates . 
 Mr Martin has drafted in two prominent recruits , David Emerson , a former businessman , and Ujjal Dosanjh , British Columbia 's former NDP premier . He has also offered C$ 450 m in extra money to help fix Vancouver 's transport problems . But that is unlikely to assuage westerners ' gripes about being ignored by Ottawa , nor break the Conservative ascendancy west of the Prairies . 
 Across Canada , the election has turned into a contest between fear and anger . Mr Harper has professed moderation on social and economic issues . He would devolve more power to the provinces . More controversially , he would pull out of the Kyoto protocol . Outside his political base of Alberta , many fear that his new party has inherited the social conservatism of its chief forebear , the Canadian Alliance . They worry that Mr Harper would make Canada more like the United States . 
 On the other hand , Mr Harper 's assault on the Liberals ' " waste , mismanagement and corruption " has struck a chord with many voters . Whether their anger at the Liberals will be enough to outweigh their fear of change may not be clear until the last British Columbian votes are tallied .

text:
The voters punish, but reprieve, the Liberals. Now the prime minister faces a difficult tactical challenge
IT WAS far from the powerful personal mandate that was Paul Martin's overriding goal ever since he replaced Jean Chretien as leader of Canada's Liberal Party and thus as prime minister late last year. But neither was it the drubbing that pollsters had predicted. The Liberals lost 37 seats in the general election on June 28th, and with them their majority in the House of Commons. But even after 11 years in power, they remain the largest party. Stephen Harper, the leader of the newly united Conservatives, saw his hopes of government dashed. Nevertheless, though the Liberal vote held up far better than opinion polls had suggested, the party was still humbled. "The message was unmistakable: Canadians expected, and expect, more from us," said Mr Martin.
The prime minister insists he will eschew a formal coalition, and will lead a "stable" minority administration, seeking support where he can find it. A first-past-the-post electoral system in a country of strong regional differences means that Canada is familiar with minority governments, though it has not had one for a generation. Financial markets barely blinked. 
Most minority governments have lasted for 18 months or so. Some have done even better. At a post-election news conference, Mr Martin recalled that Lester Pearson, one of Canada's most revered prime ministers, led minority Liberal governments for five years in the 1960s.
The new balance of the parties is much as it was then, with one big exception. The separatist Bloc Quebecois won by a landslide in its French-speaking province--not from a surge in support for Quebec's independence, but because of anger over a scandal under Mr Chretien in which a programme to promote federalism turned into a slush fund for Liberal cronies. To regain the trust of Quebeckers, the Liberals will have to show "honesty, integrity and a deep respect for taxpayers' dollars", says Mr Martin, whose own seat is in Quebec.
Elsewhere, surprisingly little changed. In the popular vote, the Liberals led the Conservatives by 7.1%, and by 13% in Ontario, the most populous province. The leftish New Democratic Party (NDP) under Jack Layton, a vigorous new leader, almost doubled its share of the vote, but won only six more seats. 
What saved the day for the Liberals was that many voters in socially tolerant Ontario were scared of Mr Harper's Conservatives, a party cobbled together from his own right-wing Canadian Alliance and the more moderate Progressive Conservatives. The Liberals and the NDP succeeded in arousing fears that the Conservative platform concealed ambiguities on abortion and that neither Medicare nor the Charter of Rights and Freedoms would be safe in the party's hands. Mr Harper, a cerebral economist from oil-rich Alberta, had dominated the early weeks of campaigning with attacks on Liberal corruption. But he aroused ire when he suggested that Mr Martin was soft on child pornography.
After weeks of hesitant lethargy, Mr Martin came alive in the campaign's final days. He flung himself into a coast-to-coast dash to support candidates in tight fights. He began touting his successful record in ten years as finance minister under Mr Chretien, casting aside his previous pretence that the two men (who abhor each other) had no links. Meanwhile, Mr Harper, apparently confident of victory and having set a transition team to work, eased off; on the campaign's final day, he took a lengthy bus ride through Alberta. 
In the end, Canada swung slightly to the left, rather than to the right. At the last election, the vote for the two separate conservative parties totalled 38%; the merged party managed only 30%. The Liberals' most willing allies are the NDP; Mr Layton said he wants "a significant role". Between them the two parties will be just one seat short of a majority (or two, if they provide the speaker).
The leftward tilt is a challenge for Mr Martin, a businessman who as finance minister balanced Canada's books, cutting both taxes and spending. This week, he sounded sanguine. There was broad agreement on his top priority, more health spending, he said. He will seek support for his health-care plans at a meeting with provincial premiers. A promised child-care scheme should attract support from the NDP and the Bloc Quebecois, but both have a long wish-list of other new spending pledges. Clashes are likely, too, over defence (even though the hawkish defence minister lost his seat). Mr Martin wants Canada to take part in the Bush administration's plans for an anti-missile shield; the NDP and the Bloc are opposed. The NDP, but not the Bloc, will push for moves towards proportional representation.
Parliament is unlikely to be convened until late September, so Mr Martin has plenty of time to ponder. His first challenge will be to approve a budget next February. Otherwise, he will have to seek support issue by issue.
To do this, he has one big weapon. None of the other parties, except perhaps the NDP, would relish another election soon. The Bloc is unlikely to do as well next time. The Conservatives need time to consolidate their new party and steer it to the centre: they will hold a policy conference in September. Making the most of his weapon will require tactical skill of an order that has been invisible since Mr Martin took over the top job. Unless he now reveals it, the Liberals' defeat may just have been postponed.

text:
Paul Martin reshapes his team
CRAFTING a cabinet is always a particularly delicate balancing act for Canadian prime ministers. Regional, ethnic and gender considerations often prevail over aptitude and expertise. The challenge is that much greater for the rare prime minister who finds himself heading a minority government, as Paul Martin now does after a scolding from voters last month. Not only is the pool of potential candidates reduced, but with a sceptical electorate to impress and not much time to do it--minority governments in Canada are lucky to last two years--the opportunities for fine-tuning later are few.
Mr Martin's new cabinet, named on July 20th, includes much of his old one, assembled when he took over the party leadership and the prime minister's office from Jean Chretien last December. Its bulwarks are still the deputy prime minister, Anne McLellan, and the finance minister, Ralph Goodale, both staunch--if dull--loyalists .
But Mr Martin, whose desire to please everyone has often rendered him a ditherer, also made several bold moves--while ensuring that all the regions (though not women) were well represented. Chief among these was the appointment of Ujjal Dosanjh as health minister. Reforming the faltering state-funded health-care system is probably the most pressing problem facing the Martin government. It is also one which will have to be negotiated with the ten provinces. Mr Dosanjh is a neophyte Liberal MP but was once the premier of British Columbia under the banner of the left-leaning New Democratic Party, whose 19 federal MPs Mr Martin will frequently need to pass legislation. 
Mr Martin also made overtures to moderate Conservatives by naming a defector from their ranks to the influential post of public-works minister. Scott Brison quit the Tories after they merged last autumn with the western-based, socially conservative Canadian Alliance party. 
Mr Brison's appointment is also intended to send another signal. The feeble showing by the Liberals in the June elections was attributable in large part to public outrage over a scandal in which hugely padded contracts were handed out by the public-works department to Liberal-friendly advertising firms in Quebec. The naming of a former Tory to head the ministry is meant to show that the department will no longer be used for doling out largesse to Liberal faithful.
Mr Martin also hopes to mend fences within his own party by bringing back Stephane Dion, a Chretien loyalist formerly in charge of intergovernmental affairs as environment minister. The new intergovernmental affairs minister is Lucienne Robillard, also a Quebecker but a less fervent federalist, an indication that Mr Martin is intent on a more accommodating relationship than his predecessor with the provinces, especially Quebec. 
One victim of the reshuffle was Bill Graham, transferred from foreign affairs, where he was thought by many Canadians to be doing an exemplary job, to the ill-fitting defence ministry. Some explained the move by saying Mr Graham was out of step with Mr Martin on whether Canada should co-operate with the United States on a controversial plan for missile defences; others suggested Mr Martin simply wanted to give the plum foreign-affairs job--which went to Pierre Pettigrew--to a Quebecker.
